24338	41	4	14	 "What the sower sows is the Message.
24339	41	4	15	 Those who receive the seed by the way-side are those in whom the Message is sown, but, when they have heard it, Satan comes at once and carries away the Message sown in them.
24340	41	4	16	 In the same way those who  receive the seed on the rocky places are those who, when they have heard the Message, at once accept it joyfully,
24341	41	4	17	 but they have no root within them. They last for a time; then, when suffering or persecution comes because of the Message, they  are immediately overthrown.
24342	41	4	18	 Others there are who  receive the seed among the thorns: these are they who have heard the Message,
24343	41	4	19	 but worldly cares and the deceitfulness of wealth and the excessive pursuit of other objects come in and stifle the Message, and it becomes unfruitful.
24344	41	4	20	 Those, on the other hand, who  have received the seed on the good ground, are all who hear the Message and welcome it, and yield a return of thirty, sixty, or a hundred fold."
24345	41	4	21	 He went on to say, "Is the lamp brought in in order to be put under the  bushel or under the bed? Is it not rather in order that it may be placed on the lampstand?
24346	41	4	22	  Why, there is nothing hidden except with a view to its being ultimately disclosed, nor has anything been made a secret but that it may at last come to light.
24347	41	4	23	 Listen, every one who has ears to listen with!"
24348	41	4	24	 He also said to them, "Take care what you hear. With what measure you measure, it will be measured to you, and that with interest.
24349	41	4	25	 For those who have will have more given them; and from those who have not, even what they have will be taken away."
24350	41	4	26	 Another saying of His was this: "The Kingdom of God is as if a man scattered seed over the ground:
24351	41	4	27	 he spends days and nights, now awake, now asleep, while the seed sprouts and grows tall, he knows not how.
24352	41	4	28	 Of itself the land produces the crop--  first the blade, then the ear; afterwards the perfect grain is seen in the ear.
24353	41	4	29	 But no sooner is the crop ripe, than he sends the  reapers, because the time of harvest has come."
24354	41	4	30	  Another saying of His was this: "How are we to picture the Kingdom of God? or by what figure of speech shall we represent it?
24355	41	4	31	 It is like a mustard-seed, which, when sown in the earth, is the smallest of all the seeds in the world;
24356	41	4	32	 yet when sown it springs up and becomes larger than all the  herbs, and throws out great branches, so that the birds build under its shadow."
24357	41	4	33	 With many such parables He used to speak the Message to them according to their capacity for receiving it.
24358	41	4	34	 But except in figurative language He spoke nothing to them; while to His own disciples He expounded everything, in private.
24359	41	4	35	  The same day, in the evening, He said to them, "Let us cross to the other side."
24360	41	4	36	 So they got away from the crowd, and took Him--as He was--in the boat; and other boats accompanied Him.
24361	41	4	37	 But a heavy squall came on, and the waves were now dashing into the boat, so that it was fast filling.
24362	41	4	38	 But He Himself was in the stern asleep, with His head on the cushion: so they woke Him.  "Rabbi," they cried, "is it nothing to you that we are drowning?"
24363	41	4	39	 So He roused Himself and rebuked the wind, and said to the waves, "Silence! Be still!" The wind sank, and a perfect calm set in.
24364	41	4	40	 "Why are you so timid?" He asked; "have you still no faith?"
24365	41	4	41	 Then they were filled with terror, and began to say to one another, "Who is this, then? For even wind and sea obey Him."
24366	41	5	1	  So they arrived at the opposite shore of the Lake, in the country of the Gerasenes.
24367	41	5	2	 At once, on His landing, there came from the tombs to meet Him a man  possessed by a foul spirit.
24368	41	5	3	 This man lived  among the tombs, nor could any one now secure him even with a chain;
24369	41	5	4	 for many a time he had been left securely bound in fetters and chains, but afterwards the chains lay torn link from link, and the fetters in fragments, and there was no one strong enough to master him.
24370	41	5	5	 And constantly, day and night, he remained among the tombs or on the hills, shrieking, and mangling himself with sharp stones.
24371	41	5	6	 And when he saw Jesus in the distance, he ran and threw himself at His feet,
24372	41	5	7	 crying out in a loud voice, "What hast Thou to do with me, Jesus, Son of God Most High? In God's name I implore Thee not to torment me."
24373	41	5	8	 For He  had said to him, "Foul spirit, come out of the man."
24374	41	5	9	 Jesus also questioned him. "What is your name?" He said. "Legion," he replied, "for there are a host of us."
24375	41	5	10	 And  he earnestly entreated Him not to send them away out of the country.
24376	41	5	11	 Feeding there, on the mountain slope, was a great herd of swine.
24377	41	5	12	 So they besought Jesus. "Send us to the swine," they said, "so that we may enter into them."
24378	41	5	13	 He gave them leave; and the foul spirits came out and entered into the swine, and the herd--about 2,000 in number--rushed headlong down the cliff into the Lake and were drowned in the Lake.
24379	41	5	14	 The swineherds fled, and spread the news in town and country. So the people came to see what it was that had happened;
24380	41	5	15	 and when they came to Jesus, they beheld the demoniac quietly seated, clothed and of sane mind--the man who had had the legion; and they were awe-stricken.
24381	41	5	16	 And those who had seen it told them the particulars of what had happened to the demoniac, and all about the swine.
24382	41	5	17	 Then they began entreating Him to depart from their district.
24383	41	5	18	 As He was embarking, the man who had been possessed asked permission to accompany Him.
24384	41	5	19	 But He would not allow it. "Go home to your family," He said, "and report to them all that the Lord has done for you, and the mercy He has shown you."
24385	41	5	20	 So the man departed, and related publicly everywhere in the Ten Towns all that Jesus had done for him; and all were astonished.
24386	41	5	21	  When Jesus had re-crossed in the boat to the other side, a vast multitude came crowding to Him; and He was on the shore of the Lake,
24387	41	5	22	 when there came one of the Wardens of the Synagogue--he was called  Jair--who, on beholding Him, threw himself at His feet,
24388	41	5	23	 and besought Him with many entreaties. "My little daughter," he said, "is at the point of death: I pray you come and lay your hands upon her, that she may recover and live."
24389	41	5	24	 And Jesus went with him. And a dense crowd followed Him, and thronged Him on all sides.
24390	41	5	25	 Now a woman who for twelve years had suffered from haemorrhage,
24391	41	5	26	 and had undergone many different treatments under a number of doctors and had spent all she had without receiving benefit but on the contrary growing worse,
24392	41	5	27	 heard of Jesus. And she came in the crowd behind Him and touched His cloak;
24393	41	5	28	 for she said, "If I but touch His clothes, I shall be cured."
24394	41	5	29	 In a moment the  flow of her blood ceased, and she felt in herself that her complaint was cured.
24395	41	5	30	 Immediately Jesus, well knowing that healing power had gone  from within Him, turned round in the crowd and asked, "Who touched my clothes?"
24396	41	5	31	 "You see the multitude pressing you on all sides," His disciples exclaimed, "and yet you ask, `Who touched me?'"
24397	41	5	32	 But He continued looking about to see the person who had done this,
24398	41	5	33	 until the woman, frightened and trembling, knowing what had happened to her, came and threw herself at His feet, and told Him all the truth.
24399	41	5	34	 "Daughter," He said, "your faith has cured you: go in peace, and be free from your complaint."
24400	41	5	35	 While He is yet speaking, men come from the house to the Warden, and say, "Your daughter  is dead: why trouble the  Rabbi further?"
24401	41	5	36	 But Jesus,  overhearing the words, said to the Warden, "Do not be afraid; only have faith."
24402	41	5	37	 And He allowed no one to accompany Him except Peter and the brothers James and John.
24403	41	5	38	 So they come to the Warden's house. Here He gazes on a scene of uproar, with people  weeping aloud and wailing.
24404	41	5	39	 He goes in. "Why all this outcry and loud weeping?" He asks; "the child is asleep, not dead."
24405	41	5	40	 To this their reply is a scornful laugh. He, however, puts them all out, takes the child's father and mother and those He has brought with Him, and enters the room where the child lies.
24406	41	5	41	 Then, taking her by the hand, He says to her, "Talitha, koum;" that is to say, "Little girl, I command you to wake!"
24407	41	5	42	 Instantly the little girl rises to her feet and begins to walk (for she was twelve years old). They were  at once beside themselves with utter astonishment;
24408	41	5	43	 but He gave strict injunctions that the matter should not be made known, and directed them to give her something to eat.
24409	41	6	1	  Leaving that place He came into His  own country, accompanied by His disciples.
24410	41	6	2	 On the Sabbath He proceeded to teach in the synagogue; and many, as they heard Him, were astonished. "Where did he acquire all this?" they asked. "What is this wisdom that has been given to him? And what are  these marvellous miracles which his hands perform?
24411	41	6	3	 Is not this the carpenter, Mary's son, the brother of James and Joses, Jude and Simon? And do not his sisters live here among us?" So they turned angrily away.
24412	41	6	4	 But Jesus said to them, "There is no Prophet without honour except in his own country, and among his own relatives, and in his own home."
24413	41	6	5	 And He could not do any miracle there, except that He laid His hands on a few who were out of health and cured them; and
24414	41	6	6	 He wondered at their unbelief.  So He went round the adjacent villages, teaching.
24415	41	6	7	  Then summoning the Twelve to Him, He proceeded to send them out by twos, and gave them authority over the foul spirits.
24416	41	6	8	 He charged them to take nothing  for the journey except a stick; no bread, no bag, and  not a penny in their  pockets,
24417	41	6	9	 but to go wearing  sandals. "And do not," He said, "put on an extra under garment.
24418	41	6	10	 Wherever you enter a house, make it your home till you leave that place.
24419	41	6	11	 But wherever they will not receive you or listen to you, when you leave shake off the very dust from under your feet to bear witness concerning them."
24420	41	6	12	 So they set out, and preached in order that men might repent.
24421	41	6	13	 Many demons they expelled, and many invalids they anointed with oil and cured.
24422	41	6	14	  King Herod heard of all this (for the name of Jesus had become widely known), and  he kept saying, "John  the Baptizer  has come back to life, and that is why  these miraculous Powers are working in him."
24423	41	6	15	 Others asserted that He was Elijah. Others again said, "He is a Prophet, like one of the great Prophets."
24424	41	6	16	 But when Herod heard of Him, he said, "The John, whom I beheaded,  has come back to life."
24425	41	6	17	  For  Herod himself had sent and had had John arrested and had kept him in prison in chains, for the sake of Herodias, his brother Philip's wife; because he had married her.
24426	41	6	18	 For John had repeatedly told Herod, "You have no right to be living with your brother's wife."
24427	41	6	19	 Therefore Herodias  hated him and wished to take his life, but could not;
24428	41	6	20	 for Herod  stood in awe of John, knowing him to be an upright and holy man, and he protected him. After listening to him he  was in great perplexity, and yet he found a pleasure in listening.
24429	41	6	21	  At length Herodias found her opportunity. Herod on his birthday gave a banquet to the nobles of his court and to the  tribunes and the principal people in Galilee,
24430	41	6	22	 at which  Herodias's own daughter came in and danced, and so charmed Herod and his guests that he said to her, "Ask me for anything you please, and I will give it to you."
24431	41	6	23	 He even swore to her, "Whatever you ask me for I will give you, up to half my kingdom."
24432	41	6	24	 She at once went out and said to her mother: "What shall I ask for?" "The head of John the Baptizer," she replied.
24433	41	6	25	 The girl immediately came in, in haste, to the King and made her request. "My desire is," she said, "that you will give me, here and now, on a dish, the head of John the Baptist."
24434	41	6	26	 Then the King, though intensely sorry, yet for the sake of his oaths, and of his guests, would not break faith with her.
24435	41	6	27	 He at once sent a soldier of his guard with orders to bring John's head. So he went and beheaded him in the prison,
24436	41	6	28	 and brought his head on a dish and gave it to the young girl, who gave it to her mother.
24437	41	6	29	 When John's disciples heard of it, they came and took away his body and laid it in a tomb.
24438	41	6	30	  When the Apostles had re-assembled round Jesus, they reported to Him all they had done and all they had taught.
24439	41	6	31	 Then He said to them, "Come away, all of you, to a quiet place, and rest awhile." For there were many coming and going, so that they had no time even for meals.
24440	41	6	32	 Accordingly they sailed away in the boat to a solitary place apart.
24441	41	6	33	 But the people saw them going, and many knew them; and coming by land they ran together there from all the neighbouring towns, and arrived before them.
24442	41	6	34	 So when Jesus landed, He saw a vast multitude; and His heart was moved with pity for them, because they were like sheep which have no shepherd, and He proceeded to teach them many things.
24443	41	6	35	 By this time it was late; so His disciples came to Him, and said, "This is a lonely place, and the hour is now late:
24444	41	6	36	 send them away that they may go to the farms and villages near here and buy themselves something to eat."
24445	41	6	37	 "Give them food yourselves," He replied. "Are we," they asked, "to go and buy two hundred shillings' worth of bread and give them food?"
24446	41	6	38	 "How many loaves have you?" He inquired; "go and see." So they found out, and said, "Five; and a couple of fish."
24447	41	6	39	 So He directed them to make all sit down in companies on the green grass.
24448	41	6	40	 And they sat down in  rows of hundreds and of fifties.
24449	41	6	41	 Then He took the five loaves and the two fish, and lifting His eyes to Heaven He blessed the food. Then He broke the loaves into portions which He went on handing to the disciples to distribute; giving pieces also of the two fish to them all.
24450	41	6	42	 All ate and were fully satisfied.
24451	41	6	43	 And they carried away broken portions enough to fill twelve baskets, besides pieces of the fish.
24452	41	6	44	 Those who ate the bread were 5,000 adult men.
24453	41	6	45	  Immediately afterwards He made His disciples go on board the boat and cross over to Bethsaida, leaving Him behind to dismiss the crowd.
24454	41	6	46	 He then bade the people farewell, and went away up the hill to pray.
24455	41	6	47	 When evening was come, the boat was half way across the Lake, while he Himself was on shore alone.
24456	41	6	48	 But when He saw them distressed with rowing (for the wind was against them),  towards morning He came towards them walking on the Lake, as if intending to pass them.
24457	41	6	49	 They saw Him walking on the water, and thinking that it was a spirit they cried out;
24458	41	6	50	 for they all saw Him and were terrified. He, however, immediately spoke to them. "There is no danger," He said; "it is I; be not alarmed."
24459	41	6	51	 Then He went up to them on board the boat, and the wind lulled; and they were beside themselves with  silent amazement.
24460	41	6	52	 For they had not  learned the lesson taught by the loaves, but their  minds were dull.
24461	41	6	53	  Having crossed over they drew to land in Gennesaret and came  to anchor.
24462	41	6	54	 But no sooner had they gone ashore than the people immediately recognized Him.
24463	41	6	55	 Then they scoured the whole district, and began to bring Him the sick on their mats wherever they heard He was.
24464	41	6	56	 And enter wherever He might--village or town or hamlet--they laid their sick in the open places, and entreated Him to let them touch were it but the tassel of His robe; and all, whoever touched Him, were restored to health.
24465	41	7	1	  Then  the Pharisees, with certain Scribes who had come from Jerusalem, came to Him in a body.
24466	41	7	2	 They had noticed that some of His disciples were eating their food with `unclean' (that is to say, unwashed) hands.
24467	41	7	3	 (For the Pharisees and all the Jews--being, as they are, zealous for the traditions of the Elders--never eat without first  carefully washing their hands,
24468	41	7	4	 and when they come from market they will not eat without  bathing first; and they have a good many other customs which they have received traditionally and cling to, such as the rinsing of cups and pots and of bronze utensils,  and the washing of beds.)
24469	41	7	5	 So the Pharisees and Scribes put the question to Him: "Why do your disciples transgress the traditions of the Elders, and eat their  food with unclean hands?"
24470	41	7	6	 "Rightly did Isaiah prophesy of you hypocrites," He replied; "as it is written, <"`This People honour Me with their lips, while their hearts are far away from Me:
24471	41	7	7	 But idle is their devotion while they lay down precepts which are mere human rules.'>
24472	41	7	8	 "You neglect God's Commandment: you hold fast to men's traditions."
24473	41	7	9	 "Praiseworthy indeed!" He added, "to set at nought God's Commandment in order to observe your own traditions!
24474	41	7	10	 For Moses said, <`Honour thy father and thy mother'> and again, <`He who  curses father or mother, let him  die the death.'>
24475	41	7	11	 But *you* say, `If a man says to his father or mother, It is a Korban (that is, a thing  devoted to God), whatever it is, which otherwise you would have received  from me--'
24476	41	7	12	 And so you no longer allow him to do anything for his father or mother,
24477	41	7	13	 thus nullifying God's precept by  your tradition which you have handed down. And many things of that kind you do."
24478	41	7	14	 Then Jesus called the people to Him again. "Listen to me, all of you," He said, "and understand.
24479	41	7	15	 There is nothing  outside a man which entering him can make him unclean; but it is the things which come out of a man that make him unclean."
24480	41	7	16	  []
24481	41	7	17	 After He had left the crowd and gone indoors, His disciples began to ask Him about this figure of speech.
24482	41	7	18	 "Have *you* also so little understanding?" He replied; "do you not understand that anything whatever that enters a man from outside cannot make him unclean,
24483	41	7	19	 because it does not go into his heart, but into his stomach, and passes away ejected from him?" By these words Jesus pronounced all kinds of food clean.
24484	41	7	20	 "What comes out of a man," He added, "that it is which makes him unclean.
24485	41	7	21	 For from within, out of men's hearts, their evil purposes proceed--fornication, theft, murder, adultery,
24486	41	7	22	 covetousness, wickedness, deceit, licentiousness, envy, reviling, pride, reckless folly:
24487	41	7	23	 all these wicked things come out from within and make a man unclean."
24488	41	7	24	  Then He rose and left that place and went into the neighbourhood of Tyre  and Sidon. Here He entered a house and wished no one to know it, but He could not escape observation.
24489	41	7	25	 Forthwith a woman whose little daughter was possessed by a foul spirit heard of Him, and came and flung herself at His feet.
24490	41	7	26	 She was a  Gentile woman, a Syro-phoenician by nation: and again and again she begged Him to expel the demon from her daughter.
24491	41	7	27	 "Let the children first eat all they want," He said; "it is not right to take the children's bread and throw it to the  dogs."
24492	41	7	28	 "True, Sir," she replied, "and yet the dogs under the table eat the children's scraps."
24493	41	7	29	 "For those words of yours, go home," He replied; "the demon has gone out of your daughter."
24494	41	7	30	 So she went home, and found the child  lying on the bed, and the demon gone.
24495	41	7	31	  Returning from the neighbourhood of Tyre, He came by way of Sidon to the Lake of Galilee, passing through the district of the Ten Towns.
24496	41	7	32	 Here they brought to Him a deaf man that stammered, on whom they begged Him to lay His hands.
24497	41	7	33	 So Jesus taking him aside, apart from the crowd, put His fingers into his ears, and spat, and moistened his tongue;
24498	41	7	34	 and looking up to Heaven  He sighed, and said to him, "Ephphatha!" (that is, "Open!")
24499	41	7	35	 And the man's ears were opened, and his tongue became untied, and he began to speak perfectly.
24500	41	7	36	 Then Jesus charged them to tell no one; but the more He charged them, all the more did they spread the news far and wide.
24501	41	7	37	 The amazement was extreme.  "He succeeds in everything he attempts," they exclaimed; "he even makes deaf men hear and dumb men speak!"
24502	41	8	1	  About that time there was again an immense crowd, and they found themselves with nothing to eat. So He called His disciples to Him.
24503	41	8	2	 "My heart yearns over the people," He said; "for this is now  the third day they have remained with me, and they have nothing to eat.
24504	41	8	3	 If I were to send them home hungry, they would faint on the way, some of them having come a great distance."
24505	41	8	4	 "Where can we possibly get bread here in this remote place to satisfy such a crowd?" answered His disciples.
24506	41	8	5	 "How many loaves have you?" He asked. "Seven," they said.
24507	41	8	6	 So He passed the word to the people to sit down on the ground. Then taking the seven loaves He blessed them, and broke them into portions and proceeded to give them to His disciples for them to distribute, and they distributed them to the people.
24508	41	8	7	 They had also a few small fish. He blessed them, and He told His disciples to distribute these also.
24509	41	8	8	 So the people ate an abundant meal; and what remained over they picked up and carried away--seven hampers of broken pieces.
24510	41	8	9	 The number fed were about 4,000. Then He sent them away,
24511	41	8	10	  and at once going on board with His disciples He came into the district of Dalmanutha.
24512	41	8	11	 The Pharisees followed Him and began to dispute with Him, asking Him for a sign  in the sky, to make trial of Him.
24513	41	8	12	 Heaving a deep and troubled sigh, He said, "Why do the men of to-day ask for a sign? In solemn truth I tell you that no sign will be given to the men of to-day."
24514	41	8	13	  So He left them, went on board again, and came away to the other side.
24515	41	8	14	 Now they had forgotten to take bread, nor had they more than a single loaf with them in the boat;
24516	41	8	15	 and when He admonished them, "See to it, be on your guard against the yeast of the Pharisees and the yeast of Herod,"
24517	41	8	16	 they explained His words to one another by saying, "We have no bread!"
24518	41	8	17	 He perceived what they were saying, and He said to them, "What is this discussion of yours about having no bread? Do you not yet see and understand? Are your minds so dull of comprehension?
24519	41	8	18	 <You have eyes! can you not see? You have ears! can you not hear?> and  have you no memory?
24520	41	8	19	 When I broke up the five loaves for the 5,000 men, how many baskets did you carry away full of broken portions?" "Twelve," they said.
24521	41	8	20	 "And when the seven for the 4,000, how many hampers full of portions did you take away?" "Seven," they answered.
24522	41	8	21	 "Do you not yet understand?"  He said.
24523	41	8	22	 And they came to Bethsaida. And a blind man was brought to Jesus and they entreated Him to touch him.
24524	41	8	23	 So He took the blind man by the  arm and brought him out of the village, and spitting into his eyes He put His hands on him and asked him, "Can you see anything?"
24525	41	8	24	 He looked up and said, "I can see the people: I see them like trees--only walking."
24526	41	8	25	 Then for the second time He put His hands on the man's eyes, and the man, looking steadily, recovered his sight and saw everything distinctly.
24527	41	8	26	 So He sent him home, and added, "Do not even go into the village."
24528	41	8	27	  From that place Jesus and His disciples went to the villages belonging to Caesarea Philippi. On the way He  began to ask His disciples, "Who do people say that I am?"
24529	41	8	28	 "John the Baptist," they replied, "but others say Elijah, and others, that it is one of the Prophets."
24530	41	8	29	 Then  He asked them pointedly, "But you yourselves, who do you say that I am?" "You are  the Christ," answered Peter.
24531	41	8	30	 And He strictly forbad them to tell this about Him to any one.
24532	41	8	31	 And now for the first time He told them, "The Son of Man  must endure much suffering, and be rejected by the Elders and the High Priests and the Scribes, and be put to death, and after two days  rise to life."
24533	41	8	32	 This He told them plainly; whereupon Peter took Him and began to remonstrate with Him.
24534	41	8	33	 But turning round and seeing His disciples, He rebuked Peter. "Get behind me,  Adversary," He said, "for your thoughts are not God's thoughts, but men's."
24535	41	8	34	 Then calling to Him the crowd and also His disciples, He said to them, "If any one is desirous of following me, let him ignore self and take up his cross, and so be my follower.
24536	41	8	35	 For whoever is bent on securing his  life will lose it, but he who loses his  life for my sake, and for the sake of the Good News, will secure it.
24537	41	8	36	  Why, what does it benefit a man to gain the whole world and  forfeit his life?
24538	41	8	37	 For what could a man give to buy back his life?
24539	41	8	38	 Every one, however, who  has been ashamed of me and of my teachings in this  faithless and sinful age, of him the Son of Man also will be ashamed when He comes in His Father's glory with the holy angels."
24540	41	9	1	 He went on to say, "In solemn truth I tell you that some of those who  are standing here will certainly not taste death till they have seen the Kingdom of God  already come  in power."
24541	41	9	2	  Six days later, Jesus took with Him Peter, James, and John, and brought them alone, apart from the rest, up a high mountain; and in their presence His appearance underwent a change.
24542	41	9	3	 His garments also became dazzling with brilliant whiteness--such whiteness as no bleaching on earth could give.
24543	41	9	4	 Moreover there appeared to them Elijah accompanied by Moses; and the two were conversing with Jesus,
24544	41	9	5	 when  Peter said to Jesus, "Rabbi,  we are thankful to you that we are here. Let us put up three  tents--one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah."
24545	41	9	6	 For he knew not what  to say: they were filled with such awe.
24546	41	9	7	 Then there came a cloud  spreading over them, and a voice issued from the cloud, "This is my Son, dearly loved: listen to Him."
24547	41	9	8	 Instantly they looked round, and now they could no longer see any one, but themselves and Jesus.
24548	41	9	9	 As they were coming down from the mountain, He very strictly forbad them to tell any one what they had seen "until after the Son of Man has risen from among the dead."
24549	41	9	10	 So they kept the matter to themselves, although frequently asking one another what was meant by the rising from the dead.
24550	41	9	11	 They also asked Him, "How is it that the Scribes say that Elijah must first come?"
24551	41	9	12	 "Elijah," He replied, "does indeed come first and reforms everything; but how is it that it is written of the Son of Man that He will endure much suffering and be held in contempt?
24552	41	9	13	 Yet I tell you that not only has Elijah come, but they have also done to him whatever they chose, as the Scriptures say about him."
24553	41	9	14	  As they came to rejoin the disciples, they saw an immense crowd surrounding them and a party of Scribes disputing with them.
24554	41	9	15	 Immediately the whole multitude on beholding Him were  astonished and awe-struck, and yet they ran forward and  greeted Him.
24555	41	9	16	 "What is the subject you are discussing?" He asked them.
24556	41	9	17	  "Rabbi," answered one of the crowd,  "I have brought you my son. He has a dumb spirit in him;
24557	41	9	18	 and wherever it comes upon him, it  dashes him to the ground, and he foams at the mouth and grinds his teeth, and he is pining away. I  begged your disciples to expel it, but they had not the power."
24558	41	9	19	 "O unbelieving generation!" replied Jesus; "how long must I be with you? how long must I have patience with you? Bring the boy to me."
24559	41	9	20	 So they brought him to Jesus. And the spirit,  when he saw Jesus, immediately threw the youth into convulsions, so that he fell on the ground and rolled about, foaming at the mouth.
24560	41	9	21	 Then Jesus asked the father, "How long has he been like this?" "From early childhood," he said;
24561	41	9	22	 "and often it has thrown him into the fire  or into  pools of water to destroy him. But, if you possibly can, have pity on us and help us."
24562	41	9	23	 "`If I possibly can!'" replied Jesus; "why, everything is possible to him who believes."
24563	41	9	24	 Immediately the father  cried out, "I do believe: strengthen my weak faith."
24564	41	9	25	 Then Jesus, seeing that an increasing crowd was running towards Him, rebuked the foul spirit, and said to it, "Dumb and deaf spirit, *I* command you, come out of him and never enter into him again."
24565	41	9	26	 So with a loud cry he threw the boy into fit after fit, and came out. The boy looked as if he were dead, so that most of them said  he was dead;
24566	41	9	27	 but Jesus took his hand and raised him up, and he stood on his feet.
24567	41	9	28	 After the return of Jesus  to the house His disciples asked Him privately, "How is it that we could not expel the spirit?"
24568	41	9	29	 "An evil spirit of this kind," He answered, "can only be driven out  by prayer."
24569	41	9	30	  Departing thence they passed through Galilee, and He was unwilling that any one should know it;
24570	41	9	31	 for He was teaching His disciples, and telling them, "The Son of Man is to be betrayed into the hands of men, and they will put Him to death; and after being put to death, in three days He will rise to life again."
24571	41	9	32	 They, however, did not understand what He meant, and were afraid to question Him.
24572	41	9	33	  So they came to Capernaum; and when in the house He asked them, "What were you arguing about on the way?"
24573	41	9	34	 But they remained silent; for on the way they had debated with one another who was the chief of them.
24574	41	9	35	 Then sitting down He called the Twelve, and said to them, "If any one wishes to be first,  he must be last of all and servant of all."
24575	41	9	36	 And taking a young child He made him stand in their midst, then threw His arms round him and said,
24576	41	9	37	 "Whoever  for my sake receives one such young child as this, receives me; and whoever receives me, receives not so much me as Him who sent me."
24577	41	9	38	  "Rabbi,"  said John to Him, "we saw a  man making use of your name to expel demons, and we tried to hinder him,  on the ground that he did not follow us."
24578	41	9	39	  "You should not have tried to hinder him," replied Jesus, "for there is no one who will use my name to perform a miracle and be able the next minute to speak evil of me.
24579	41	9	40	  He who is not against us is for us;
24580	41	9	41	  and whoever gives you a cup of water to drink because you belong to Christ, I solemnly tell you that he will certainly not lose his reward.
24581	41	9	42	  "And whoever shall occasion the fall of one of these little ones who  believe, he would be better off if, with a  millstone round his neck, he were  lying at the bottom of the sea.
24582	41	9	43	 If your hand should  cause you to sin, cut it off: it would be better for you to enter into Life maimed, than remain in possession of both your hands and go away into Gehenna, into the  fire which cannot be put out.
24583	41	9	44	  []
24584	41	9	45	 Or if your foot  should cause you to sin, cut it off: it would be better for you to enter into Life crippled, than remain in possession of both your feet and be thrown into Gehenna.
24585	41	9	46	  []
24586	41	9	47	 Or if your eye  should cause you to sin, tear it out. It would be better for you to enter into the Kingdom of God half-blind than remain in possession of two eyes and be thrown into Gehenna,
24587	41	9	48	 where <their worm does not die and the fire does not go out.>
24588	41	9	49	 Every one,  however, will be salted  with fire.
24589	41	9	50	 Salt is a good thing, but if the salt should become tasteless, what will you use to give it saltness? Have salt within you and live at peace with one another."
24590	41	10	1	  Soon on His feet once more, He enters the district of Judaea and crosses the Jordan: again the people flock to Him, and ere long, as was usual with Him, He was teaching them once more.
24591	41	10	2	  Presently a party of Pharisees come to Him with the question--seeking to entrap Him, "May a man divorce his wife?"
24592	41	10	3	 "What rule did Moses lay down for you?" He answered.
24593	41	10	4	 "Moses," they said, "permitted a man to draw up a written notice of divorce, and to send his wife away."
24594	41	10	5	 "It was in consideration of your stubborn hearts," said Jesus, "that Moses enacted this law for you;
24595	41	10	6	 but from the beginning of the creation the rule was, <`Male and female did God make them.
24596	41	10	7	 For this reason a man  shall leave his father and his mother, and  shall cling to his wife,
24597	41	10	8	 and the two  shall be  one';> so that they are two no longer, but  <`one.'>
24598	41	10	9	 What, therefore, God has joined together let not man separate."
24599	41	10	10	 Indoors the disciples began questioning Jesus again on the same subject.
24600	41	10	11	 He replied, "Whoever divorces his wife and marries another woman, commits adultery against the first wife;
24601	41	10	12	 and if a woman puts away her husband and marries another man, she commits adultery."
24602	41	10	13	  One day people were bringing young children to Jesus for Him to touch them, but the disciples interfered.
24603	41	10	14	 Jesus, however, on seeing this, was moved to indignation, and said to them, "Let the little children come to me: do not hinder them; for to those who are childlike the Kingdom of God belongs.
24604	41	10	15	 In solemn truth I tell you that no one who does not receive the Kingdom of God like a little child will by any possibility enter it."
24605	41	10	16	 Then He  took them in His arms and blessed them lovingly,  one by one, laying His hands upon them.
24606	41	10	17	  As He went out to resume His journey, there came  a man running up to Him, who knelt at His feet and asked, "Good Rabbi, what am I to do in order to inherit the Life  of the Ages?"
24607	41	10	18	 "Why do you call me good?" asked Jesus in reply; "there is no one truly good except One--that is, God.
24608	41	10	19	 You know the Commandments--<`Do not murder;' `Do not commit adultery;' `Do not steal;' `Do not lie in giving evidence;' `Do not defraud;' `Honour thy father and thy mother.'">
24609	41	10	20	 "Rabbi," he replied, "all these Commandments I have carefully obeyed from my youth."
24610	41	10	21	 Then Jesus looked at him and  loved him, and said, "One thing is lacking in you: go, sell all you possess and  give the proceeds to the poor, and you shall have riches in Heaven; and come and be a follower of mine."
24611	41	10	22	 At these words his brow darkened, and he went away sad; for he was possessed of great wealth.
24612	41	10	23	 Then looking round on His disciples Jesus said, "With how hard a struggle will the possessors of riches enter the Kingdom of God!"
24613	41	10	24	 The disciples were  amazed at His words. Jesus, however,  said again, "Children, how hard a struggle is it  for those who trust in riches to enter the Kingdom of God!
24614	41	10	25	 It is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the Kingdom of God."
24615	41	10	26	 They were astonished beyond measure, and said to one another, "Who then *can* be saved?"
24616	41	10	27	 Jesus looking on them said, "With men it is impossible, but not with God; for everything is possible with God."
24617	41	10	28	 "Remember,"  said Peter to Him, "that we forsook everything and have become your followers."
24618	41	10	29	 "In solemn truth I tell you," replied Jesus, "that there is no one who has forsaken house or brothers or sisters, or mother or father, or children or lands, for my sake and for the sake of the Good News,
24619	41	10	30	 but will receive a hundred times as much now  in this present life--houses, brothers, sisters, mothers, children, lands--and persecution with them--and in the coming age the Life  of the Ages.
24620	41	10	31	 But many who are now first will be last, and the last, first."
24621	41	10	32	  They were still on the road going up to Jerusalem, and Jesus was walking ahead of them; they were full of wonder, and some, though they followed, did so with fear. Then, once more calling to Him the Twelve, He began to tell them what was about to happen to Him.
24622	41	10	33	 "See," He said, "we are going up to Jerusalem, where the Son of Man will be betrayed to the High Priests and the Scribes. They will condemn Him to death, and will hand Him over to the Gentiles;
24623	41	10	34	 they will insult Him in cruel sport, spit on Him,  scourge Him, and put Him to death; but on the third day He will rise to life again."
24624	41	10	35	  Then James and John, the sons of Zabdi, came up to Him and said,  "Rabbi, we wish you would grant us  whatever request we make of you."
24625	41	10	36	 "What would you have me do for you?" He asked.
24626	41	10	37	 "Allow us," they replied, "to sit one at your right hand and the other at your left hand, in your glory."
24627	41	10	38	 "You know not," said He, "what you are asking. Are you able to drink out of the  cup from which I am to drink, or to be baptized with the  baptism with which I am to be baptized?"
24628	41	10	39	 "We are able," they replied. "Out of the cup," said Jesus, "from which I am to drink you shall drink, and with the baptism with which I am to be baptized you shall be baptized;
24629	41	10	40	 but as to sitting at my right hand or at my left, that is not mine to give: it will be for those for whom it is reserved."
24630	41	10	41	 The other ten, hearing of it, were at first highly indignant with James and John.
24631	41	10	42	 Jesus, however, called them to Him and said to them, "You are aware how those who are deemed rulers among the Gentiles lord it over them, and their great men make them feel their authority;
24632	41	10	43	 but it is not to be so among you. No, whoever desires to be great among you must be your servant;
24633	41	10	44	 and whoever desires to be first among you must be the bondservant of all.
24634	41	10	45	 For the Son of Man also did not come to be waited upon, but to wait on others, and to give His  life as the redemption-price for a multitude of people."
24635	41	10	46	  They came to Jericho; and as He was leaving that town--Himself and His disciples and a great crowd--Bartimaeus (the son of Timaeus), a blind beggar, was sitting by the way-side.
24636	41	10	47	 Hearing that it was Jesus the Nazarene, he began to cry out, "Son of David, Jesus, have pity on me."
24637	41	10	48	 Many angrily told him to leave off shouting; but he only cried out all the louder, "Son of David, have pity on me."
24638	41	10	49	 Then Jesus stood still. "Call him," He said. So they called the blind man. "Cheer up," they said; "rise, he is calling you."
24639	41	10	50	 The man flung away his outer garment, sprang to his feet, and came to Jesus.
24640	41	10	51	 "What shall I do for you?"  said Jesus.  "Rabboni," replied the blind man, "let me  recover my sight."
24641	41	10	52	 "Go," said Jesus, "your faith has cured you." Instantly he  regained his sight, and followed Him along the road.
24642	41	11	1	  When they were getting near Jerusalem and had arrived at Bethphage and Bethany, on the Mount of Olives, Jesus sent two of his disciples on in front, with these instructions.
24643	41	11	2	 "Go," He said, "to the village facing you, and immediately on entering it you will find an ass's foal tied up which no one has ever yet ridden: untie him and bring him here.
24644	41	11	3	 And if any one asks you, `Why are you doing that?' say, `The Master needs it, and will send it back here without delay.'"
24645	41	11	4	 So they went and found a young ass tied up at the front door of a house. They were untying it,
24646	41	11	5	 when some of the bystanders called out, "What are you doing, untying the foal?"
24647	41	11	6	 But on their giving the answer that Jesus had bidden them give, they let them take it.
24648	41	11	7	 So they brought the foal to Jesus, and threw their outer garments over him; and Jesus mounted.
24649	41	11	8	 Then many spread their outer garments to carpet the road, and others leafy branches which they had cut down  in the fields;
24650	41	11	9	 while those who led the way and those who followed kept shouting <"God save Him!" Blessed be He who comes in the Lord's name.>
24651	41	11	10	 Blessings on the coming Kingdom of our forefather David! <God in the highest Heavens save Him!">
24652	41	11	11	 So He came into Jerusalem and into  the Temple; and after looking round upon everything there, the hour being now late He went out to Bethany with the Twelve.
24653	41	11	12	  The next day, after they had left Bethany, He was hungry.
24654	41	11	13	 But in the distance He saw a fig-tree in full leaf, and went to see whether perhaps He could find some figs on it. When however He came to it, He found nothing but leaves (for it was  not fig time);
24655	41	11	14	 and He said to the tree, "Let no one ever again eat fruit from thee!" And His disciples heard this.
24656	41	11	15	  They reached Jerusalem, and entering the Temple He began to drive out the buyers and sellers, and upset the money-changers' tables and the stools of the pigeon-dealers,
24657	41	11	16	 and would not allow any one to carry  anything through the Temple.
24658	41	11	17	 And He remonstrated with them. "Is it not written," He said, <"`My House shall be called The House of Prayer for all the nations?'> But you  have made it what it now is--<a robbers' cave.">
24659	41	11	18	 This the High Priests and Scribes heard, and they began to devise means to destroy Him. For they were afraid of Him, because of the deep impression produced on all the people by His teaching.
24660	41	11	19	 When evening came on, Jesus and His disciples used to leave the city.
24661	41	11	20	  In the early morning, as they passed by, they saw the fig-tree withered to the roots;
24662	41	11	21	 and Peter, recollecting, said to Him, "Look, Rabbi, the fig-tree which you cursed is withered up."
24663	41	11	22	 Jesus said to them, "Have faith in God.
24664	41	11	23	 In solemn truth I tell you that if any one shall say to this mountain, `Remove, and hurl thyself into the sea,' and has no doubt about it in his heart, but stedfastly believes that what he says will happen, it shall be granted him.
24665	41	11	24	 That is why I tell you, as to whatever you pray and make request for, if you believe that you have received it it shall be yours.
24666	41	11	25	 But whenever you stand praying, if you have a grievance against any one, forgive it, so that your Father in Heaven may also forgive you your offences."
24667	41	11	26	  []
24668	41	11	27	  They came again to Jerusalem; and as He was walking in the Temple, the High Priests, Scribes and Elders came to Him
24669	41	11	28	 and asked,  "By what authority are you doing these things? and who gave you authority to do them?"
24670	41	11	29	 "And I will put a question to you," replied Jesus; "answer me, and then I will tell you by what authority I do these things.
24671	41	11	30	 John's Baptism--was it of Heavenly or of human origin? Answer me."
24672	41	11	31	 So they debated the matter with one another. "Suppose we say, `Heavenly,'" they argued, "he will ask, `Why then did you not believe him?'
24673	41	11	32	 Or should we say, `human?'" They were afraid of the people; for all agreed in holding John to have been really a Prophet.
24674	41	11	33	 So they answered Jesus, "We do not know." "Nor do I tell you," said Jesus, "by what authority I do these things."
24675	41	12	1	  Then He began to speak to them in figurative language. "There was once a man," He said, "who planted a vineyard, fenced it round, dug a pit for the wine-tank, and built a strong lodge. Then he let the place to vine-dressers and went abroad.
24676	41	12	2	 At vintage-time he sent one of his servants to receive from the vine-dressers a share of the grapes.
24677	41	12	3	 But they seized him, beat him cruelly and sent him away empty-handed.
24678	41	12	4	 Again he sent to them another servant: and as for him, they  wounded him in the head and treated him shamefully.
24679	41	12	5	 Yet a third he sent, and him they killed. And he sent many besides, and them also they ill-treated, beating some and killing others.
24680	41	12	6	 He had still one left whom he could send, a dearly-loved son: him last of all he sent, saying, "`They will treat my son with respect.'
24681	41	12	7	 "But those men--the vine-dressers--said to one another, "`Here is the heir: come, let us kill him, and then the property will one day be ours.'
24682	41	12	8	 "So they took him and killed him, and flung  his body outside the vineyard.
24683	41	12	9	 What, therefore, will the owner of the vineyard do?" "He will come and put the vine-dressers to death," they said; "and will give the vineyard to others."
24684	41	12	10	 "Have you not read even this passage," He added, <"`The stone which the builders rejected has become the Cornerstone:
24685	41	12	11	  this Cornerstone came from the Lord, and is wonderful in our esteem?'">
24686	41	12	12	 And they kept looking out for an opportunity to seize Him, but were afraid of the people; for they saw that in this parable He had referred to *them*. So they left Him and went away.
24687	41	12	13	  Their next step was to send to Him some of the Pharisees and of Herod's partisans to entrap Him in conversation.
24688	41	12	14	 So they came to Him.  "Rabbi," they said, "we know that you are a truthful man and you do not fear any one; for you do not recognize human distinctions, but teach God's way truly. Is it allowable to pay poll-tax to Caesar, or not?
24689	41	12	15	 Shall we pay, or shall we refuse to pay?" But He, knowing their hypocrisy, replied, "Why try to ensnare me? Bring me a shilling for me to look at."
24690	41	12	16	 They brought one; and He asked them, "Whose is this likeness and this inscription?" "Caesar's," they replied.
24691	41	12	17	 "What is Caesar's," replied Jesus, "pay to Caesar--and what is God's, pay to God." And they wondered exceedingly at Him.
24692	41	12	18	  Then came to Him a party of Sadducees, a sect which denies that there is any Resurrection; and they proceeded to question Him.
24693	41	12	19	 "Rabbi," they said, "Moses made it a law for us: <`If a man's brother should die and leave a wife, but no child, the man shall marry the widow and raise up a family for his brother.'>
24694	41	12	20	 There were once seven brothers, the eldest of whom married a wife, but at his death left no family.
24695	41	12	21	 The second married her, and died, leaving no family; and the third did the same.
24696	41	12	22	 And so did the rest of the seven, all dying childless. Finally the woman also died.
24697	41	12	23	 At the Resurrection whose wife will she be? For they all seven married her."
24698	41	12	24	 "Is not this the cause of your error," replied Jesus--"your ignorance alike of the Scriptures and of the power of God?
24699	41	12	25	 For when they have risen from among the dead, men do not marry and women are not given in marriage, but they are as angels are in Heaven.
24700	41	12	26	 But as to the dead, that they  rise to life, have you never read in the Book of Moses, in the passage about the Bush, how God said to him, <`I am the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob?'>
24701	41	12	27	 He is not the God of dead, but of living men. You are in grave error."
24702	41	12	28	  Then one of the Scribes, who had heard them disputing and well knew that Jesus had given them an answer to the point, and a forcible one, came forward and asked Him, "Which is the chief of all the Commandments?"
24703	41	12	29	 "The chief Commandment," replied Jesus, "is this: <`Hear, O Israel! The Lord our God is one Lord;
24704	41	12	30	 and thou shalt love the Lord thy God  with thy whole heart, thy whole soul, thy whole mind, and thy whole strength.'>
24705	41	12	31	 "The second is this: <`Thou shalt love thy  fellow man as thou lovest thyself.'> "Other Commandment greater than these there is none."
24706	41	12	32	 So the Scribe said to Him, "Rightly, in very truth, Rabbi, have you said that <He stands alone, and there is none but He;>
24707	41	12	33	 and <To love Him with all one's heart, with all one's understanding, and with all one's strength, and to love one's fellow man no less than oneself,> is far better than all our <whole burnt-offerings and sacrifices.">
24708	41	12	34	  Perceiving that the Scribe had answered wisely Jesus said to him, "You are not far from the Kingdom of God." No one from that time forward ventured to put any question to Him.
24709	41	12	35	  But, while teaching in the Temple, Jesus asked, "How is it the Scribes say that the Christ is a son of David?
24710	41	12	36	 David himself said, taught by the Holy Spirit, <"`The Lord said to my Lord, Sit at My right hand, until  I have made thy foes a footstool under thy feet.'>
24711	41	12	37	 "David himself calls Him `Lord:' how then can He be his son?" And the mass of people found pleasure in listening to Jesus.
24712	41	12	38	  Moreover in the course of His teaching He said,  "Be on your guard against the Scribes who like to walk about in long robes and to be bowed to in places of public resort,
24713	41	12	39	 and to occupy the best seats  in the synagogues and at dinner parties,
24714	41	12	40	 and who swallow up the property of widows and then mask their wickedness by making long prayers: these men will receive far heavier punishment."
24715	41	12	41	  Having taken a seat opposite the Treasury, He observed how the people were dropping money into the Treasury, and that many of the wealthy threw in large sums.
24716	41	12	42	 But there came one poor widow and dropped in two farthings, equal in value to a halfpenny.
24717	41	12	43	 So He called His disciples to Him and said, "In solemn truth I tell you that this widow, poor as she is, has thrown in more than all the other contributors to the Treasury;
24718	41	12	44	 for they have all contributed out of what they could well spare, but she out of her need has thrown in all she possessed--all she had to live on."
24719	41	13	1	  As He was leaving the Temple, one of His disciples exclaimed, "Look,  Rabbi,  what wonderful stones!  what wonderful buildings!"
24720	41	13	2	 "You see all these great buildings?" Jesus replied;  "not one stone will be left here upon another--not thrown down."
24721	41	13	3	 He was sitting  on the Mount of Olives opposite to the Temple, when Peter, James, John, and Andrew, apart from the others asked Him,
24722	41	13	4	 "Tell us, When will these things be? and what will be the sign when all these predictions are on the point of being fulfilled?"
24723	41	13	5	 So Jesus began to say to them: "Take care that no one misleads you.
24724	41	13	6	 Many will come  assuming my name and saying, `I am He;' and they will mislead many.
24725	41	13	7	 But when you hear of wars and rumours of wars, do not be alarmed: come they must, but the End is not yet.
24726	41	13	8	 For <nation  will rise in arms against nation, and kingdom against kingdom.> There will be earthquakes in various places; there will be famines. These miseries are but like the early pains of childbirth.
24727	41	13	9	  "You yourselves must be on your guard. They will deliver you up to Sanhedrins; you will be brought into synagogues and cruelly beaten; and you will stand before governors and kings for my sake, to be witnesses to them for me.
24728	41	13	10	 But the proclamation of the Good News must be carried to all the Gentiles  before the End comes.
24729	41	13	11	 When however they are marching you along under arrest, do not be anxious beforehand about what you are to say, but speak what is given you when the time comes; for it will not be you who speak, but the Holy Spirit.
24730	41	13	12	 "Brother will betray brother to be killed, and fathers will betray children; and <children will rise against their parents> and have them put to death.
24731	41	13	13	 You will be objects of universal hatred because you are called by my name, but those who stand firm to the End will be saved.
24732	41	13	14	  "As soon, however, as you see the <Abomination of Desolation> standing where  he ought not" --let the reader observe these words--"then let those in Judaea  escape to the hills;
24733	41	13	15	 let him who is on the roof not come down and enter the house to fetch anything out of it;
24734	41	13	16	 and let not him who is in the field turn back to pick up his outer garment.
24735	41	13	17	 And alas for the women who at that time are with child or have infants!
24736	41	13	18	 "But pray that it may not come in the winter.
24737	41	13	19	 For those will be times of <suffering the like of which has never been from the  first creation of God's world until now,> and assuredly  never will be again;
24738	41	13	20	 and but for the fact that the Lord has cut short those days, no one would escape; but for the sake of His own People whom He has chosen for Himself He has cut short the days.
24739	41	13	21	  "At that time if any one says to you, `See, here is the Christ!' or `See, He is there!' do not believe it.
24740	41	13	22	 For <there will rise up> false Christs and false <prophets, displaying signs and prodigies> with a view to lead astray--if indeed that were possible--even God's own People.
24741	41	13	23	 But as for yourselves, be on your guard: I have forewarned you of everything.
24742	41	13	24	 <"At that time,> however, after that <distress, the sun will  be darkened and the moon will not shed her light;
24743	41	13	25	 the stars will be seen falling from the firmament, and the  forces which are in the heavens will be disordered and disturbed.>
24744	41	13	26	 And then will they see <the Son of Man coming in clouds> with great power and glory.
24745	41	13	27	 Then He will send forth the angels and gather together His chosen People from north, south, east and west, from the remotest parts of the earth and the sky.
24746	41	13	28	 "Learn from the fig-tree the lesson it teaches. As soon as its branch has become soft and it is bursting into leaf, you know that summer is near.
24747	41	13	29	 So also do you, when you see these things happening, be sure that  He is near, at your very door.
24748	41	13	30	 I tell you in solemn truth that  the present generation will certainly not pass away without all these things having first taken place.
24749	41	13	31	  Earth and sky will pass away, but it is certain that my words will not pass away.
24750	41	13	32	 "But as to that day or the exact time no one knows--not even the angels in Heaven, nor the Son, but the Father alone.
24751	41	13	33	 Take care, be on the alert,  and pray; for you do not know when it will happen.
24752	41	13	34	 It is like a man living abroad who has left his house, and given the management to his  servants--to each one his special duty--and has ordered the porter to keep awake.
24753	41	13	35	 Be wakeful therefore, for you know not when the master of the house is coming--in the evening, at midnight, at cock-crow, or at dawn.
24754	41	13	36	  Beware lest He should arrive unexpectedly and find you asleep.
24755	41	13	37	 Moreover, what I say to you I say to all--Be wakeful!"
24756	41	14	1	  It was now  two days before the Passover and the feast of Unleavened Bread, and the High Priests and Scribes were bent on finding how to seize Him by stratagem and put Him to death.
24757	41	14	2	 But they said, "Not on the Festival-day, for fear there should be a riot among the people."
24758	41	14	3	  Now when He was at Bethany, in the house of Simon the Leper, while He was at table, there came a woman with a jar of  pure, sweet-scented ointment very costly: she broke the jar and poured the ointment over His head.
24759	41	14	4	 But there were some who said indignantly among themselves, "Why has the ointment been thus wasted?
24760	41	14	5	 For that ointment might have been sold for  fifteen pounds or more,  and the money have been given to the poor." And they were exceedingly angry with her.
24761	41	14	6	 But Jesus said, "Leave her alone: why are you troubling her? She has done a most gracious act towards me.
24762	41	14	7	 For you always have the poor among you, and whenever you choose you can do acts of kindness to them; but me you have not always.
24763	41	14	8	 What she could she did: she has perfumed my body in preparation for my burial.
24764	41	14	9	 And I solemnly tell you that wherever in the whole world the Good News shall be proclaimed, this which she has done shall also be told in remembrance of her."
24765	41	14	10	  But Judas Iscariot,  already mentioned as one of the Twelve, went to the High Priests to betray Jesus to them.
24766	41	14	11	 They gladly listened to his proposal, and promised to give him a sum of money. So he looked out for an opportunity to betray Him.
24767	41	14	12	  On the first day of the feast of Unleavened Bread--the day for killing the Passover lamb--His disciples asked Him, "Where shall we go and prepare for you to eat the Passover?"
24768	41	14	13	 So He sent two of His disciples with instructions, saying, "Go into the city, and you will meet  a man carrying a pitcher of water: follow him,
24769	41	14	14	 and whatever house he enters, tell the master of the house, `The  Rabbi asks, Where is my  room where I can eat the Passover with my disciples?'
24770	41	14	15	 Then he will himself show you a large room upstairs, ready furnished: there make preparation for us."
24771	41	14	16	 So the disciples went out and came to the city, and found everything just as He had told them; and they got the Passover ready.
24772	41	14	17	  When it was evening, He came with the Twelve.
24773	41	14	18	  And while they were at table Jesus said, "I solemnly tell you that one of you will betray me--one who is eating with me."
24774	41	14	19	 They were filled with sorrow, and began asking Him, one by one, "Not I, is it?"
24775	41	14	20	 "It is one of the Twelve," He replied; "he who is dipping his fingers in the dish with me.
24776	41	14	21	 For the Son of Man is going His way as it is written about Him; but alas for the man by whom the Son of Man is betrayed! It had been a happy thing for that man, had he never been born."
24777	41	14	22	  Also during the meal He took a Passover biscuit, blessed it, and broke it. He then gave it to them, saying,  "Take this, it is my body."
24778	41	14	23	 Then He  took the cup, gave thanks, and handed it to them, and they all of them drank  from it.
24779	41	14	24	 "This is my blood," He said, "which is to be poured out on behalf of many--the blood  which makes  the Covenant sure.
24780	41	14	25	 I solemnly tell you that never again will I taste the produce of the vine till I shall drink the new wine in the Kingdom of God."
24781	41	14	26	  After singing  a hymn, they went out to the Mount of Olives.
24782	41	14	27	  Then said Jesus to them, "All of you are about to stumble and fall, for it is written, <`I will strike down the Shepherd, and the sheep will be scattered in all directions.'>
24783	41	14	28	 But after I have risen to life again I will go before you into Galilee."
24784	41	14	29	 "All may stumble and fall," said Peter, "yet I never will."
24785	41	14	30	 "I solemnly tell you," replied Jesus, "that to-day--this night--before the cock crows twice, you yourself will three times disown me."
24786	41	14	31	 "Even if I must die with you," declared Peter again and again, "I will never disown you." In like manner protested also all the disciples.
24787	41	14	32	  So they came to a place called Gethsemane. There He said to His disciples, "Sit down here till I have prayed."
24788	41	14	33	 Then He took with Him Peter and James and John, and began to be full of terror and distress,
24789	41	14	34	 and He said to them, "My heart is oppressed with anguish to the very point of death: wait here and keep awake."
24790	41	14	35	 Going forward a short distance He threw Himself upon His face and prayed repeatedly that, if it was possible,  He might be spared that time of agony;
24791	41	14	36	 and He said, "Abba!  my Father! all things are possible for Thee:  take this  cup of suffering away from me: and yet not what I desire, but what Thou desirest."
24792	41	14	37	 Then He came and found them asleep, and He said to Peter, "Simon, are you asleep? Had you not strength to keep awake a single hour?
24793	41	14	38	 Be wakeful, all of you, and keep on praying, that you may not come into temptation:  the spirit is right willing, but the body is frail."
24794	41	14	39	 He again went away and prayed, using the very same words.
24795	41	14	40	 When He returned He again found them asleep, for they were very tired; and they knew not how to answer Him.
24796	41	14	41	 A third time He came, and then He said, "Sleep on and rest. Enough! the hour has come. Even now they are betraying the Son of Man into the hands of sinful men.
24797	41	14	42	 Rouse yourselves, let us be going: my betrayer is close at hand."
24798	41	14	43	  Immediately, while He was still speaking,  Judas, one of the Twelve, came and with him a crowd of men armed with swords and cudgels, sent by the High Priests and Scribes and Elders.
24799	41	14	44	 Now the betrayer had arranged a signal with them. "The one I kiss," he said, "is the man: lay hold of him, and take him safely away."
24800	41	14	45	 So he came, and going straight to Jesus he said, "Rabbi!" and kissed Him with seeming affection;
24801	41	14	46	 whereupon they laid hands on Him and held Him firmly.
24802	41	14	47	 But one of those who stood by drew his sword and struck a blow at the High Priest's  servant, cutting off his ear.
24803	41	14	48	 "Have you come out," said Jesus, "with swords and cudgels to arrest me, as if you had to fight with a robber?
24804	41	14	49	 Day after day I used to be among you in the Temple teaching, and you never seized me. But  this is happening in order that the Scriptures may be fulfilled.'
24805	41	14	50	 Then His friends all forsook Him and fled.
24806	41	14	51	 One youth indeed did follow Him,  wearing only a  linen cloth round his bare body. Of him they laid hold,
24807	41	14	52	 but he left the linen cloth in their hands and fled  without it.
24808	41	14	53	  So they led Jesus away to the High Priest, and  with him there assembled all the High Priests, Elders, and Scribes.
24809	41	14	54	 Peter followed Jesus at a distance, as far as the outer court of the High Priest's palace. But there he remained sitting among the  officers, and warming himself  by the fire.
24810	41	14	55	  Meanwhile the High Priests and the entire Sanhedrin were endeavouring to get evidence against Jesus in order to put Him to death, but could find none;
24811	41	14	56	 for though many gave false testimony against Him, their statements did not tally.
24812	41	14	57	 Then some came forward as witnesses and falsely declared,
24813	41	14	58	 "We have heard him say, `I will pull down this Sanctuary built by human hands, and three days afterwards I will erect another built without hands.'"
24814	41	14	59	 But not even in this shape was their testimony consistent.
24815	41	14	60	 At last the High Priest stood up, and advancing into the midst of them all, asked Jesus, "Have you no answer to make? What is the meaning of all this that these witnesses allege against you?"
24816	41	14	61	 But He remained silent, and gave no reply. A second time the High Priest questioned Him. "Are you the Christ, the Son of the Blessed One?" he said.
24817	41	14	62	 "I am," replied Jesus, "and  you and others will see the Son of Man sitting at the right hand of the  divine Power, and coming amid the clouds of the sky."
24818	41	14	63	 Rending his garments the High Priest exclaimed, "What need have we of witnesses after that?
24819	41	14	64	 You all heard his impious words. What is your judgement?" Then with one voice they condemned Him as deserving of death.
24820	41	14	65	 Thereupon some began to spit on Him, and to blindfold Him, while striking Him with their fists and crying,  "Prove that you are a prophet." The  officers too  struck Him with  open hands as they took Him in charge.
24821	41	14	66	 Now while Peter was below in the quadrangle, one of the High Priest's maidservants came,
24822	41	14	67	 and seeing Peter warming himself she looked at him and said, "You also were with Jesus, the Nazarene."
24823	41	14	68	 But he denied it, and said,  "I don't know--I don't understand--What do you mean?" And then he went out into the outer court.  Just then a cock crowed.
24824	41	14	69	 Again the maidservant saw him, and again began to say to the people standing by, "He is one of them."
24825	41	14	70	 A second time he repeatedly denied it. Soon afterwards the bystanders again accused Peter, saying, "You are surely one of them, for you too are a Galilaean."
24826	41	14	71	 But he broke out into curses and oaths, declaring, "I know nothing of the man you are talking about."
24827	41	14	72	 No sooner had he spoken than a cock crowed for the second time, and Peter recollected the words of Jesus, "Before the cock crows twice, you will three times disown me." And as he thought of it, he  wept aloud.
24828	41	15	1	 At earliest dawn, after the High Priests had held a consultation with the Elders and Scribes, they and the entire Sanhedrin bound Jesus and took Him away and handed Him over to Pilate.
24829	41	15	2	  So Pilate questioned Him. "Are *you* the King of the Jews?" he asked. "I am," replied Jesus.
24830	41	15	3	 Then, as the High Priests went on heaping accusations on Him,
24831	41	15	4	 Pilate again and again asked Him, "Do you make no reply? Listen to the many charges they are bringing against you."
24832	41	15	5	 But Jesus made no further answer: so that Pilate wondered.
24833	41	15	6	  Now at the Festival it was customary for Pilate to release to the Jews any one prisoner whom they might beg off from punishment;
24834	41	15	7	 and at this time a man named Barabbas was in prison among the insurgents--persons who in the insurrection had committed murder.
24835	41	15	8	 So the people came crowding up, asking Pilate to grant them the usual favour.
24836	41	15	9	 "Shall I release for you the King of the Jews?" answered Pilate.
24837	41	15	10	 For he could see that it was out of sheer spite that the High Priests had handed Him over.
24838	41	15	11	 But the High Priests urged on the crowd to obtain Barabbas's release in preference;
24839	41	15	12	 and when Pilate again asked them, "What then shall I do to the man you call King of the Jews?"
24840	41	15	13	 they once more shouted out, "Crucify Him!"
24841	41	15	14	  "Why, what crime has he committed?" asked Pilate. But they vehemently shouted, "Crucify Him!"
24842	41	15	15	 So Pilate, wishing to satisfy the mob, released Barabbas for them, and after scourging Jesus handed Him over for crucifixion.
24843	41	15	16	  Then the soldiers led Him away into the court of the Palace (the Praetorium), and calling together the whole battalion
24844	41	15	17	 they arrayed Him in crimson, placed on His head a wreath of thorny twigs which they had twisted,
24845	41	15	18	 and went on to salute Him with shouts of "Long live the King of the Jews."
24846	41	15	19	 Then they began to beat Him on the head with a  cane, to spit on Him, and to do Him homage on bended knees.
24847	41	15	20	 At last, having finished their sport, they took the robe off Him, put His own clothes on Him, and led Him out to crucify Him.
24848	41	15	21	  One Simon, a Cyrenaean, the father of Alexander and Rufus, was passing along, coming from the country: him they compelled to carry His cross.
24849	41	15	22	 So they brought Him to the place called Golgotha, which, being translated, means `Skull-ground.'
24850	41	15	23	 Here they offered Him wine mixed with myrrh; but He refused it.
24851	41	15	24	  Then they crucified Him. This done, they divided His garments among them, drawing lots to decide what each should take.
24852	41	15	25	 It was nine o'clock in the morning when they crucified Him.
24853	41	15	26	 Over His head was the notice in writing of the charge against Him: THE KING OF THE JEWS.
24854	41	15	27	 And together with Jesus they crucified two robbers, one at His right hand and one at His left.
24855	41	15	28	  []
24856	41	15	29	  And all the passers-by reviled Him. They shook their heads at Him and said, "Ah! you who were for destroying the Sanctuary and building a new one in three days,
24857	41	15	30	 come down from the cross and save yourself."
24858	41	15	31	 In the same way the High Priests also, as well as the Scribes, kept on scoffing at Him, saying to one another, "He has  saved others:  himself he cannot save!
24859	41	15	32	 This Christ, the King of Israel, let him come down now from the cross, that we may see and believe." Even the men who were being crucified with Him heaped insults on Him.
24860	41	15	33	  At noon there came a darkness over the whole land, lasting till three o'clock in the afternoon.
24861	41	15	34	 But at three o'clock Jesus cried out with a loud voice, <"Elohi, Elohi, lama sabachthani?"> which means, "My God, My God, <why hast Thou forsaken me?">
24862	41	15	35	 Some of the bystanders, hearing Him, said, "Listen, he is calling for Elijah!"
24863	41	15	36	 Then a man ran to fill a sponge with  sour wine, and he put it on the end of a cane and placed it to His lips, saying at the same time, "Wait! let us see whether Elijah will come and take him down."
24864	41	15	37	 But Jesus uttered a loud cry and yielded up His spirit.
24865	41	15	38	  And the curtain in the Sanctuary  was torn in two, from top to bottom.
24866	41	15	39	 And when the  Centurion who stood in front of the cross saw that He was dead, he exclaimed, "This man was indeed God's Son."
24867	41	15	40	 There were also a party of women looking on from a distance; among them being both Mary of Magdala and Mary the mother of James the Little and of Joses, and Salome--
24868	41	15	41	 all of whom in the Galilaean days  had habitually been with Him and cared for Him, as well as many other women who had come up to Jerusalem with Him.
24869	41	15	42	  Towards sunset, as it was the Preparation--that is, the day preceding the Sabbath--
24870	41	15	43	 Joseph of Arimathaea came, a  highly respected member of the  Council, who himself also was living in expectation of the Kingdom of God. He summoned up courage to go in to see Pilate and beg for the body of Jesus.
24871	41	15	44	 But Pilate could hardly believe that He was already dead. He called, however, for the Centurion and inquired whether He had been long dead;
24872	41	15	45	 and having ascertained the fact he granted the body to Joseph.
24873	41	15	46	 He, having bought a sheet of linen, took Him down, wrapped Him in the sheet and laid Him in a tomb hewn in the rock; after which he rolled a stone against the entrance to the tomb.
24874	41	15	47	 Mary of Magdala and Mary the mother of Joses were looking on to see where He was put.
24875	41	16	1	  When the Sabbath was over, Mary of Magdala, Mary the mother of James, and Salome, bought spices, in order to come and anoint  His body.
24876	41	16	2	 So, very soon after sunrise on the first day of the week, they came to the tomb;
24877	41	16	3	 and they were saying to one another, `Who will roll away the stone for us from the entrance to the tomb?"
24878	41	16	4	 But then, looking up, they saw that the stone was already rolled back:  for it was of immense size.
24879	41	16	5	  Upon entering the tomb, they saw a young man sitting at their right hand, clothed in a long white robe. They were astonished and terrified.
24880	41	16	6	 But he said to them, "Do not be terrified. It is Jesus you are looking for--the Nazarene who has been crucified. He has  come back to life: He is not here: this is the place where they laid Him.
24881	41	16	7	 But go and tell His disciples and Peter that He is going before you into Galilee: and that there you will see Him, as He told you."
24882	41	16	8	  So they came out, and fled from the tomb, for they were greatly agitated and surprised; and they said not a word to any one, for they were afraid.
24883	41	16	9	  [But He rose to life early on the first day of the week, and appeared first to Mary of Magdala from whom He had expelled seven demons.
24884	41	16	10	 She went and brought the tidings to those who had been with Him, as they were mourning and weeping.
24885	41	16	11	 But they, when they were told that He was alive and that she had seen Him, could not believe it.
24886	41	16	12	  Afterwards He showed Himself in another form to two of them as they were walking, on their way into the country.
24887	41	16	13	 These, again, went and told the news to the rest; but not even them did they believe.
24888	41	16	14	  Later still He showed Himself to the Eleven themselves whilst they were at table, and He upbraided them with their unbelief and obstinacy in not having believed those who had seen Him alive.
24889	41	16	15	  Then He said to them, "Go the whole world over, and proclaim the Good News to all  mankind.
24890	41	16	16	 He who believes and is baptized shall be saved, but he who disbelieves will be condemned.
24891	41	16	17	 And signs shall attend those who believe, even such as these. By making use of my name they shall expel demons. They shall speak  new languages.
24892	41	16	18	 They shall take up venomous snakes, and if they drink any deadly poison it shall do them no harm whatever. They shall lay their hands on the sick, and the sick shall recover."
24893	41	16	19	  So the Lord  Jesus after having thus spoken to them was taken up into Heaven, and sat down at the right hand of God.
24894	41	16	20	 But they went out and made proclamation everywhere, the Lord working with them and confirming their Message by the signs which accompanied it.]
24895	42	1	1	 Seeing that many have attempted to draw up a narrative of the facts which are  received with full assurance among us
24896	42	1	2	 on the authority of those who were from the beginning eye-witnesses and were devoted to  the service of the divine Message,
24897	42	1	3	 it has seemed right to me also, after careful investigation of the facts from their commencement, to write for you, most noble Theophilus, a connected account,
24898	42	1	4	 that you may fully know the truth of the things which you have been taught by word of mouth.
24899	42	1	5	 There was in the time of Herod, the king of Judaea, a priest of the name of  Zechariah, belonging to the class of  Abijah. He had a wife who was a descendant of Aaron, and her name was  Elizabeth.
24900	42	1	6	 They were both of them upright before God, blamelessly obeying all the Lord's precepts and ordinances.
24901	42	1	7	 But they had no child, because Elizabeth was barren; and both of them were far advanced in life.
24902	42	1	8	 Now while he was doing priestly duty before God in the prescribed course of his class,
24903	42	1	9	 it fell to his lot--according to the custom of the priesthood--to go into the Sanctuary of the Lord and burn the incense;
24904	42	1	10	 and the whole multitude of the people were outside praying, at the hour of incense.
24905	42	1	11	 Then there appeared to him an angel of the Lord standing on the right side of the altar of incense;
24906	42	1	12	 and Zechariah on seeing him was  agitated and terrified.
24907	42	1	13	 But the angel said to him,  "Do not be afraid, Zechariah, for your petition has been heard: and your wife Elizabeth will bear you a son, and you are to call his name John.
24908	42	1	14	 Gladness and exultant joy shall be yours, and many will rejoice over his birth.
24909	42	1	15	 For he will be great in the sight of the Lord; no wine or fermented drink shall he ever drink; but he will be filled with the Holy Spirit from the very hour of his birth.
24910	42	1	16	 Many of the descendants of Israel will he turn to the Lord their God;
24911	42	1	17	 and he will be His forerunner in the spirit and power of Elijah, to turn fathers' hearts to the children, and cause the rebellious to walk in the wisdom of the upright, to make a people perfectly ready for the lord."
24912	42	1	18	 "By what proof," asked Zechariah, "shall I know this? For I am an old man, and my wife is far advanced in years."
24913	42	1	19	 "I am Gabriel, who stand in the presence of God," answered the angel, "and I have been sent to talk with you and tell you this good news.
24914	42	1	20	 And now you will be dumb and unable to speak until the day when this has taken place; because you did not believe my words--words which will be fulfilled at their appointed time."
24915	42	1	21	 Meanwhile the people were waiting for Zechariah, and were surprised that he stayed so long in the Sanctuary.
24916	42	1	22	 When, however, he came out, he was unable to speak to them; and they knew that he must have seen a vision in the Sanctuary; but he kept making signs to them and continued dumb.
24917	42	1	23	 When his days of service were at an end, he went to his home;
24918	42	1	24	 and in course of time his wife Elizabeth conceived, and kept herself secluded five months.
24919	42	1	25	 "Thus has the Lord dealt with me," she said, "now that He has  graciously taken away my reproach among men."
24920	42	1	26	 Now in the sixth month the angel Gabriel was sent from God to a town in Galilee called  Nazareth,
24921	42	1	27	 to a maiden betrothed to a man of the name of Joseph, a descendant of David. The maiden's name was  Mary.
24922	42	1	28	 So Gabriel went into the house and said to her, "Joy be to you, favoured one! the Lord is  with you."
24923	42	1	29	 She was greatly  agitated at his words, and wondered what such a greeting meant.
24924	42	1	30	 But the angel said,  "Do not be frightened, Mary, for you have found favour with God.
24925	42	1	31	 You will conceive in your womb and bear a son; and you are to call His name  JESUS.
24926	42	1	32	 He will be great and He will be called `Son of the Most High.' And the Lord God will give Him the throne of His forefather David;
24927	42	1	33	 and He will be King over the House of Jacob for the Ages, and of His Kingdom there will be no end."
24928	42	1	34	 "How can this be," Mary replied, "seeing that I have no husband?"
