27267	44	10	7	 So when the angel who had been speaking to him was gone, Cornelius called two of his  servants and a God-fearing soldier who was in constant attendance on him,
27268	44	10	8	 and, after telling them everything, he sent them to Jaffa.
27269	44	10	9	 The next day, while they were still on their journey and were getting near the town, about noon Peter went up on the house-top to pray.
27270	44	10	10	 He had become unusually hungry and wished for food; but, while they were preparing it, he fell into a trance.
27271	44	10	11	 The sky had opened to his view, and what seemed to be an enormous sail was descending, being let down to the earth by ropes at the four corners.
27272	44	10	12	 In it were  all kinds of quadrupeds, reptiles and birds,
27273	44	10	13	 and a voice came to him which said, "Rise, Peter, kill and eat."
27274	44	10	14	 "On no account, Lord," he replied; "for I have never yet eaten anything unholy and impure."
27275	44	10	15	 Again a second time a voice was heard which said, "What God has purified, you must not regard as unholy."
27276	44	10	16	 This  was said three times, and immediately the sail was drawn up  out of sight.
27277	44	10	17	 While Peter was greatly perplexed as to the meaning of the vision which he had seen, just then the men sent by Cornelius, having by inquiry found out Simon's house,
27278	44	10	18	 had come to the door and had called the servant, and were asking, "Is Simon, surnamed Peter, staying here?"
27279	44	10	19	 And Peter was still earnestly thinking over the vision, when the Spirit said to him,  "Three men are now inquiring for you.
27280	44	10	20	 Rise, go down, and go with them without any misgivings; for it is I who have sent them to you."
27281	44	10	21	 So Peter went down and said to the men, "I am the Simon you are inquiring for. What is the reason of your coming?"
27282	44	10	22	 Their reply was, "Cornelius, a Captain, an upright and God-fearing man, of whom the whole Jewish nation speaks well, has been divinely instructed by a holy angel to send for you to come to his house and listen to what you have to say."
27283	44	10	23	 Upon hearing this, Peter invited them in, and gave them a lodging. The next day he set out with them, some of the brethren from Jaffa going with him,
27284	44	10	24	 and the day after that they reached Caesarea. There Cornelius was awaiting their arrival, and had invited all his relatives and intimate friends to be present.
27285	44	10	25	 When Peter entered the house, Cornelius met him, and threw himself at his feet to do him homage.
27286	44	10	26	 But Peter lifted him up. "Stand up," he said; "I myself also am but a man."
27287	44	10	27	 So Peter went in and conversed with him, and found a large company assembled.
27288	44	10	28	 He said to them,  "You know better than most that a Jew  is strictly forbidden to associate with a Gentile or visit him; but God has taught me to call no one unholy or unclean.
27289	44	10	29	 So for this reason, when sent for, I came without raising any objection. I therefore ask why you sent for me."
27290	44	10	30	 "Just at this hour,  three days ago," replied Cornelius, "I was offering afternoon prayer in my house, when suddenly a man in shining raiment stood in front of me,
27291	44	10	31	 who said, "`Cornelius, your prayer has been heard, and your charities have been put on record before God.
27292	44	10	32	 Send therefore to Jaffa, and invite Simon, surnamed Peter, to come here. He is staying as a guest in the house of Simon, a tanner, close to the sea.'
27293	44	10	33	 "Immediately, therefore, I sent to you, and  I thank you heartily for having come. That is why all of us are now assembled here in God's presence, to listen to what the Lord has commanded you to say."
27294	44	10	34	 Then Peter began to speak. "I clearly see," he said, "that  God makes no distinctions between one man and another;
27295	44	10	35	 but that in every nation those who fear Him and live good lives are acceptable to Him.
27296	44	10	36	 The Message which He sent to the descendants of Israel, when He announced the Good News of peace through Jesus Christ--He is Lord of all--that Message  you cannot but know;
27297	44	10	37	 the story, I mean, which has spread through the length and breadth of Judaea, beginning in Galilee after the baptism which John proclaimed.
27298	44	10	38	 It tells how God  anointed Jesus of Nazareth with the  Holy Spirit and with power, so that He went about everywhere doing acts of kindness, and curing all who were being continually oppressed by the Devil--for God was with Jesus.
27299	44	10	39	 "And we are witnesses as to all that He did both in the country of the Jews and in Jerusalem. But they even put Him to death,  by crucifixion.
27300	44	10	40	 That same Jesus God raised to life on the third day, and permitted Him to appear unmistakably,
27301	44	10	41	 not to all the people, but to witnesses--men previously chosen by God--namely, to us, who ate and drank with Him after He rose from the dead.
27302	44	10	42	 And He has commanded us to preach to the people and solemnly declare that this is He who has been appointed by God to be the Judge of  the living and the dead.
27303	44	10	43	 To Him all the Prophets bear witness, and testify that through His name all who  believe in Him receive the forgiveness of their sins."
27304	44	10	44	 While Peter  was speaking these words, the Holy Spirit fell on all who were listening to the Message.
27305	44	10	45	 And all the  Jewish believers who had come with Peter were astonished that on the Gentiles also the gift of the Holy Spirit was poured out.
27306	44	10	46	 For they heard them speaking in tongues and extolling the majesty of God. Then Peter  said,
27307	44	10	47	 "Can any one forbid the use of water, and object to these persons being baptized--men who have received the Holy Spirit just as we did?"
27308	44	10	48	 And  he directed  that they should be baptized in the name of Jesus Christ. Then they begged him to remain with them for a time.
27309	44	11	1	 Now the Apostles, and the brethren  in various parts of Judaea, heard that the Gentiles also had received God's Message;
27310	44	11	2	 and, when Peter returned to Jerusalem, the champions of circumcision found fault with him.
27311	44	11	3	 "You went into the houses of men who are not Jews," they said, "and you ate with them."
27312	44	11	4	 Peter, however, explained the whole matter to them from the beginning.
27313	44	11	5	 "While I was in the town of Jaffa, offering prayer," he said, "in a trance I saw a vision. There descended what seemed to be an enormous sail, being let down from the sky by ropes at the four corners, and it came close to me.
27314	44	11	6	 Fixing my eyes on it, I examined it closely, and saw various kinds of quadrupeds, wild beasts, reptiles and birds.
27315	44	11	7	 I also heard a voice saying to me, "`Rise, Peter, kill and eat.'
27316	44	11	8	 "`On no account, Lord,' I replied, `for nothing unholy or impure has ever gone into my mouth.'
27317	44	11	9	 "But a voice answered, speaking a second time from the sky, "`What God has purified, you must not regard as unholy.'
27318	44	11	10	 "This was said three times, and then everything was drawn up again out of sight.
27319	44	11	11	 "Now at that very moment three men came to the house where we were, having been sent from Caesarea to find me.
27320	44	11	12	 And the Spirit told me to accompany them  without any misgivings. There also went with me these six brethren who are now present, and we reached the  Centurion's house.
27321	44	11	13	 Then he described to us how he had seen  the angel come and  enter his house and say, "`Send to Jaffa and fetch Simon, surnamed Peter.
27322	44	11	14	 He will teach you truths by which you and all your family will be saved.'"
27323	44	11	15	 "And," said Peter, "no sooner had I begun to speak than the Holy Spirit fell upon them, just as He fell upon us at the first.
27324	44	11	16	 Then I remembered the Lord's words, how He used to say, "`John baptized with water, but you shall be baptized in the Holy Spirit.'
27325	44	11	17	 "If therefore God gave them the  same gift as He gave us when we  first believed on the Lord Jesus Christ, why, who was I to be able to thwart God?"
27326	44	11	18	 This statement of Peter's silenced his opponents. They extolled the goodness of God, and said, "So, then, to the Gentiles also God has given the repentance which leads to Life."
27327	44	11	19	 Those, however, who had been driven in various directions by the persecution which broke out on account of Stephen made their way to Phoenicia, Cyprus and Antioch, delivering the Message to none but Jews.
27328	44	11	20	 But some of them were Cyprians and Cyrenaeans, who, on coming to Antioch, spoke to the  Greeks also and told them the Good News concerning the Lord Jesus.
27329	44	11	21	 The  power of the Lord was with them, and there were a vast number who believed and turned to the Lord.
27330	44	11	22	 When tidings of this reached the ears of the Church in Jerusalem, they sent Barnabas as far as Antioch.
27331	44	11	23	 On getting there he was delighted to see the grace which God had bestowed; and he  encouraged them all to remain, with fixed resolve, faithful to the Lord.
27332	44	11	24	 For he was a good man, and was full of the Holy Spirit and of faith; and the number of believers in the Lord greatly increased.
27333	44	11	25	 Then Barnabas paid a visit to Tarsus to try to find Saul.
27334	44	11	26	 He succeeded, and brought him to Antioch; and for a whole year they attended the meetings of the Church, and taught a large number of people. And it was in Antioch that the disciples first received the name of `Christians.'
27335	44	11	27	 At  that time certain Prophets came down from Jerusalem to Antioch,
27336	44	11	28	 one of whom, named Agabus, being instructed by the Spirit,  publicly predicted the speedy coming of a great famine throughout the world. (It came in the reign of Claudius.)
27337	44	11	29	 So the disciples decided to send relief, every one in proportion to his means, to the brethren living in Judaea.
27338	44	11	30	 This they did, forwarding their contributions to the  Elders by Barnabas and Saul.
27339	44	12	1	 Now, about that time, King Herod arrested certain members of the Church, in order to ill-treat them;
27340	44	12	2	 and James, John's brother, he beheaded.
27341	44	12	3	 Finding that this gratified the Jews, he proceeded to seize Peter also; these being the days of Unleavened Bread.
27342	44	12	4	 He had him arrested and lodged in jail, handing him over to the care of  sixteen soldiers; and intended after the Passover to bring him out again to the people.
27343	44	12	5	 So Peter was kept in prison; but long and fervent prayer was offered to God by the Church on his behalf.
27344	44	12	6	 Now when Herod was on the point of taking him out of prison, that very night Peter was asleep between two soldiers, bound with two chains, and  guards were  on duty outside the door.
27345	44	12	7	 Suddenly an angel of the Lord stood by him, and a light shone in the cell; and, striking Peter on the side, he woke him and said, "Rise quickly." Instantly the chains dropped off his wrists.
27346	44	12	8	 "Fasten your girdle," said the angel, "and tie on your sandals." He did so. Then the angel said, "Throw your cloak round you, and follow me."
27347	44	12	9	 So Peter went out, following him, yet could not believe that what the angel was doing was real, but supposed that he saw a vision.
27348	44	12	10	 And passing through  the first ward and the second, they came to the iron gate leading into the city. This opened to them of itself; and, going out, they passed on through one of the streets, and then suddenly the angel left him.
27349	44	12	11	 Peter coming to himself said, "Now I know for certain that the Lord has sent His angel and has rescued me from the power of Herod and from all that the Jewish people were anticipating."
27350	44	12	12	 So, after thinking things over, he went to the house of Mary, the mother of John surnamed Mark, where a large number of people were assembled, praying.
27351	44	12	13	 When he knocked at the  wicket in the door, a maidservant named  Rhoda came to answer the knock;
27352	44	12	14	 and recognizing Peter's voice, for very joy she did not open the door, but ran in and told them that Peter was standing there.
27353	44	12	15	 "You are mad," they said. But she strenuously maintained that it was true. "It is his  guardian angel," they said.
27354	44	12	16	 Meanwhile Peter went on knocking, until at last they opened the door and saw that it was really he, and were filled with amazement.
27355	44	12	17	 But he motioned with his hand for silence, and then described to them how the Lord had brought him out of the prison. "Tell all this to James and the brethren," he added. Then he left them, and went to another place.
27356	44	12	18	 When morning came, there was no little commotion among the soldiers, as to what could possibly have become of Peter.
27357	44	12	19	 And when Herod had had him searched for and could not find him, after sharply questioning the guards he ordered them away to execution. He then went down from Judaea to Caesarea and remained there.
27358	44	12	20	 Now the people of Tyre and Sidon had incurred Herod's violent displeasure. So they sent a large deputation to wait on him; and having secured the good will of Blastus, his treasurer, they begged the king  to be friendly with them again, because their country was dependent on his for its food supply.
27359	44	12	21	 So, on an appointed day, Herod, having arrayed himself in royal robes, took his seat on the tribunal, and was haranguing them;
27360	44	12	22	 and the assembled people kept shouting, "It is the voice of a god, and not of a man!"
27361	44	12	23	 Instantly an angel of the Lord struck him, because he had not given the glory to God, and being eaten up by worms, he  died.
27362	44	12	24	 But God's Message prospered, and converts were multiplied.
27363	44	12	25	 And Barnabas and Saul returned from Jerusalem, having discharged their mission, and they brought with them John, surnamed Mark.
27364	44	13	1	 Now there were in Antioch,  in the Church there--as Prophets and teachers--barnabas,  Symeon surnamed `the black,' Lucius the Cyrenaean, Manaen  (who was Herod the Tetrarch's foster-brother), and Saul.
27365	44	13	2	 While they were worshipping the Lord and fasting, the Holy Spirit said, "Set apart for Me, now at once, Barnabas and Saul, for the work to which I have called them."
27366	44	13	3	 So, after fasting and prayer and the laying on of hands, they let them go.
27367	44	13	4	 They therefore, being thus sent out by the Holy Spirit, went  down to Seleuceia, and from there sailed to Cyprus.
27368	44	13	5	 Having reached Salamis, they began to announce God's Message in the synagogues of the Jews. And they had John as their  assistant.
27369	44	13	6	 When they had gone through the whole length of the island as far as Paphos, they there met with a Jewish magician and false prophet,  Bar-Jesus by name,
27370	44	13	7	 who was a friend of the Proconsul Sergius Paulus. The Proconsul was a man of keen intelligence. He sent for Barnabas and Saul, and asked to be told God's Message.
27371	44	13	8	 But  Elymas (or `the Magician,' for such is the meaning of the name) opposed them, and tried to  prevent the Proconsul from accepting the faith.
27372	44	13	9	 Then Saul, who is also called Paul, was filled with the Holy Spirit, and, fixing his eyes on Elymas,
27373	44	13	10	 said, "You who are full of every kind of craftiness and unscrupulous cunning--you son of the Devil and foe to all that is right--will you never cease  to misrepresent the straight paths of the Lord?
27374	44	13	11	 The Lord's hand is now upon you, and you will be blind for a time and unable to see the light of day." Instantly there fell upon him a mist and a darkness, and, as he walked about, he begged people to lead him  by the hand.
27375	44	13	12	 Then the Proconsul, seeing what had happened, believed, being struck with amazement at  the teaching of the Lord.
27376	44	13	13	 From Paphos, Paul and his party put out to sea and sailed to Perga in Pamphylia. John, however, left them and returned to Jerusalem.
27377	44	13	14	 But they themselves, passing through from Perga, came to Antioch in Pisidia. Here, on the Sabbath day, they went into the synagogue and sat down.
27378	44	13	15	 After the reading of the Law and the Prophets, the Wardens of the synagogue sent word to them. "Brethren," they said, "if you have anything encouraging to say to the people, speak."
27379	44	13	16	 So Paul rose, and motioning with his hand for silence, said, "Israelites, and you others who fear God, pay attention to me.
27380	44	13	17	 The God of this people of Israel chose our forefathers, and made the people great during their stay in Egypt, until with  wondrous power He brought them out from that land.
27381	44	13	18	 For a period of about forty years, He  fed them, like a nurse, in the Desert.
27382	44	13	19	 Then, after overthrowing seven nations in the land of Canaan, He divided that country among them as their inheritance for about four hundred and fifty years;
27383	44	13	20	 and afterwards He gave them judges down to the time of the Prophet Samuel.
27384	44	13	21	 Next they asked for a king, and God gave them Saul the son of Kish, a Benjamite, who reigned forty years.
27385	44	13	22	 After removing him, He raised up David to be their king, to whom He also bore witness when He said, "`I have found David the son of Jesse, a man I love, who will obey all My commands.'
27386	44	13	23	 "It is from among David's descendants that God, in fulfilment of His promise, has raised up a Saviour for Israel, even Jesus.
27387	44	13	24	 Before the coming of Jesus, John had proclaimed to all the people of Israel a baptism of repentance.
27388	44	13	25	 But John, towards the end of his career, repeatedly asked the people, "`What do you suppose me to be? I am not the Christ. But there is One coming after me whose sandal I am not worthy to unfasten.'
27389	44	13	26	 "Brethren, descendants of the family of Abraham, and all among you who fear God, to us has this Message of salvation been sent.
27390	44	13	27	 For the people of Jerusalem and their rulers,  by the judgement they pronounced on Jesus, have actually fulfilled the predictions of the Prophets which are read Sabbath after Sabbath, through ignorance of those predictions and of Him.
27391	44	13	28	 Without having found Him guilty of any capital offence they urged Pilate to have Him put to death;
27392	44	13	29	 and when they had carried out everything which had been written about Him, they took Him down from the  cross and laid Him in a tomb.
27393	44	13	30	 "But God raised Him from the dead.
27394	44	13	31	 And, after a few days, He appeared to the people who had gone up with Him from Galilee to Jerusalem and are now witnesses concerning Him to the Jews.
27395	44	13	32	 And we bring you the Good News about the promise made to our forefathers,
27396	44	13	33	 that God has amply fulfilled it to our children in  raising up Jesus; as it is also written in  the second Psalm, <`Thou art My Son: to-day I have become Thy Father.'>
27397	44	13	34	 And as to His having raised Him from among the dead, never again to be in the position of one soon to return to decay, He  speaks thus: <`I will give you the holy and trustworthy promises made to David.'>
27398	44	13	35	 Because in another Psalm also He says, <`Thou wilt not  give up Thy Holy One to undergo decay.'>
27399	44	13	36	 For David,  after having been useful to his own generation in accordance with God's purpose, did fall asleep, was gathered to his forefathers, and did undergo decay.
27400	44	13	37	 But He whom God raised to life underwent no decay.
27401	44	13	38	 "Understand therefore, brethren, that through this Jesus forgiveness of sins is announced to you;
27402	44	13	39	 and in Him every believer is absolved from all offences, from which you could not be absolved under the Law of Moses.
27403	44	13	40	 Beware, then, lest what is spoken in the Prophets should come true of you:
27404	44	13	41	 <`Behold, you despisers, be astonished and perish, because I am carrying on a work in your time--a work which you will utterly refuse to believe, though it be fully declared to you.'">
27405	44	13	42	 As  Paul and Barnabas were leaving the synagogue, the people earnestly begged to have all this repeated to them on the following Sabbath.
27406	44	13	43	 And, when the congregation had broken up, many of the Jews and of the devout converts from heathenism continued with Paul and Barnabas, who talked to them and urged them to hold fast to the grace of God.
27407	44	13	44	 On the next Sabbath almost the whole population of the city came together to hear the Lord's Message.
27408	44	13	45	 Seeing the crowds, the Jews, filled with angry jealousy, opposed Paul's statements and abused him.
27409	44	13	46	 Then, throwing off all reserve, Paul and Barnabas said, "We were bound to proclaim God's Message to you first. But since you spurn it and judge yourselves to be unworthy of the Life  of the Ages--well, we turn to the Gentiles.
27410	44	13	47	 For such is the Lord's command to us. <"`I have placed Thee,'> He says of Christ, <`as a light to the Gentiles, in order that Thou mayest be a Saviour as far as the remotest parts of the earth.'">
27411	44	13	48	 The Gentiles listened with delight and extolled the Lord's Message; and all who were pre-destined to the Life of the Ages believed.
27412	44	13	49	 So the Lord's Message spread through the whole district.
27413	44	13	50	 But the Jews influenced the gentlewomen of rank who worshipped with them, and also the leading men in the city, and stirred up persecution against Paul and Barnabas and drove them out of the district.
27414	44	13	51	 But they shook off the dust from their feet as a protest against them and came to Iconium;
27415	44	13	52	 and as for the disciples, they were  more and more filled with joy and with the Holy Spirit.
27416	44	14	1	 At Iconium the Apostles went  together to the Jewish synagogue and preached, with the result that a great number both of Jews and Greeks believed.
27417	44	14	2	 But the Jews who  had refused  obedience stirred up the Gentiles and embittered their minds against the brethren.
27418	44	14	3	 Yet Paul and Barnabas remained there for a considerable time, speaking freely and relying on the Lord, while He bore witness to the Message of His grace by permitting signs and marvels to be done by them.
27419	44	14	4	 At length the people of the city  split into parties, some siding with the Jews and some with the Apostles.
27420	44	14	5	 And when a hostile movement was made by both Gentiles and Jews, with the sanction of their magistrates, to maltreat and stone them,
27421	44	14	6	 the Apostles, having become aware of it, made their escape into the Lycaonian towns of Lystra and Derbe, and the neighbouring country.
27422	44	14	7	 And there they continued to tell the Good News.
27423	44	14	8	 Now a man who had no power in his feet used to sit in the streets of Lystra. He had been lame from his birth and  had never walked.
27424	44	14	9	  After this man had listened to one of Paul's sermons, the Apostle, looking steadily at him and perceiving that he had faith to be cured,
27425	44	14	10	 said in a loud voice, "Stand upright upon your feet!"
27426	44	14	11	 So he sprang up and began to walk about. Then the crowds, seeing what Paul had done, rent the air with their shouts in the Lycaonian language, saying, "The gods have assumed human form and have come down to us."
27427	44	14	12	 They called Barnabas `Zeus,' and Paul, as being the principal speaker, `Hermes.'
27428	44	14	13	 And the priest of Zeus--the temple of Zeus being at the entrance to the city--brought bullocks and garlands to  the gates, and in company with the crowd was intending to offer sacrifices to them.
27429	44	14	14	 But the Apostles, Barnabas and Paul, heard of it; and tearing their clothes they rushed out into the middle of the crowd, exclaiming, "Sirs, why are you doing all this?
27430	44	14	15	 We also are but men, with  natures kindred to your own; and we bring you the Good News that you are to turn from these unreal things, to worship the ever-living God, the Creator of earth and sky and sea and of everything that is in them.
27431	44	14	16	 In times gone by He allowed all the nations to go their own ways;
27432	44	14	17	 and yet by His beneficence He has not left His existence unattested--His beneficence, I mean, in sending you rain from Heaven and fruitful seasons, satisfying your hearts with food and joyfulness."
27433	44	14	18	 Even with words like these they had difficulty in preventing the thronging crowd from offering sacrifices to them.
27434	44	14	19	 But now a party of Jews came from Antioch and Iconium, and, having won over the crowd, they stoned Paul and dragged him out of the town, believing him to be dead.
27435	44	14	20	 When, however, the disciples had collected round him, he rose and went back into the town. The next day he went with Barnabas to Derbe;
27436	44	14	21	 and, after proclaiming the Good News to the people there and gaining a large number of converts, they retraced their steps to Lystra, Iconium, and Antioch.
27437	44	14	22	 Everywhere they strengthened the disciples by encouraging them to hold fast to the faith, and warned them saying, "It is through many afflictions that we must make our way into the Kingdom of God."
27438	44	14	23	 And in every Church, after prayer and fasting, they  selected Elders  by show of hands, and commended them to the Lord on whom their faith rested.
27439	44	14	24	 Then passing through Pisidia they came into Pamphylia;
27440	44	14	25	 and after telling the Message at Perga they came down to Attaleia.
27441	44	14	26	 Thence they sailed to Antioch, where they had previously been commended to the grace of God in connexion with the work which they had now completed.
27442	44	14	27	 Upon their arrival they called the Church together and proceeded to report in detail all that God, working with them, had done, and how He had opened for the Gentiles the door of faith.
27443	44	14	28	 And they remained a considerable time in Antioch with the disciples.
27444	44	15	1	 But certain persons who had come down from Judaea tried to convince the brethren, saying, "Unless you are circumcised in accordance with the Mosaic custom, you cannot be saved."
27445	44	15	2	 Between these new comers and Paul and Barnabas there was no little disagreement and controversy, until at last it was decided that Paul and Barnabas and some other brethren should go up to consult the Apostles and Elders in Jerusalem on this matter.
27446	44	15	3	 So they set out, being accompanied for a short distance by some other members of the Church; and as they passed through Phoenicia and Samaria, they told the whole story of the conversion of the Gentiles and inspired all the brethren with great joy.
27447	44	15	4	 Upon their arrival in Jerusalem they were cordially received by the Church, the Apostles, and  the Elders; and they reported in detail all that God, working with them, had done.
27448	44	15	5	 But certain men who had belonged to the sect of the Pharisees but were now believers, stood up in the assembly, and said, "Yes, Gentile believers ought to be circumcised and be ordered to keep the Law of Moses."
27449	44	15	6	 Then the Apostles and Elders met to consider the  matter;
27450	44	15	7	 and after there had been a long discussion Peter rose to his feet. "It is within  your own knowledge," he said, "that God  originally made choice among you that from my lips the Gentiles were to hear the Message of the Good News, and believe.
27451	44	15	8	 And God, who knows all hearts, gave His testimony in their favour by bestowing the Holy Spirit on them just as He did on us;
27452	44	15	9	 and He made no difference between us and them, in that He cleansed their hearts by their faith.
27453	44	15	10	 Now, therefore, why try an experiment upon God,  by laying on the necks of these disciples a yoke which neither our forefathers nor we have been able to bear?
27454	44	15	11	 On the contrary, we believe that it is by the grace of the Lord Jesus that we, as well as they, shall be saved."
27455	44	15	12	 Then the whole assembly  remained silent while they listened to the statement made by Paul and Barnabas as to all the signs and marvels that God had done among the Gentiles through their instrumentality.
27456	44	15	13	 When they had finished speaking, James said, "Brethren, listen to me.
27457	44	15	14	  Symeon has related how God first looked graciously on the Gentiles to take from among them a People to be called by His name.
27458	44	15	15	 And this is in harmony with the language of the Prophets, which says:
27459	44	15	16	 <"`"Afterwards I will return, and will rebuild David's fallen tent. Its ruins I will rebuild, and I will set it  up again;
27460	44	15	17	 In order that the rest of mankind may earnestly seek the Lord--even all the nations which are called by My name,"
27461	44	15	18	 Says the Lord,  who has been making these things known  from ages long past.'>
27462	44	15	19	 "My judgement, therefore, is against inflicting  unexpected annoyance on those of the Gentiles who are turning  to God.
27463	44	15	20	 Yet let us send them written instructions to abstain from  things polluted by connexion with idolatry, from fornication, from meat killed by strangling, and from blood.
27464	44	15	21	 For Moses from  the earliest times  has had his preachers in every town, being read, as he is, Sabbath after Sabbath, in the various synagogues."
27465	44	15	22	 Thereupon it was decided by the Apostles and Elders, with the approval of the whole Church, to choose suitable persons from among themselves and send them to Antioch, with Paul and Barnabas. Judas, called Bar-sabbas, and Silas, leading men among the brethren, were selected,
27466	44	15	23	 and they took with them the following letter: "The Apostles and the elder brethren send greeting to the Gentile brethren throughout Antioch, Syria and Cilicia.
27467	44	15	24	 As we have been informed that certain persons who have gone out from among us have disturbed you by their teaching and have unsettled your minds, without having received any such instructions from us;
27468	44	15	25	 we have  unanimously decided to select certain men and send them to you in company with our dear friends Barnabas and Paul,
27469	44	15	26	 who have endangered their very lives for the sake of our Lord Jesus Christ.
27470	44	15	27	 We have therefore sent Judas and Silas, who are themselves bringing you the same message by word of mouth.
27471	44	15	28	 For it has seemed good to the Holy Spirit and to us to lay upon you no burden heavier than these necessary requirements--
27472	44	15	29	 You must abstain from things sacrificed to idols, from blood, from things strangled, and from fornication. Keep yourselves clear of these things, and it will be well with you. Farewell."
27473	44	15	30	 They, therefore, having been solemnly sent, came down to Antioch, where they called together the whole assembly and delivered the letter.
27474	44	15	31	 The people  read it, and were delighted with the comfort it brought them.
27475	44	15	32	 And Judas and Silas, being themselves also  Prophets, gave  them a long and encouraging talk, and strengthened them in the faith.
27476	44	15	33	 After spending some time there they received an affectionate farewell from the brethren to return to those who had sent them.
27477	44	15	34	  []
27478	44	15	35	 But Paul and Barnabas remained in Antioch, teaching and, in company with many others, telling the Good News of the Lord's Message.
27479	44	15	36	 After a while Paul said to Barnabas, "Suppose we now revisit the brethren in the various towns in which we have made known the Lord's Message--to see whether they are prospering!"
27480	44	15	37	 Barnabas, however, was bent on taking with them John, whose other name was Mark,
27481	44	15	38	 while Paul deemed it undesirable to have as their companion one who had deserted them in Pamphylia and had not gone on with them to the work.
27482	44	15	39	 So there arose a serious disagreement between them, which resulted in their parting from one another, Barnabas taking Mark and setting sail for Cyprus.
27483	44	15	40	 But Paul chose Silas as his travelling companion; and set out, after being commended by the brethren to the grace of the Lord;
27484	44	15	41	 and he passed through Syria and Cilicia, strengthening the Churches.
27485	44	16	1	 He also came to Derbe and to Lystra. At Lystra he found a disciple, Timothy by name--the son of  a Christian Jewess, though he had a Greek father.
27486	44	16	2	 Timothy was well spoken of by the brethren at Lystra and Iconium,
27487	44	16	3	 and Paul desiring that he should accompany him on his journey, took him and circumcised him on account of the Jews in those parts, for they all knew that his father was a Greek.
27488	44	16	4	 As they journeyed on from town to town, they handed to the brethren for their observance the decisions which had been arrived at by the Apostles and Elders in Jerusalem.
27489	44	16	5	 So the Churches went on gaining a stronger faith and growing in numbers from day to day.
27490	44	16	6	 Then  Paul and his companions passed through  Phrygia and Galatia, having been forbidden by the Holy Spirit to proclaim the Message in the province of Asia.
27491	44	16	7	 When they reached the frontier of Mysia, they were about to enter Bithynia, but the Spirit of Jesus would not permit this.
27492	44	16	8	 So,  passing along Mysia, they came to  Troas.
27493	44	16	9	 Here, one night, Paul saw a vision. There was a Macedonian who was standing, entreating him and saying, "Come over into Macedonia and help us."
27494	44	16	10	 So when he had seen the vision, we immediately looked out for an opportunity of passing on into Macedonia, confidently inferring that God had called us to proclaim the Good News to the people there.
27495	44	16	11	 Accordingly we put out to sea from Troas, and ran a straight course to Samothrace. The next day we came to Neapolis,
27496	44	16	12	 and thence to Philippi,  which is a city in Macedonia, the first in its district, a Roman colony. And there we stayed some little time.
27497	44	16	13	 On the Sabbath we went beyond the city gate to the riverside, where we had reason to believe that there was a place for prayer; and sitting down we talked with the women who had come together.
27498	44	16	14	 Among our hearers was one named Lydia, a dealer in purple goods. She belonged to the city of Thyateira, and was a worshipper  of the true God. The Lord opened her heart, so that she gave attention to what Paul was saying.
27499	44	16	15	 When she and her household had been baptized, she urged us, saying, "If  in your judgement I am a believer in the Lord, come and stay at my house." And she made us go there.
27500	44	16	16	 One day, as we were on our way to the place of prayer, a slave girl met us who  claimed to be inspired and was accustomed to bring her owners large profits by telling fortunes.
27501	44	16	17	 She kept following close behind Paul and the rest of us, crying aloud, "These men are the bondservants of the Most High God, and are proclaiming to you the way of salvation."
27502	44	16	18	 This she persisted in  for a considerable time, until Paul,  wearied out, turned round and said to the spirit, "I command you in the name of Jesus Christ to come out of her." And it came out  immediately.
27503	44	16	19	 But when her owners saw that their hopes of gain were gone, they seized Paul and Silas and dragged them off to the  magistrates in the public square.
27504	44	16	20	 Then they brought them before the praetors. "These men," they said, "are creating a great disturbance in our city.
27505	44	16	21	 They are Jews, and are teaching customs which we, as Romans, are not permitted to adopt or practise."
27506	44	16	22	 The crowd, too,  joined in the outcry against them, till at length the praetors  ordered them to be stripped and beaten with rods;
27507	44	16	23	 and, after severely flogging them, they threw them into jail and bade the jailer keep them safely.
27508	44	16	24	 He, having received an order like that, lodged them in the inner prison, and secured their feet in the stocks.
27509	44	16	25	 About midnight Paul and Silas were praying and singing hymns to God, and the prisoners were listening to them,
27510	44	16	26	 when suddenly there was such a violent shock of earthquake that the prison shook to its foundations. Instantly the doors all flew open, and the chains  fell off from every prisoner.
27511	44	16	27	 Starting up from sleep and seeing the doors of the jail wide open, the jailer drew his sword and was on the point of killing himself, supposing that the prisoners had escaped.
27512	44	16	28	 But Paul shouted loudly to him, saying, "Do yourself no injury: we are all here.
27513	44	16	29	 Then, calling for lights, he sprang in and fell trembling at the feet of Paul and Silas;
27514	44	16	30	 and, bringing them out of the prison, he exclaimed, "O sirs, what must I do to be saved?"
27515	44	16	31	 "Believe on the Lord Jesus," they replied, "and both you and your household will be saved."
27516	44	16	32	 And they told  the Lord's Message to him as well as to all who were in his house.
27517	44	16	33	 Then he took them, even at that time of night, washed their wounds, and he and all his household were immediately baptized;
27518	44	16	34	 and bringing the Apostles up into his house, he spread a meal for them, and was filled with gladness,  with his whole household,  his faith resting on God.
27519	44	16	35	 In the morning the praetors sent their lictors with the order, "Release those men."
27520	44	16	36	 So the jailer brought Paul word, saying, "The praetors  have sent orders for you to be released. Now therefore you can go, and proceed on your way in peace."
27521	44	16	37	 But Paul said to them, "After  cruelly beating us in public, without trial, Roman citizens though we are, they have thrown us into prison, and are they now going to send us away privately?  No, indeed! Let them come in person and fetch us out."
27522	44	16	38	 This answer the lictors took back to the praetors, who were alarmed when they were told that Paul and Silas were Roman citizens.
27523	44	16	39	 Accordingly they came and  apologized to them; and, bringing them out, asked them to leave the city.
27524	44	16	40	 Then Paul and Silas, having come out of the prison, went to Lydia's house; and, after seeing the brethren and encouraging them, they left Philippi.
27525	44	17	1	 Then, passing through Amphipolis and Apollonia, they went to Thessalonica. Here there was a synagogue of the Jews.
27526	44	17	2	 Paul--following his usual custom--betook himself to it, and  for three successive Sabbaths reasoned with them from the Scriptures,
27527	44	17	3	 which he clearly explained, pointing out that it had been necessary for the Christ to suffer and rise again from the dead, and insisting, "The Jesus whom I am announcing to you is the Christ."
27528	44	17	4	 Some of the people were won over, and  attached themselves to Paul and Silas, including many  God-fearing Greeks and not a few gentlewomen of high rank.
27529	44	17	5	 But the jealousy of the Jews was aroused, and, calling to their aid some ill-conditioned and idle fellows, they got together a riotous mob and filled the city with uproar. They then attacked the house of Jason and searched for Paul and Silas, to bring them out before the assembly of people.
27530	44	17	6	 But, failing to find them, they dragged Jason and some of the other brethren before the  magistrates of the city, loudly accusing them. "These men," they said, "who have raised a tumult throughout the Empire, have come here also.
27531	44	17	7	 Jason has received them into his house; and they all set Caesar's  authority at defiance, declaring that there is another  Emperor--  one called Jesus."
27532	44	17	8	 Great was the excitement among the crowd, and among the magistrates of the city, when they heard these charges.
27533	44	17	9	 They required Jason and the rest to find substantial bail, and after that they let them go.
27534	44	17	10	 The brethren at once sent Paul and Silas away by night to Beroea, and they, on their arrival, went to the synagogue of the Jews.
27535	44	17	11	 The Jews at Beroea were of a nobler disposition than those in Thessalonica, for they very readily received the Message, and day after day searched the Scriptures to see whether  it was as Paul stated.
27536	44	17	12	 As the result many of them became believers, and so did not a few of the Greeks--gentlewomen of good position, and men.
27537	44	17	13	 As soon, however, as the  Jews of Thessalonica learnt that God's Message  had been proclaimed by Paul at Beroea, they came there also, and incited the mob to a riot.
27538	44	17	14	 Then the brethren promptly sent Paul down to the sea-coast, but Silas and Timothy remained behind.
27539	44	17	15	 Those who were caring for Paul's safety went with him as far as Athens, and then left him, taking a message from him to Silas and Timothy, asking them to join him as speedily as possible.
27540	44	17	16	 While Paul was waiting for them in Athens, his spirit  was stirred within him when he noticed that the city was full of idols.
27541	44	17	17	 So he  had discussions in the synagogue with the Jews and the other  worshippers, and in the market place, day after day, with those whom he happened to meet.
27542	44	17	18	 A few of the Epicurean and Stoic  philosophers also  encountered him. Some of them asked, "What has this  beggarly babbler to say?" "His business," said others, "seems to be to cry up some foreign gods." This was because he had been telling the Good News of Jesus and the  Resurrection.
27543	44	17	19	 Then they  took him and brought him up to  the Areopagus, asking him, "May we be told what this new teaching of yours is?
27544	44	17	20	 For the things you are saying sound strange to us. We should therefore like to be told exactly what they mean."
27545	44	17	21	 (For all the Athenians and their foreign visitors used to devote their whole leisure to telling or hearing about something new.)
27546	44	17	22	 So Paul, taking his stand in the centre of the Areopagus, spoke as follows:  "Men of Athens, I perceive that you are in every respect remarkably religious.
27547	44	17	23	 For as I passed along and observed the things you worship, I found also an altar bearing the inscription,  `TO AN UNKNOWN GOD.'  "The Being, therefore, whom you, without knowing Him, revere, Him I now proclaim to you.
27548	44	17	24	 GOD who made the universe and everything in it--He, being Lord of Heaven and earth, does not dwell in sanctuaries built by men.
27549	44	17	25	 Nor is He ministered to by human hands, as though He needed anything--but He Himself gives to all men life and breath and all things.
27550	44	17	26	  He caused to spring  from one forefather people of every race, for them to live on the whole surface of the earth, and marked out for them an appointed span of life and the boundaries of their homes;
27551	44	17	27	  that they might seek God, if perhaps they could grope for Him and find Him. Yes, though He is not far from any one of us.
27552	44	17	28	 For it is in closest union with Him that we live and move and have our being; as in fact some of the poets in repute among yourselves have said, `For we are also His offspring.'
27553	44	17	29	 Since then we are God's offspring, we ought not to imagine that His nature resembles gold or silver or marble, or anything sculptured by the art and inventive faculty of man.
27554	44	17	30	 Those times of ignorance God viewed with indulgence. But now He commands all men everywhere to repent,
27555	44	17	31	 seeing that He has appointed a day on which, before long, He will judge  the world in righteousness,  through the instrumentality of a man whom He has pre-destined to this work, and has made the fact certain to every one by raising Him from the dead."
27556	44	17	32	 When they heard Paul speak of a resurrection of dead men, some began to scoff. But others said, "We will hear you again on that subject."
27557	44	17	33	 So Paul went away from them.
27558	44	17	34	 A few, however, attached themselves to him and believed, among them being Dionysius a member of the Council, a gentlewoman named Damaris, and some others.
27559	44	18	1	 After this he left Athens and came to Corinth.
27560	44	18	2	 Here he found a Jew,  a native of Pontus, of the name of Aquila. He and his wife Priscilla had recently come from Italy because of Claudius's edict expelling all the Jews from Rome. So Paul paid them a visit;
27561	44	18	3	 and because he was of the same trade--that of  tent-maker--he lodged with them  and worked with them.
27562	44	18	4	 But, Sabbath after Sabbath, he preached in the synagogue and tried to win over both Jews and Greeks.
27563	44	18	5	 Now at the time when Silas and Timothy came down from Macedonia, Paul was preaching fervently and was solemnly telling the Jews that Jesus is the Christ.
27564	44	18	6	 But upon their opposing him with abusive language, he shook his clothes by way of protest, and said to them, "Your ruin will be upon your own heads. I am not responsible: in future I will go among the Gentiles."
27565	44	18	7	 So he left the place and went to the house of a person called Titius Justus, a worshipper of the true God. His house was next door to the synagogue.
27566	44	18	8	 And Crispus, the Warden of the synagogue, believed in the Lord, and so did all his household; and  from time to time many of the Corinthians who heard Paul believed and received baptism.
27567	44	18	9	 And, in a vision by night, the Lord said to Paul, "Dismiss your fears: go on speaking, and do not give up.
27568	44	18	10	 I am with you, and no one shall attack you to injure you; for I have very many people in this city."
27569	44	18	11	 So Paul remained in Corinth for a year and six months, teaching among them the Message of God.
27570	44	18	12	 But when Gallio became Proconsul of Greece, the Jews with one accord made a dead set at Paul, and brought him before the court.
27571	44	18	13	 "This man," they said, "is inducing people to offer unlawful worship to God."
27572	44	18	14	 But, when Paul was about to begin his defence, Gallio said to the Jews, "If it had been some wrongful act or piece of cunning knavery I might reasonably have listened to you Jews.
27573	44	18	15	 But since these are questions about words and names and your Law, you yourselves must see to them. I refuse to be a judge in such matters."
27574	44	18	16	 So he ordered them out of court.
27575	44	18	17	 Then the people all set upon Sosthenes, the Warden of  the synagogue, and beat him  severely in front of the court. Gallio did not concern himself in the least about this.
27576	44	18	18	 After remaining a considerable time longer in Corinth, Paul took leave of the brethren and set sail for Syria; and Priscilla and Aquila were with him.  He had shaved his head at Cenchreae, because he was bound by a vow.
27577	44	18	19	 They put in at Ephesus, and there Paul left his companions behind. As for himself, he went to the synagogue and  had a discussion with the Jews.
27578	44	18	20	 When they asked him to remain longer he did not consent,
27579	44	18	21	 but took leave of them with the promise, "I will return to you, God willing." So he set sail from Ephesus.
27580	44	18	22	 Landing at Caesarea, he went up to Jerusalem and inquired after the welfare of the Church, and then went down to Antioch.
27581	44	18	23	 After spending some time in Antioch, Paul set out on a tour, visiting the whole of Galatia and Phrygia in order, and strengthening all the disciples.
27582	44	18	24	 Meanwhile a Jew named Apollos came to Ephesus. He was a native of Alexandria,  a man of great learning and well versed in the Scriptures.
27583	44	18	25	 He had been instructed by word of mouth in the way of the Lord, and, being full of burning zeal, he used to speak and teach accurately the facts about Jesus, though he knew of no baptism but John's.
27584	44	18	26	 He began to speak boldly in the synagogue, and Priscilla and Aquila, after hearing him, took him home and explained  God's way to him more accurately.
27585	44	18	27	 Then, as he had made up his mind to cross over into Greece, the brethren wrote to the disciples in Corinth begging them to give him a kindly welcome. Upon his arrival he rendered valuable help to those who through grace had believed;
27586	44	18	28	 for he powerfully and in public overcame the Jews in argument, proving to them from the Scriptures that Jesus is the Christ.
27587	44	19	1	 During the stay of Apollos in Corinth, Paul, after passing through the inland districts, came to Ephesus, where he found a few disciples.
27588	44	19	2	 "Did you receive the Holy Spirit when you  first believed?" he asked them. "No," they replied, "we did not even hear that there is a Holy Spirit."
27589	44	19	3	  "Into what then were you baptized?" he asked.  "Into John's baptism," they replied.
27590	44	19	4	 "John," he said, "administered a baptism  of repentance, bidding the people believe on One who was to come after him; namely, on Jesus."
27591	44	19	5	 On hearing this, they were baptized  into the name of the Lord Jesus;
27592	44	19	6	 and when Paul laid his hands upon them, the Holy Spirit came on them, and they began to speak in tongues and  to prophesy.
27593	44	19	7	 They numbered in all about twelve men.
27594	44	19	8	 Afterwards he went into the synagogue. There for three months he continued to preach fearlessly, explaining in words which carried conviction the truths which concern the Kingdom of God.
27595	44	19	9	 But some grew obstinate in unbelief and spoke evil of  the new faith before all the congregation. So Paul left them, and,  taking with him those who were disciples, held discussions daily in Tyrannus's lecture-hall.
27596	44	19	10	 This went on for two years, so that  all the inhabitants of the province of Asia, Jews as well as Greeks, heard the Lord's Message.
27597	44	19	11	 God also brought about extraordinary miracles through Paul's instrumentality.
27598	44	19	12	  Towels or aprons, for instance, which Paul had handled used to be carried to the sick, and they recovered from their ailments,  or the evil spirits left them.
27599	44	19	13	 But there were also some wandering Jewish exorcists who undertook to invoke the name of Jesus over those who had the evil spirits, saying, "I command you by that Jesus whom Paul preaches."
27600	44	19	14	 There were seven sons of one Sceva, a Jew of high-priestly family, who were doing this.
27601	44	19	15	 "Jesus I know," the evil spirit answered, "and Paul  I have heard of, but who are you?"
27602	44	19	16	 And the man in whom the evil spirit was sprang on two of them, over-mastered them both, and treated them with such violence, that they fled from the house stripped of their clothes and wounded.
27603	44	19	17	 All the people of Ephesus, Jews as well as Greeks, came to know of this. There was widespread terror, and they  began to hold the name of the Lord Jesus in high honour.
27604	44	19	18	 Many also of those who  believed  came confessing without reserve what their conduct had been,
27605	44	19	19	 and not a few of those who had practised magical arts brought their books together and  burnt them in the presence of all. The total value was reckoned and found to be  50,000 silver coins.
27606	44	19	20	 Thus mightily did the Lord's Message spread and triumph!
27607	44	19	21	 When matters had reached this point, Paul decided in his own  mind to travel through Macedonia and Greece, and go to Jerusalem. "After that," he said, "I must also see Rome."
27608	44	19	22	 But he sent two of  his assistants, Timothy and Erastus, to Macedonia, while he himself remained for a while in Roman Asia.
27609	44	19	23	 Now just at that time there arose no small commotion about  the new faith.
27610	44	19	24	 There was a certain Demetrius, a silversmith, who made miniature silver sanctuaries of  Diana, a business which brought great gain to the mechanics in his employ.
27611	44	19	25	 He called his workmen together, and others who were engaged in similar trades, and said to them, "You men well know that our prosperity depends on this business of ours;
27612	44	19	26	 and you see and hear that, not in Ephesus only but throughout almost the whole province of Asia, this fellow Paul has led away a vast number of people by inducing them to believe that they are not gods at all that are made by men's hands.
27613	44	19	27	 There is danger,  therefore, not only that this our trade will become of no account, but also that the  temple of the great goddess Diana will fall into utter disrepute, and that before long she will be actually deposed from her majestic rank--she who is now worshipped by the whole province of Asia; nay, by the whole world."
27614	44	19	28	 After listening to this harangue, they became furiously angry and kept calling out, "Great is the Ephesian Diana!"
27615	44	19	29	 The riot and uproar spread through the whole city, till at last with one accord they rushed into  the Theatre, dragging with them Gaius and Aristarchus, two Macedonians who were fellow travellers with Paul.
27616	44	19	30	 Then Paul would have liked to go in and address the people, but the disciples would not let him do so.
27617	44	19	31	 A few of the  public officials, too, who were friendly to him, sent repeated messages entreating him not to venture into the Theatre.
27618	44	19	32	 The people, meanwhile, kept shouting,  some one thing and some another; for the assembly was all uproar and confusion, and the greater part had no idea why they had come together.
27619	44	19	33	 Then some of the people  crowded round Alexander, whom the Jews had pushed forward; and Alexander, motioning with his hand to get silence, was prepared to make a defence to the people.
27620	44	19	34	 No sooner, however, did they see that he was a Jew, than there arose from them all one roar of shouting, lasting about two hours. "Great is the Ephesian Diana," they said.
27621	44	19	35	 At length the  Recorder quieted them down. "Men of Ephesus," he said, "who is there of all mankind that needs to be told that the city of Ephesus is the guardian of the temple of the great Diana and of the image which fell down from Zeus?
27622	44	19	36	 These facts, then, being unquestioned, it becomes you to maintain your self-control and not act recklessly.
27623	44	19	37	 For you have brought these men here, who are neither robbers of temples nor blasphemers of our goddess.
27624	44	19	38	 If, however, Demetrius and the mechanics who support his contention have a grievance against any one,  there are Assize-days and there are Proconsuls: let the persons interested accuse one another.
27625	44	19	39	 But if you desire  anything further, it will have to be settled in the regular assembly.
27626	44	19	40	 For in connexion with to-day's proceedings there is danger of our being charged with attempted insurrection, there having been no real reason for this riot; nor shall we be able to justify the behaviour of this disorderly mob."
27627	44	19	41	 With these words he dismissed the assembly.
27628	44	20	1	 When the uproar had ceased, Paul sent for the disciples; and, after speaking words of encouragement to them, he took his leave, and started for Macedonia.
27629	44	20	2	 Passing through those districts he encouraged the disciples in frequent addresses, and then came into  Greece, and spent three months there.
27630	44	20	3	 The Jews having planned to waylay him whenever he might be on the point of taking ship for Syria, he decided to travel back by way of Macedonia.
27631	44	20	4	 He was accompanied as far as the province of Asia by Sopater the Beroean, the son of Pyrrhus; by the Thessalonians, Aristarchus and Secundus; by Gaius of Derbe, and Timothy; and by the Asians, Tychicus and Trophimus.
27632	44	20	5	 These brethren had gone on and were waiting for us in the Troad.
27633	44	20	6	 But we ourselves sailed from Philippi after the days of Unleavened Bread, and five days later joined them in the Troad, where we remained for a week.
27634	44	20	7	 On the first day of the week, when we had met to break bread, Paul, who was going away the next morning, was preaching to them, and prolonged his discourse till midnight.
27635	44	20	8	 Now there were a good many lamps in the room upstairs where we all were,
27636	44	20	9	 and a youth of the name of Eutychus was sitting at the window. This lad, gradually sinking into deep sleep while Paul preached at unusual length, overcome at last by sleep, fell from the second floor and was taken up dead.
27637	44	20	10	 Paul, however, went down, threw himself upon him, and folding him in his arms said,  "Do not be alarmed; his life is still in him."
27638	44	20	11	 Then he went  upstairs again, broke bread, and took some food; and after a long conversation which was continued till daybreak, at last he parted from them.
27639	44	20	12	 They had taken the lad home alive, and were greatly comforted.
27640	44	20	13	 The rest of us had already gone on board a ship, and now we set sail for Assos, intending to take Paul on board there; for so he had arranged, he himself intending to go by land.
27641	44	20	14	 Accordingly, when he met us at Assos, we took him on board and came to Mitylene.
27642	44	20	15	 Sailing from there, we arrived the next day  off Chios. On the next we touched at  Samos; and on the day following reached Miletus.
27643	44	20	16	 For Paul's plan was to sail past Ephesus, so as not to spend much time in the province of Asia; since he was very desirous of being in Jerusalem, if possible, on the day of the  Harvest Festival.
27644	44	20	17	 From Miletus he sent to Ephesus for the  Elders of the Church to come to him.
27645	44	20	18	 Upon their arrival he said to them, "You Elders well know, from the first day of my setting foot in the province of Asia, the kind of life I lived among you the whole time,
27646	44	20	19	 serving the Lord  in all humility, and  with  tears, and  amid trials which came upon me through the plotting of the Jews--
27647	44	20	20	 and that I never shrank from declaring to you anything that was profitable, or from teaching you in public and in your homes,
27648	44	20	21	 and urging upon both Jews and Greeks the necessity of turning to God and of believing in Jesus  our Lord.
27649	44	20	22	 "And now,  impelled by a sense of duty, I am on my way to Jerusalem, not knowing what will happen to me there,
27650	44	20	23	 except that the Holy Spirit, at town after town, testifies to me that imprisonment and suffering are awaiting me.
27651	44	20	24	 But even  the sacrifice of my life I count as nothing, if only I may perfect my earthly course, and be faithful to the  duty which the Lord Jesus has entrusted to me of proclaiming, as of supreme importance, the Good News of God's grace.
27652	44	20	25	 "And now, I know that none of you among whom I have gone in and out proclaiming the coming of the Kingdom will any longer see my face.
27653	44	20	26	 Therefore I protest to you to-day that I am not responsible for the ruin of any one of you.
27654	44	20	27	 For I have not shrunk from declaring to you God's whole  truth.
27655	44	20	28	 "Take heed to yourselves and to all the flock among which the Holy Spirit has  placed you to take the oversight  for Him and act as shepherds to  the Church of God, which He has bought with His own blood.
27656	44	20	29	 I know that, when I am gone, cruel wolves will come among you and will not spare the flock;
27657	44	20	30	 and that from among your own selves men will rise up who will seek with their perverse talk to draw away the disciples after them.
27658	44	20	31	 Therefore be on the alert; and remember that, night and day, for three years, I never ceased admonishing every one, even with tears.
27659	44	20	32	 "And now I commend you to God and to the word of His grace. He is able to build you up and to give you your inheritance among His people.
27660	44	20	33	 No one's silver or gold or clothing  have I coveted.
27661	44	20	34	 You yourselves know that  these hands of mine have provided for my own necessities and for the people with me.
27662	44	20	35	 In all things I have set you an example, showing you that, by working as I do, you ought to help the weak, and to bear in mind the words of the Lord Jesus, how He Himself said, "`It is more blessed to give than to receive.'"
27663	44	20	36	 Having spoken thus, Paul knelt down and prayed with them all;
27664	44	20	37	 and with loud lamentation they all threw their arms round his neck, and kissed him  lovingly,
27665	44	20	38	 grieved above all things at his having told them that  after that day they were no longer to see his face. And they went with him to the ship.
27666	44	21	1	 When, at last, we had torn ourselves away and had set sail, we ran in a straight course to Cos; the next day to Rhodes, and from there to Patara.
27667	44	21	2	 Finding a ship bound for Phoenicia, we went on board and put to sea.
27668	44	21	3	 After sighting Cyprus and leaving that island on our left, we continued our voyage to Syria and put in at Tyre; for there the ship was to unload her cargo.
27669	44	21	4	 Having searched for the disciples and found them, we stayed at Tyre for seven days; and, taught by the Spirit, they repeatedly urged Paul not to proceed to Jerusalem.
27670	44	21	5	 When, however, our time was up, we left and went on our way, all the disciples and their wives and children coming to see us off. Then, after kneeling down on the beach and praying,
27671	44	21	6	 we took leave of one another; and we went on board, while they returned home.
27672	44	21	7	 As for us, our voyage was over when having sailed from Tyre we reached Ptolemais. here we inquired after the welfare of the brethren, and remained a day with them.
27673	44	21	8	 On the morrow  we left Ptolemais and  went on to Caesarea, where we came to the house of Philip the Evangelist, who was one of the seven, and stayed with him.
27674	44	21	9	 Now Philip had four unmarried daughters who were prophetesses;
27675	44	21	10	 and  during our somewhat lengthy stay a Prophet of the name of Agabus came down from Judaea.
27676	44	21	11	 When he arrived he took Paul's  loincloth, and bound his own feet and arms with it, and said, "Thus says the Holy Spirit, `So will the Jews in Jerusalem bind the owner of this loincloth, and will hand him over to the Gentiles.'"
27677	44	21	12	 As soon as we heard these words, both we and the brethren at Caesarea entreated Paul not to go up to Jerusalem.
27678	44	21	13	 His reply was, "What can you mean by thus breaking my heart with your grief? Why, as for me, I am ready not only to go to Jerusalem and be put in chains, but even to die there for the sake of the Lord Jesus."
27679	44	21	14	 So when he was not to be dissuaded, we ceased remonstrating with him and said, "The Lord's will be done!"
27680	44	21	15	 A few days afterwards we loaded our baggage-cattle and continued our journey to Jerusalem.
27681	44	21	16	 Some of the disciples from Caesarea also joined our party, and  brought with them Mnason, a Cyprian, one of the early disciples, at whose house we were to lodge.
27682	44	21	17	 At length we reached Jerusalem, and there the brethren gave us a hearty welcome.
27683	44	21	18	 On the following day we went with Paul to call on James, and all the Elders of the Church came also.
27684	44	21	19	 After exchanging friendly greetings, Paul told in detail all that God had done among the Gentiles through his instrumentality.
27685	44	21	20	 And they, when they had heard his statement, gave the glory to God. Then they said, "You see, brother,  how many tens of thousands of Jews there are among those who have accepted the faith, and they are all zealous upholders of the Law.
27686	44	21	21	 Now what they have been repeatedly told about you is that you teach all the Jews among the Gentiles to abandon Moses, and that you forbid them to circumcise their children or observe old-established customs.
27687	44	21	22	 What then ought you to do? They are sure to hear that you have come to Jerusalem;
27688	44	21	23	 so do this which we now tell you. We have four men here who have a vow resting on them.
27689	44	21	24	 Associate with these men and purify yourself with them, and pay their expenses so that they can shave their heads. Then everybody will know that there is no truth in these stories about you, but that in your own actions you yourself  scrupulously obey the Law.
27690	44	21	25	 But as for the Gentiles who have accepted the faith, we have communicated to them our decision  that they are carefully to abstain from anything sacrificed to an idol, from blood, from what is strangled, and from fornication."
27691	44	21	26	 So Paul associated with the men; and the next day,  having purified himself with them, he  went into the Temple, giving  every one to understand that the days of their purification were finished, and there he remained  until the sacrifice for each of them was offered.
27692	44	21	27	 But, when the seven days were nearly over, the Jews from the province of Asia, having seen Paul in the Temple, set about rousing the fury of all the people against him.
27693	44	21	28	 They laid hands on him, crying out, "Men of Israel, help! help! This is the man who goes everywhere preaching to everybody against the Jewish people and the Law and this place. And besides, he has even brought Gentiles into the Temple and has desecrated this holy place."
27694	44	21	29	 (For they had previously seen Trophimus the Ephesian with him in the city, and imagined that Paul had brought him into the Temple.)
27695	44	21	30	 The excitement spread through the whole city, and the people rushed in crowds to the Temple, and there laid hold of Paul and began to drag him out; and the Temple gates were immediately closed.
27696	44	21	31	 But while they were trying to kill Paul, word was taken up to the Tribune in command of the battalion, that all Jerusalem was in a ferment.
27697	44	21	32	 He instantly sent for a few soldiers and their officers, and came down among the people with all speed. At the sight of the Tribune and the troops they ceased beating Paul.
27698	44	21	33	 Then the Tribune, making his way to him, arrested him, and, having ordered him to be secured with two chains, proceeded to ask who he was and what he had been doing.
27699	44	21	34	 Some of the crowd shouted one accusation against Paul and some another, until, as the uproar made it impossible for the truth to be ascertained with certainty, the Tribune ordered him to be brought into the barracks.
27700	44	21	35	 When Paul was going up the steps, he had to be carried by the soldiers because of the violence of the mob;
27701	44	21	36	 for the whole mass of the people pressed on in the rear, shouting, "Away with him!"
27702	44	21	37	 When he was about to be taken into the barracks, Paul said to the Tribune, "May I speak to you?" "Do you know Greek?" the Tribune asked.
27703	44	21	38	 "Are you not the Egyptian who some years ago excited the riot of the 4,000  cut-throats, and led them out into the Desert?"
27704	44	21	39	 "I am a Jew," replied Paul, "belonging to Tarsus in Cilicia, and am a citizen of no unimportant city. Give me leave, I pray you, to speak to the people."
27705	44	21	40	 So with his permission Paul stood on the steps and motioned with his hand to the people to be quiet; and when there was perfect silence he addressed them in Hebrew.
27706	44	22	1	 "Brethren and fathers," he said, "listen to my defence which I now make before you."
27707	44	22	2	 And on hearing him address them in Hebrew, they kept all the more quiet; and he said,
27708	44	22	3	 "I am a Jew, born at Tarsus in Cilicia, but brought up in this city. I was carefully trained at the feet of Gamaliel in the Law of our forefathers, and, like all of you to-day, was zealous for God.
27709	44	22	4	 I persecuted to death this new faith, continually binding both men and women and throwing them into prison;
27710	44	22	5	 as the High Priest also and all the Elders can bear me witness. It was, too, from them that I received letters to the brethren in Damascus, and I was already on my way to Damascus, intending to bring those also who had fled there, in chains to Jerusalem, to be punished.
27711	44	22	6	 "But on my way, when I was now not far from Damascus, about noon a sudden blaze of light from Heaven shone round me.
27712	44	22	7	 I fell to the ground and heard a voice say to me, "`Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting Me?'
27713	44	22	8	 "`Who art thou, Lord?' I asked. "`I am Jesus, the Nazarene,' He replied, `whom you are persecuting.'
27714	44	22	9	 "Now the men who were with me, though they saw the light, did not hear the  words of Him who spoke to me.
27715	44	22	10	 And I asked, "`What am I to do, Lord?' "And the Lord said to me, "`Rise, and go into Damascus. There you shall be told of all that has been appointed for you to do.'
27716	44	22	11	 "And as I could not see because the light had been so dazzling, those who were with me had to lead me by the arm, and so I came to Damascus.
27717	44	22	12	 "And a certain Ananias, a pious man who obeyed the Law and bore a good character with all the Jews of the city,
27718	44	22	13	 came to me and standing at my side said, "`Brother Saul, recover your sight.' "I instantly  regained my sight and looked up at him.
27719	44	22	14	 Then he said, `The God of our forefathers has appointed you to know His will, and to see the righteous One and hear Him speak.
27720	44	22	15	 For you shall be a witness for Him, to all men, of what  you have seen and heard.
27721	44	22	16	 And now why delay? Rise, get yourself baptized, and wash off your sins, calling upon His name.'
27722	44	22	17	 "After my return to Jerusalem, and while praying in the Temple, I fell into a trance.
27723	44	22	18	 I saw Jesus, and He said to me, "`Make haste and leave Jerusalem quickly, because they will not accept your testimony about Me.'
27724	44	22	19	 "`Lord,' I replied, `they themselves well know how active I was in imprisoning, and in flogging in synagogue after synagogue those who believe in Thee;
27725	44	22	20	 and when they were shedding the blood of Stephen, Thy witness, I was standing by, fully approving of it, and I held the clothes of those who were killing him.'
27726	44	22	21	 "`Go,' He replied; `I will send you as an Apostle  to nations far away.'"
27727	44	22	22	 Until they heard this last statement the people listened to Paul, but now with a roar of disapproval they cried out, "Away with such a fellow from the earth! He ought not to be allowed to live."
27728	44	22	23	 And when they continued their furious shouts, throwing their clothes into the air and flinging dust about,
27729	44	22	24	 the Tribune ordered him to be brought into the barracks, and be examined by flogging, in order to ascertain the reason why they thus cried out against him.
27730	44	22	25	 But, when they had tied him up  with the straps, Paul said to the Captain who stood by, "Does the Law permit you to flog a Roman citizen--and one too who is uncondemned?"
27731	44	22	26	 On hearing this question, the Captain went to report the matter to the Tribune.  "What are you intending to do?" he said. "This man is a Roman citizen."
27732	44	22	27	 So the Tribune came to Paul and asked him, "Tell me, are you a Roman citizen?" "Yes," he said.
27733	44	22	28	 "I paid a large sum for my citizenship," said the Tribune. "But I was born free," said Paul.
27734	44	22	29	 So the men who had been on the point of putting him  under torture immediately left him. And the Tribune, too, was frightened when he learnt that Paul was a Roman citizen, for he had had him bound.
27735	44	22	30	 The next day, wishing to know exactly what charge was being brought against him by the Jews, the Tribune ordered his chains to be removed; and, having sent word to the High Priests and all the Sanhedrin to assemble, he brought Paul down and made him stand before them.
27736	44	23	1	 Then Paul, fixing a steady gaze on the Sanhedrin, said, "Brethren, it is with a perfectly clear conscience that I have discharged my duties before God up to this day."
27737	44	23	2	 On hearing this the High Priest Ananias ordered those who were standing near Paul to strike him on the mouth.
27738	44	23	3	 "Before long," exclaimed Paul,  "God will strike you, you white-washed wall! Are you sitting there to judge me in accordance with the Law, and do you yourself actually break the Law by ordering me to be struck?"
27739	44	23	4	 "Do you rail at God's High Priest?" cried the men who stood by him.
27740	44	23	5	 "I did not know, brethren," replied Paul, "that he was the High Priest; for it is written, <`Thou shalt not speak evil of a ruler of Thy people.'">
27741	44	23	6	 Noticing, however, that the Sanhedrin consisted partly of Sadducees and partly of  Pharisees, he called out loudly among them, "Brethren, I am a Pharisee, the son of Pharisees. It is because of my hope of a resurrection of the dead that I am on my trial."
27742	44	23	7	 These words of his caused an angry dispute between the Pharisees and the Sadducees, and the assembly took different sides.
27743	44	23	8	 For the Sadducees maintain that there is no resurrection, and neither angel nor spirit; but the Pharisees acknowledge the existence of both.
27744	44	23	9	 So there arose a great uproar; and some of the Scribes belonging to the sect of the Pharisees sprang to their feet and fiercely contended, saying, "We find no harm in the man.  What if a spirit has spoken to him, or an angel----!"
27745	44	23	10	 But when the struggle was becoming violent, the Tribune, fearing that Paul would be torn to pieces by the people, ordered the troops to go down and take him from among them by force and bring him into the barracks.
27746	44	23	11	 The following night the Lord came and stood at Paul's side, and said, "Be of good courage, for as you have borne faithful witness about me in Jerusalem, so you must also bear witness in Rome."
27747	44	23	12	 Now, when daylight came, the Jews formed a conspiracy and solemnly swore not to eat or drink till they had killed Paul.
27748	44	23	13	 There were more than forty of them who bound themselves by this oath.
27749	44	23	14	 They went to the High Priests and Elders and said to them, "We have bound ourselves under a heavy curse  to take no food till we have killed Paul.
27750	44	23	15	 Now therefore you and the Sanhedrin should make representations to the Tribune for him to bring him down to you, under the impression that you intend to inquire more minutely about him; and we are prepared to assassinate him before he comes near the place."
27751	44	23	16	 But Paul's sister's son heard of the intended attack upon him. So he came and went into the barracks and told Paul about it;
27752	44	23	17	 and Paul called one of the Captains and said, "Take this young man to the Tribune, for he has information to give him."
27753	44	23	18	 So he took him and brought him to the Tribune, and said, "Paul, the prisoner, called me to him and begged me to bring this youth to you, because he has something to say to you."
27754	44	23	19	 Then the Tribune, taking him by the  arm, withdrew  out of the hearing of others and asked him, "What have you to tell me?"
27755	44	23	20	 "The Jews," he replied, "have agreed to request you to bring Paul down to the Sanhedrin to-morrow for the purpose of making yourself more accurately acquainted with the case.
27756	44	23	21	 I beg you not to comply; for more than forty men among them are lying in wait for him, who have solemnly vowed that they will neither eat nor drink till they have assassinated him; and even now they are ready, in anticipation of receiving that promise of you."
27757	44	23	22	 So the Tribune sent the youth home, cautioning him. "Do not let any one know that you have given me this information," he said.
27758	44	23	23	 Then, calling to him two of the Captains, he gave his orders. "Get ready two hundred men," he said, "to march to Caesarea, with seventy cavalry and two hundred light infantry, starting at nine o'clock to-night."
27759	44	23	24	 He further told them to provide  horses to mount Paul on, so as to bring him safely to Felix the Governor.
27760	44	23	25	 He also wrote a letter of which these were the  contents:
27761	44	23	26	 "Claudius Lysias to his Excellency, Felix the Governor: all good wishes.
27762	44	23	27	 This man Paul had been seized by the Jews, and they were on the point of killing him, when I came upon them with the troops and rescued him, for I had been informed that he was a Roman citizen.
27763	44	23	28	 And, wishing to know with certainty the offense of which they were accusing him, I brought him down into their Sanhedrin,
27764	44	23	29	 and I discovered that the charge had to do with questions of their Law, but that he was accused of nothing for which he deserves death or imprisonment.
27765	44	23	30	 But now that I have received information of an intended attack upon him, I immediately send him to you, directing his accusers also to state before you the case they have against him."
27766	44	23	31	 So, in obedience to their orders, the soldiers took Paul and brought him by night as far as Antipatris.
27767	44	23	32	 The next day the infantry returned to the barracks, leaving the cavalry to proceed with him;
27768	44	23	33	 and, the cavalry having reached Caesarea and delivered the letter to the Governor, they brought Paul also to him.
27769	44	23	34	 Felix, after reading the letter, inquired from what province he was; and being told "from Cilicia,"
27770	44	23	35	 he said, "I will hear all you have to say, when your accusers also have come." And he ordered him to be detained in custody in Herod's Palace.
27771	44	24	1	  Five days after this, Ananias the High Priest came down to Caesarea with a number of Elders and a pleader called Tertullus. They stated to the Governor the case against Paul.
27772	44	24	2	 So Paul was sent for, and Tertullus began to impeach him as follows: "Indebted as we are," he said, "to you, most noble Felix, for the perfect peace which we enjoy, and for reforms which your wisdom has introduced to this nation,
27773	44	24	3	 in every instance and in every place we accept them with profound gratitude.
27774	44	24	4	 But--not to detain you too long--I beg you in your forbearance to listen to a brief statement from us.
27775	44	24	5	 For we have found this man Paul a source of mischief and a disturber of the peace among all the Jews throughout the Empire, and a ringleader in the heresy of the Nazarenes.
27776	44	24	6	 He even attempted to profane the Temple, but we arrested him.
27777	44	24	7	  []
27778	44	24	8	 You, however, by examining him, will yourself be able to learn the truth as to all this which we allege against him."
27779	44	24	9	 The Jews also  joined in the charge, maintaining that these were facts.
27780	44	24	10	 Then, at  a sign from the Governor, Paul answered, "Knowing,  Sir, that for many years you have administered justice to this nation, I cheerfully make my defence.
27781	44	24	11	 For you have it in your power to ascertain that it is not more than twelve days ago that I went up to worship in Jerusalem;
27782	44	24	12	 and that neither in the Temple nor in the synagogues, nor anywhere in the city, did they find me disputing with any opponent or collecting a crowd about me.
27783	44	24	13	 Nor can they  prove the charges which they are now bringing against me.
