27784	44	24	14	 But this I confess to you--that in the way which they style a heresy, I worship the God of our forefathers, believing everything that is taught in the Law or is written in the Prophets,
27785	44	24	15	 and having a hope directed towards God, which my accusers themselves also entertain, that before long there will be a resurrection both of the righteous and the unrighteous.
27786	44	24	16	 This too is my own earnest endeavour--always to have a clear conscience in relation to God and man.
27787	44	24	17	 "Now after an interval of several years I came to bring alms to my nation, and to offer sacrifices.
27788	44	24	18	 While I was busy about these, they found me in the Temple purified, with no crowd around me and no uproar; but there were certain Jews from the province of Asia.
27789	44	24	19	 They ought to have been here before you, and to have been my prosecutors, if they have any charge to bring against me.
27790	44	24	20	 Or let these men themselves say what misdemeanour they found me guilty of when I stood before the Sanhedrin,
27791	44	24	21	 unless it was in that one expression which I made use of when I shouted out as I stood among them, "`The resurrection of the dead is the thing about which I am on my trial before you to-day.'"
27792	44	24	22	 At this point Felix, who was fairly well informed about the new faith, adjourned the trial, saying to the Jews, "When the Tribune Lysias comes down, I will enter carefully into the matter."
27793	44	24	23	 And he gave orders to the Captain that Paul was to be kept in custody, but be treated with indulgence, and that his personal friends were not to be prevented from showing him kindness.
27794	44	24	24	 Not long after this, Felix came with Drusilla his wife, a Jewess, and sending for Paul, listened to him as he spoke about faith in Christ Jesus.
27795	44	24	25	 But when he dealt with the subjects of justice,  self-control, and the judgement which was soon to come, Felix became alarmed and said, "For the present leave me, and when I can find a convenient opportunity I will send for you."
27796	44	24	26	 At the same time he hoped that Paul would give him money; and for this reason he sent for him the oftener to converse with him.
27797	44	24	27	 But after the lapse of fully two years Felix was succeeded by Porcius Festus; and being desirous of gratifying the Jews, Felix left Paul still  in prison.
27798	44	25	1	 Festus, having entered on his duties as governor of the province, two days later went up from Caesarea to Jerusalem.
27799	44	25	2	 The High Priests and the leading men among the Jews immediately made representations to him against Paul, and begged him--
27800	44	25	3	 asking it as a favour, to Paul's prejudice--to have him brought to Jerusalem. They were planning an ambush to kill him on the way.
27801	44	25	4	 Festus, however, replied that Paul was in custody  in Caesarea, and that he was himself going there very soon.
27802	44	25	5	 "Therefore let those of you," he said, "who can come, go down with me, and impeach the man, if there is anything amiss in him."
27803	44	25	6	 After a stay of eight or ten days in Jerusalem--not more--he went down to Caesarea; and the next day, taking his seat on the tribunal, he ordered Paul to be brought in.
27804	44	25	7	 Upon Paul's arrival, the Jews who had come down from Jerusalem stood round him, and brought many grave charges against him which they were unable to substantiate.
27805	44	25	8	 But, in reply, Paul said, "Neither against the Jewish Law, nor against the Temple, nor against Caesar, have I committed any offence whatever."
27806	44	25	9	 Then Festus, being anxious to gratify the Jews, asked Paul, "Are you willing to go up to Jerusalem, and there  stand your trial before me on these charges?"
27807	44	25	10	 "I am standing before Caesar's tribunal," replied Paul, "where alone I ought to be tried. The Jews have no real ground of complaint against me, as in fact you yourself are beginning to see more clearly.
27808	44	25	11	 If, however, I have done wrong and have committed any offence for which I deserve to die, I do not ask to be excused that penalty. But if there is no truth in what these men allege against me, no one has the right to give me up to them as a favour. I appeal to Caesar."
27809	44	25	12	 Then, after conferring with the Council, Festus replied, "To Caesar you have appealed: to Caesar you shall go."
27810	44	25	13	 A short time after this, Agrippa the king and Bernice came to Caesarea to pay a complimentary visit to Festus;
27811	44	25	14	 and, during their rather long stay, Festus laid Paul's case before the king. "There is a man here," he said, "whom Felix left a prisoner,
27812	44	25	15	 about whom, when I went to Jerusalem, the High Priests and the Elders of the Jews made representations to me, begging that sentence might be pronounced against him.
27813	44	25	16	 My reply was that it is not the custom among the Romans to give up any one for punishment before the accused has had his accusers face to face, and has had an opportunity of defending himself against the charge which has been brought against him.
27814	44	25	17	 "When, therefore, a number of them came here, the next day I took my seat on the tribunal, without any loss of time, and ordered the man to be brought in.
27815	44	25	18	 But, when his accusers stood up, they did not charge him with the misdemeanours of which I had been suspecting him.
27816	44	25	19	 But they quarrelled with him about certain matters connected with their own religion, and about one Jesus who had died, but--so Paul persistently maintained--is now alive.
27817	44	25	20	 I was at a loss how to investigate such questions, and asked Paul whether he would care to go to Jerusalem and there stand his trial on these matters.
27818	44	25	21	 But when Paul appealed to have his case kept for the Emperor's decision, I ordered him to be kept in prison until I could send him up to Caesar."
27819	44	25	22	 "I should like to hear the man myself," said Agrippa. "to-morrow," replied Festus, "you shall." Accordingly, the next day, Agrippa and Bernice came in state
27820	44	25	23	 and took their seats in the Judgement Hall, attended by the Tribunes and the men of high rank in the city; and, at the command of Festus, Paul was brought in.
27821	44	25	24	 Then Festus said, "King Agrippa and all who are present with us, you see here the man about whom the whole nation of the Jews made suit to me, both in Jerusalem and here, crying out that he ought not to live any longer.
27822	44	25	25	 I could not discover that he had done anything for which he deserved to die; but as he has himself appealed to the Emperor, I have decided to send him to Rome.
27823	44	25	26	 I have nothing very definite, however, to tell our Sovereign about him. So I have brought the man before you all--and especially before you, King Agrippa--that after he has been examined I may find something which I can put into writing.
27824	44	25	27	 For, when sending a prisoner to Rome, it seems to me to be absurd not to state the charges against him."
27825	44	26	1	 Then Agrippa said to Paul, "You have permission to speak about yourself." So Paul, with outstretched arm, proceeded to make his defence.
27826	44	26	2	 "As regards all the accusations brought against me by the Jews," he said,  "I think myself fortunate, King Agrippa, in being about to defend myself to-day before  you,
27827	44	26	3	 who are so familiar with all the customs and speculations that prevail among the Jews; and for this reason, I pray you, give me a patient hearing.
27828	44	26	4	 "The kind of life I have lived from my youth upwards, as exemplified in my early days among my nation and in Jerusalem, is known to all the Jews.
27829	44	26	5	 For they all know me of old--if they would but testify to the fact--how, being an adherent of the strictest sect of our religion, my life was that of a Pharisee.
27830	44	26	6	 And now I stand here impeached  because of my hope in the fulfilment of the promise made by God to our forefathers--
27831	44	26	7	 the promise which our twelve tribes, worshipping day and night with intense devotedness, hope to have made good to them. It is on the subject of this hope,  Sir, that I am accused by the Jews.
27832	44	26	8	 Why is it deemed with all of you a thing past belief if God raises the dead to life?
27833	44	26	9	 "I myself, however, thought it a duty to do many things in hostility to the name of Jesus, the Nazarene.
27834	44	26	10	 And that was how I acted in Jerusalem. Armed with authority received from the High Priests I shut up many of  God's people in various prisons, and when they were about to be put to death I gave my vote against them.
27835	44	26	11	 In all the synagogues also I punished them many a time, and tried to make them blaspheme; and in my wild fury I chased them even to foreign towns.
27836	44	26	12	 "While thus engaged, I was travelling one day to Damascus armed with authority and a commission from the High Priests,
27837	44	26	13	 and on the journey, at noon, Sir, I saw a light from Heaven--brighter than the brightness of the sun--shining around me and around those who were travelling with me.
27838	44	26	14	 We all fell to the ground; and I heard a voice which said to me in Hebrew, "`Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting Me? You are finding it painful to kick against the ox-goad.'
27839	44	26	15	 "`Who art Thou, Lord?' I asked. "`I am Jesus whom you are persecuting,' the Lord replied.
27840	44	26	16	 `But rise, and stand on your feet; for I have appeared to you for the very purpose of appointing you My servant and My witness both as to the things you have already seen and as to those in which I will appear to you.
27841	44	26	17	 I will save you from the Jewish people and from the Gentiles,  to whom I send you to open their eyes,
27842	44	26	18	 that they may turn from darkness to light and from the obedience to Satan to God, in order to receive forgiveness of sins and an inheritance among those who are sanctified through faith in Me.'
27843	44	26	19	 "Therefore, King Agrippa, I was not disobedient to the heavenly vision;
27844	44	26	20	 but I proceeded to preach first to the people in Damascus, and then to those in Jerusalem and in all Judaea, and to the Gentiles, that they must repent and turn to God, and live lives consistent with such repentance.
27845	44	26	21	 "It was on this account that the Jews seized me in the Temple and tried to kill me.
27846	44	26	22	 Having, however, obtained the help which is from God, I have stood firm until now, and have solemnly exhorted rich and poor alike, saying nothing except what the Prophets and Moses predicted as soon to happen,
27847	44	26	23	 since the Christ was to be a suffering Christ, and by coming back from the dead was then to be the first to proclaim a message of light both to the Jewish people and to the Gentiles."
27848	44	26	24	 As Paul thus made his defence, Festus exclaimed in a loud voice, "You are raving mad, Paul; and great learning is driving you mad."
27849	44	26	25	 "I am not mad, most noble Festus," replied Paul; "I am speaking words of sober truth.
27850	44	26	26	 For the King, to whom I speak freely, knows about these matters. I am not to be persuaded that any detail of them  has escaped his notice; for these things have not been done in a corner.
27851	44	26	27	 King Agrippa, do you believe the Prophets? I know that you believe them."
27852	44	26	28	 Agrippa answered,  "In brief, you are doing your best to persuade me to become a Christian."
27853	44	26	29	 "My prayer to God, whether  briefly or at length," replied Paul, "would be that not only you but all who are my hearers to-day, might become such as I am--except these chains."
27854	44	26	30	 So the King rose, and the Governor, and Bernice, and those who were sitting with them;
27855	44	26	31	 and, having withdrawn, they talked to one another and said, "This man is doing nothing for which he deserves death or imprisonment."
27856	44	26	32	 And Agrippa said to Festus, "He might have been set at liberty, if he had not appealed to Caesar."
27857	44	27	1	 Now when it was decided that we should sail for Italy, they handed over Paul and a few other prisoners into the custody of Julius, a Captain of the Augustan battalion;
27858	44	27	2	 and going on board a ship of Adramyttium which was about to sail to the ports of the province of Asia, we put to sea; Aristarchus, the Macedonian, from Thessalonica, forming one of our party.
27859	44	27	3	 The next day we put in at Sidon. There Julius treated Paul with thoughtful kindness and allowed him to visit his friends and profit by their generous care.
27860	44	27	4	 Putting to sea again, we sailed under the lee of Cyprus, because the winds were  against us;
27861	44	27	5	 and, sailing the whole length of the sea that lies off Cilicia and Pamphylia, we reached  Myra in Lycia.
27862	44	27	6	 There Julius found an Alexandrian ship bound for Italy, and put us on board of her.
27863	44	27	7	 It took several days of slow sailing for us to come with difficulty off Cnidus; from which point, as the wind did not allow us to get on in the direct course, we ran under the lee of Crete  by Salmone.
27864	44	27	8	 Then, coasting along with difficulty, we reached a place called `Fair Havens,' near the town of Lasea.
27865	44	27	9	  Our voyage thus far had occupied a considerable time, and the navigation being now unsafe and  the Fast also already over, Paul warned them.
27866	44	27	10	 "Sirs," he said, "I perceive that before long the voyage will be attended with danger and heavy loss, not only to the cargo and the ship but to our own lives also."
27867	44	27	11	 But Julius let himself be persuaded by the pilot and by the owner rather than by Paul's arguments;
27868	44	27	12	 and as the harbour was inconvenient for wintering in, the majority were in favour of putting out to sea, to try whether they could get to Phoenix--a harbour on the coast of Crete  facing north-east and south-east--to winter there.
27869	44	27	13	 And a light breeze from the south sprang up, so that they supposed they  were now sure of their purpose. So weighing anchor they ran along the coast of Crete, hugging the shore.
27870	44	27	14	 But it was not long before  a furious north-east wind, coming  down from the mountains,  burst upon us and carried the ship out of her course.
27871	44	27	15	 She was unable to make headway against the gale; so we gave up and let her drive.
27872	44	27	16	 Then we ran under the lee of a little island called  Cauda, where we managed with great difficulty to secure the boat;
27873	44	27	17	 and, after hoisting it on board, they used frapping-cables  to undergird the ship, and, as they were afraid of being driven on the Syrtis quicksands, they lowered the gear and  lay to.
27874	44	27	18	 But, as the storm was still violent, the next day they began to lighten the ship;
27875	44	27	19	 and, on the third day, with their own hands they threw the ship's spare gear overboard.
27876	44	27	20	 Then, when for several days neither sun nor stars were seen and the terrific gale still harassed us, the last ray of hope was now vanishing.
27877	44	27	21	 When for a long time they had taken but little food, Paul, standing up among them, said, "Sirs, you ought to have listened to me and not have sailed from Crete. You would then have escaped this suffering and loss.
27878	44	27	22	 But now take courage, for there will be no destruction of life among you, but of the ship only.
27879	44	27	23	 For there stood by my side, last night, an angel of the God to whom I belong, and whom also I worship,
27880	44	27	24	 and he said, "`Dismiss all fear, Paul, for you must stand before Caesar; and God has granted you the lives of all who are sailing with you.'
27881	44	27	25	 "Therefore, Sirs, take courage; for I believe God, and am convinced that things will happen exactly as I have been told.
27882	44	27	26	 But we are to be stranded on a certain island."
27883	44	27	27	 It was now the fourteenth night, and we were  drifting through  the Sea of Adria, when, about midnight, the sailors suspected that land was close at hand.
27884	44	27	28	 So they hove the lead and found twenty fathoms of water; and after a short time they hove again and found fifteen fathoms.
27885	44	27	29	 Then for fear of possibly running on rocks, they threw out four anchors from the stern and  waited impatiently for daylight.
27886	44	27	30	 The sailors, however, wanted to make their escape from the ship, and had lowered the boat into the sea, pretending that they were going to lay out anchors from the bow.
27887	44	27	31	 But Paul, addressing Julius and the soldiers, said, "Your lives will be sacrificed, unless these men remain on board."
27888	44	27	32	 Then the soldiers cut the ropes of the ship's boat and let her fall off.
27889	44	27	33	 And continually, up till daybreak, Paul kept urging all on board to take some food. "This is the fourteenth day," he said, "that you have been anxiously waiting for the storm to cease, and have fasted, eating little or nothing.
27890	44	27	34	 I therefore strongly advise you to take some food. This is essential for your safety. For not a hair will perish from the head of any one of you."
27891	44	27	35	 Having said this he took some bread, and, after giving thanks to God for it before them all, he broke it in pieces and began to eat it.
27892	44	27	36	 This raised the spirits of all, and they too took food.
27893	44	27	37	 There were  276 of us, crew and passengers, all told.
27894	44	27	38	 After eating a hearty meal they lightened the ship by throwing the wheat overboard.
27895	44	27	39	 When daylight came, they tried in vain to recognise the coast. But an inlet with a sandy beach attracted their attention, and now  their object was, if possible, to run the ship aground  in this inlet.
27896	44	27	40	 So they cut away the anchors and left them in the sea, unloosing at the same time the bands which secured the  paddle-rudders. Then, hoisting the foresail to the wind, they made for the beach.
27897	44	27	41	 But coming to a place where two seas met, they stranded the ship, and her bow sticking fast remained immovable, while the stern began to go to pieces under the heavy hammering of the sea.
27898	44	27	42	 Now the soldiers recommended that the prisoners should be killed, for fear some one of them might swim ashore and effect his escape.
27899	44	27	43	 But their Captain, bent on securing Paul's safety, kept them from their purpose and gave orders that those who could swim should first jump overboard and get to land;
27900	44	27	44	 and that the rest should follow, some on planks, and others on various things from the ship. In this way they all  got safely to land.
27901	44	28	1	 Our lives having been thus preserved, we discovered that the island was called  Malta.
27902	44	28	2	 The strange-speaking natives showed us remarkable kindness, for they lighted a fire and made us all welcome because of the pelting rain and the cold.
27903	44	28	3	 Now, when Paul had gathered a bundle of sticks and had thrown them on the fire, a viper, driven by the heat, came out and fastened itself on his hand.
27904	44	28	4	 When the natives saw the creature hanging to his hand, they said to one another, "Beyond doubt this man is a murderer, for, though saved from the sea, unerring Justice does not permit him to live."
27905	44	28	5	 He, however, shook the reptile off into the fire and was unhurt.
27906	44	28	6	 They expected him soon to swell with inflammation or suddenly fall down dead; but, after waiting a long time and seeing no harm come to him, they changed their minds and said that he was a god.
27907	44	28	7	 Now in the same part of the island there were estates belonging to the Governor, whose name was Publius. He welcomed us to his house, and for three days generously made us his guests.
27908	44	28	8	 It happened, however, that his father was lying ill of dysentery aggravated by attacks of fever; so Paul went to see him, and, after praying, laid his hands on him and cured him.
27909	44	28	9	 After this, all the other sick people in the island came and were cured.
27910	44	28	10	 They also loaded us with honours, and when at last we sailed they put supplies on board for us.
27911	44	28	11	 Three months passed before we set sail in an Alexandrian vessel,  called the `Twin Brothers,' which had wintered at the island.
27912	44	28	12	 At Syracuse we put in and stayed for  two days.
27913	44	28	13	 From there we  came round and reached Rhegium; and a day later, a south wind sprang up which brought us by the evening of the next day to Puteoli.
27914	44	28	14	 Here we found brethren, who invited us to remain with them for a week; and so we reached Rome.
27915	44	28	15	 Meanwhile the brethren there, hearing of our movements, came as far as  the Market of Appius and the Three Huts to meet us; and when Paul saw them he thanked God and felt encouraged.
27916	44	28	16	 Upon our arrival  in Rome, Paul received permission to live  by himself, guarded by a soldier.
27917	44	28	17	 After  one complete day he invited the leading men among the Jews to meet him; and, when they were come together, he said to them, "As for me, brethren, although I had done nothing prejudicial to our people or contrary to the customs of our forefathers, I was handed over as a prisoner from Jerusalem into the power of the Romans.
27918	44	28	18	 They, after they had sharply questioned me, were willing to set me at liberty, because they found no offence in me for which I deserve to die.
27919	44	28	19	 But,  at last, the opposition of the Jews compelled me to appeal to Caesar; not however that I had any charge to bring against my nation.
27920	44	28	20	 For these reasons, then, I have invited you here, that I might see you and speak to you; for it is for the sake of  Him who is the hope of Israel that this chain hangs  upon me."
27921	44	28	21	 "For our part," they replied, "we have not received any letters from Judaea about you, nor have any of our countrymen come here and reported or stated anything to your disadvantage.
27922	44	28	22	 But we should be glad to hear from you what it is that you believe; for as for this sect all we know is that it is everywhere spoken against."
27923	44	28	23	 So they arranged a day with him and came to him in  considerable numbers  at the house of the friends who were entertaining him. And then, with solemn earnestness, he explained to them the subject of the Kingdom of God, endeavouring from morning till evening to convince them about Jesus, both from the Law of Moses and from the Prophets.
27924	44	28	24	 Some were convinced; others refused to believe.
27925	44	28	25	 Unable to agree among themselves, they at last left him, but not before Paul had spoken a parting word to them, saying, "Right well did the Holy Spirit say to your forefathers through the Prophet Isaiah:
27926	44	28	26	 <"`Go to this people and tell them, you will hear and hear, and by no means understand; and will look and look, and by no means see.
27927	44	28	27	 For this people's mind has grown callous, their hearing has become dull, and their eyes they have closed; to prevent their ever seeing with their eyes, or hearing with their ears, or understanding with their minds, and turning back, so that I might cure them.'>
27928	44	28	28	 "Be fully assured, therefore, that this salvation--God's salvation--has now been sent to the Gentiles, and that they, at any rate, will give heed."
27929	44	28	29	  []
27930	44	28	30	 After this Paul lived for fully two years in a hired house of his own, receiving all who came to see him.
27931	44	28	31	 He announced the coming of the Kingdom of God, and taught concerning the Lord Jesus Christ without let or hindrance.
27932	45	1	1	 Paul, a bondservant of Jesus Christ,  called to be an Apostle, set apart to proclaim God's Good News,
27933	45	1	2	 which God had already promised through His Prophets in Holy Writ, concerning His Son,
27934	45	1	3	 who, as regards His human descent, belonged to the posterity of David,
27935	45	1	4	 but as regards the holiness of His Spirit was decisively proved by His Resurrection to be the Son of God--I mean concerning Jesus Christ our Lord,
27936	45	1	5	 through whom we have received  grace and Apostleship in His service in order  to win men to obedience to the faith, among all Gentile peoples,
27937	45	1	6	 among whom you also,  called, as you have been, to belong to Jesus Christ, are numbered:
27938	45	1	7	 To all  God's loved ones who are in Rome, called  to be saints. May grace and peace be granted to you from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
27939	45	1	8	 First of all, I thank my God through Jesus Christ for what He has done for all of you; for the report of your faith is spreading through the whole world.
27940	45	1	9	 I call God to witness--to whom I render priestly and spiritual service by telling the Good News about His Son--  how unceasingly I make mention of you in His presence,
27941	45	1	10	 always in my prayers entreating that now, at length, if such be His will, the way may by some means be made clear for me to come to you.
27942	45	1	11	 For I am longing to see you, in order to convey to you some spiritual help, so that you may be strengthened;
27943	45	1	12	 in other words that while I am among you we may be mutually encouraged by one another's faith, yours and mine.
27944	45	1	13	 And I desire you to know, brethren, that I have many a time intended to come to you--though until now I have been disappointed--in order that among you also I might gather some fruit from my labours, as I have already done among the rest of the Gentile nations.
27945	45	1	14	 I  am already under obligations alike to Greek-speaking races and to others, to cultured and to uncultured people:
27946	45	1	15	 so that for my part I am willing and eager to proclaim the Good News to you also who are in Rome.
27947	45	1	16	 For I am not ashamed of the Good News. It is God's power which is at work for the salvation of every one who believes--the Jew first, and then the  Gentile.
27948	45	1	17	 For in the Good News  a righteousness which comes from God is being revealed, depending on faith and tending to produce faith; as the Scripture has it,  <"The righteous man shall live by faith.">
27949	45	1	18	 For God's anger is being revealed from Heaven against all impiety and against the iniquity of men who through iniquity suppress the truth. God is angry:
27950	45	1	19	 because what may be known about Him is plain  to their inmost consciousness; for He Himself has made it plain to them.
27951	45	1	20	 For, from the very creation of the world, His invisible perfections--namely His eternal power and divine nature--have been rendered intelligible and clearly visible by His works,  so that these men are without excuse.
27952	45	1	21	 For when they had come to know God, they did not give Him glory as God nor render Him thanks, but they became absorbed in useless discussions, and their senseless minds were darkened.
27953	45	1	22	 While boasting of their wisdom they became  utter fools,
27954	45	1	23	 and,  instead of worshipping the imperishable God, they worshipped images resembling perishable man or resembling birds or beasts or reptiles.
27955	45	1	24	 For this reason, in accordance with  their own depraved cravings, God gave them up to uncleanness, allowing them to dishonour their bodies among themselves with impurity.
27956	45	1	25	 For they had bartered the reality of God for  what is unreal, and had offered divine honours and religious service to created things, rather than to the Creator--He who is for ever blessed. Amen.
27957	45	1	26	 This then is the reason why God gave them up to vile passions. For not only did the women among them exchange the natural use of their bodies for one which is contrary to nature, but the men also,
27958	45	1	27	 in just the same way--neglecting that for which nature intends women--burned with passion towards one another, men practising shameful vice with men, and receiving in their own selves the reward which necessarily followed their misconduct.
27959	45	1	28	 And just as they had refused to continue to have a full knowledge of God, so it was to utterly worthless minds that God gave them up, for them to do things which should not be done.
27960	45	1	29	 Their hearts overflowed with all sorts of dishonesty, mischief, greed,  malice. They were full of envy and murder, and were quarrelsome, crafty, and spiteful.
27961	45	1	30	 They were secret backbiters, open slanderers;  hateful to God, insolent, haughty, boastful; inventors of new forms of sin, disobedient to parents, destitute of common sense,
27962	45	1	31	 faithless to their promises, without natural affection, without human pity.
27963	45	1	32	 In short, though knowing full well the sentence which God pronounces against  actions such as theirs, as things which deserve death, they not only  practise them, but even  encourage and applaud others who do them.
27964	45	2	1	 You are therefore without excuse, O man,  whoever you are who  sit in judgement upon others. For when you  pass judgement on your fellow man, you condemn yourself; for you who sit in judgement upon others are guilty of the same misdeeds;
27965	45	2	2	 and we know that God's judgement  against those who commit such sins is in accordance with the truth.
27966	45	2	3	 And you who pronounce judgement upon those who do such things although your own conduct is the same as theirs--do you imagine that you yourself will escape unpunished when God judges?
27967	45	2	4	 Or is it that you think slightingly of  His infinite goodness, forbearance and patience, unaware that the goodness of God is gently drawing you to repentance?
27968	45	2	5	 The fact is that in the stubbornness of your impenitent heart you are treasuring up against yourself anger on the day of Anger--the day when the righteousness of God's judgements will stand revealed.
27969	45	2	6	 <To each man He will make an award corresponding to his actions;>
27970	45	2	7	 to those on the one hand who, by lives of persistent right-doing, are striving for glory, honour and immortality, the Life of the Ages;
27971	45	2	8	 while on the other hand upon the self-willed who disobey the truth and obey unrighteousness will fall anger and fury,  affliction and awful distress,
27972	45	2	9	 coming upon the soul of every  man and woman who deliberately does wrong--upon the Jew first, and then upon the  Gentile;
27973	45	2	10	 whereas glory, honour and peace will be given to every one who does what is good and right--to the Jew first and then to the Gentile.
27974	45	2	11	  For God pays no attention to this world's distinctions.
27975	45	2	12	 For all who  have sinned  apart from the Law will also perish apart from the Law, and all who have sinned whilst living  under the Law, will be judged by the Law.
27976	45	2	13	 It is not those that merely  hear the Law  read who are righteous in the sight of God, but it is those that obey the Law who will be pronounced righteous.
27977	45	2	14	 For when Gentiles who have no Law obey by natural instinct the commands of the Law, they, without having a Law, are a Law to themselves;
27978	45	2	15	 since they exhibit proof that  a knowledge of the conduct which the Law requires is engraven on their hearts, while their consciences also bear witness to the Law, and their thoughts, as if in mutual discussion, accuse them or perhaps maintain their innocence--
27979	45	2	16	 on the day when God will judge the secrets of men's lives  by Jesus Christ, as declared in the Good News as I have taught it.
27980	45	2	17	 And since you claim the name of Jew, and find  rest and satisfaction in the Law, and make your boast in God,
27981	45	2	18	 and know the supreme will, and  can test things that differ--being a man who receives instruction from the Law--
27982	45	2	19	 and have persuaded yourself that, as for you, you are a guide to the blind, a light to those who are in darkness,
27983	45	2	20	 a schoolmaster for the dull and ignorant, a teacher of the young, because in the Law you possess  an outline of  real knowledge and an outline of the truth:
27984	45	2	21	 you then who teach your fellow man, do you refuse to teach yourself? You who cry out against stealing, are you yourself a thief?
27985	45	2	22	 You who forbid adultery, do you commit adultery? You who loathe idols, do you plunder their temples?
27986	45	2	23	 You who make your boast in the Law, do you offend against its commands and so dishonour God?
27987	45	2	24	 <For the name of God is blasphemed among the Gentile nations because of you,> as Holy Writ declares.
27988	45	2	25	 Circumcision does indeed profit, if you obey the Law; but if you are a Law-breaker, the fact that you have been circumcised counts for nothing.
27989	45	2	26	 In the same way if an uncircumcised man pays attention to the just requirements of the Law, shall not his lack of circumcision  be overlooked, and,
27990	45	2	27	  although he is a Gentile by birth, if he scrupulously obeys the Law, shall he not sit in judgement upon you who, possessing, as you do, a written Law and circumcision, are yet a Law-breaker?
27991	45	2	28	 For the true Jew is not the man who is simply a Jew outwardly, and true circumcision is not that which is outward and bodily.
27992	45	2	29	 But the true Jew is one inwardly, and true circumcision is heart-circumcision--not literal, but spiritual; and such people receive praise not from men, but from God.
27993	45	3	1	 What special privilege, then, has a Jew? Or what benefit is to be derived from circumcision?
27994	45	3	2	 The privilege is great from every point of view. First of all, because the Jews were entrusted with  God's truth.
27995	45	3	3	 For what if some Jews have proved  unfaithful? Shall their faithlessness render God's faithfulness worthless?
27996	45	3	4	  No, indeed; let us hold God to be true, though every man should prove to be false. As it stands written, <"That Thou mayest be shown to be just in  the sentence Thou pronouncest, and gain Thy cause  when Thou contendest.">
27997	45	3	5	 But if our unrighteousness  sets God's righteousness in a clearer light, what shall we say? (Is God unrighteous--I speak in our everyday language-- when He inflicts punishment?
27998	45	3	6	 No indeed; for in that case how shall He judge all mankind?)
27999	45	3	7	 If,  for instance, a falsehood of mine has made God's truthfulness more conspicuous, redounding to His glory, why am I judged all the same as a sinner?
28000	45	3	8	 And why should we not say--for so they wickedly misrepresent us, and so some charge us with arguing--"Let us do evil that good may come"? The condemnation  of those who would so argue is just.
28001	45	3	9	 What then? Are we Jews more highly  estimated than they? Not in the least; for we have already charged all Jews and Gentiles alike with being in thraldom to sin.
28002	45	3	10	 Thus it stands written, <"There is not one righteous man.
28003	45	3	11	 There is not one who is really wise, nor one who is a diligent seeker after God.
28004	45	3	12	 All have turned aside from the right path; they have every one of them become corrupt. There is no one who does what is right--no, not so much as one."
28005	45	3	13	 "Their throats resemble an opened grave; with their tongues they have been talking deceitfully." "The venom of vipers lies hidden  behind their lips."
28006	45	3	14	 "Their mouths are full of cursing and bitterness."
28007	45	3	15	 "Their feet move swiftly to shed blood.
28008	45	3	16	  Ruin and misery mark their path;
28009	45	3	17	 and the way to peace they have not known."
28010	45	3	18	 "There is no fear of God before their eyes.">
28011	45	3	19	 But it cannot be denied that all that the Law says is addressed to those who are living under the Law, in order that  every mouth may be stopped, and that the whole world may await sentence from God.
28012	45	3	20	 For on the ground of obedience to Law no man living will be declared righteous before Him. Law simply brings a sure knowledge of sin.
28013	45	3	21	 But now a righteousness coming from God has been brought to light apart from any Law, both Law and Prophets bearing witness to it--
28014	45	3	22	 a righteousness coming from God,  which depends on faith in Jesus Christ and extends  to all who believe. No distinction is made;
28015	45	3	23	 for all alike have sinned, and all  consciously come short of the glory of God,
28016	45	3	24	 gaining acquittal from guilt by His free unpurchased grace through the  deliverance which is found in Christ Jesus.
28017	45	3	25	 He it is whom God put forward as  a Mercy-seat, rendered efficacious through faith in His blood, in order to demonstrate His righteousness--  because of the passing over, in God's forbearance, of the sins previously committed--
28018	45	3	26	 with a view to demonstrating, at the present time, His righteousness, that He may  be shown to be righteous Himself, and the giver of righteousness to those who believe in Jesus.
28019	45	3	27	 Where then is there room for your boasting? It is  for ever shut out.  On what principle? On the ground of merit? No, but on the ground of faith.
28020	45	3	28	  For we maintain that it is as the result of faith that a man is held to be righteous, apart from actions done in obedience to Law.
28021	45	3	29	 Is God simply the God of the Jews, and not of the Gentiles also? He is certainly the God of the Gentiles also,
28022	45	3	30	 unless you can deny that it is one and the same God who will pronounce the circumcised to be acquitted on the ground of faith, and the uncircumcised to be acquitted through the same faith.
28023	45	3	31	 Do we then by means of this faith abolish  the Law? No, indeed; we give  the Law a firmer footing.
28024	45	4	1	 What then shall we say  that Abraham, our earthly forefather, has gained?
28025	45	4	2	 For if he was held to be righteous on the ground of his actions, he has something to boast of; but not  in the presence of God.
28026	45	4	3	 For what says the Scripture? <"And Abraham believed God, and  this was placed to his credit as righteousness.">
28027	45	4	4	 But in the case of a man who works, pay is not reckoned a favour but a debt;
28028	45	4	5	 whereas in the case of a man who pleads no actions of his own, but simply  believes in Him who declares the ungodly free from guilt, his faith is placed to his credit as righteousness.
28029	45	4	6	 In this way David also  tells of the blessedness of the man to whose credit God places righteousness, apart from his actions.
28030	45	4	7	 <"Blessed,"> he says, <"are those whose iniquities have been forgiven, and whose sins have been covered over.
28031	45	4	8	 Blessed is the man of whose sin the Lord will not take account.">
28032	45	4	9	 This declaration of blessedness, then, does it come simply to the circumcised, or to the uncircumcised as well? For <Abraham's faith>--so we affirm--<was placed to his credit as righteousness.>
28033	45	4	10	 What then were the circumstances under which this took place? Was it after he had been circumcised, or before?
28034	45	4	11	 Before, not after. And he received  circumcision as a sign, a mark attesting the reality of the faith-righteousness which was his while still uncircumcised, that he might be the forefather of all those who believe even though they are uncircumcised--in order that this righteousness might be placed to their credit;
28035	45	4	12	 and the forefather of the circumcised, namely of those who not merely are circumcised, but also walk in the steps of the faith which our forefather Abraham had while he was as yet uncircumcised.
28036	45	4	13	  Again, the promise that he should inherit the world did not come to Abraham or his posterity conditioned by Law, but by faith-righteousness.
28037	45	4	14	 For if it is the righteous through Law who are heirs, then faith is useless and the promise counts for nothing.
28038	45	4	15	 For the Law inflicts  punishment; but where no Law exists, there can be no violation of Law.
28039	45	4	16	 All depends on faith, and for this reason--that  acceptance with God might be an act of pure grace,
28040	45	4	17	 so that the promise should be made sure to all Abraham's true descendants; not merely to those who are righteous through the Law, but to those who are righteous through a faith like that of Abraham. Thus in the sight of God in whom he believed, who gives life to  the dead and makes reference to things that do not exist, as though they did, Abraham is the forefather of  all of us. As it is written, <"I have appointed you to be the forefather of many nations.">
28041	45	4	18	 Under utterly hopeless circumstances he hopefully believed, so that he might become the forefather of many nations, in agreement with the words <"Equally numerous shall your posterity be.">
28042	45	4	19	 And, without growing weak in faith, he could contemplate his own vital powers which had now decayed--for he was nearly 100 years old--and Sarah's barrenness.
28043	45	4	20	 Nor did he in unbelief stagger at God's promise, but became mighty in faith, giving glory to God,
28044	45	4	21	 and being absolutely certain that whatever promise He is bound by He is able also to make good.
28045	45	4	22	 For this reason also his faith <was placed to his credit as righteousness.>
28046	45	4	23	 Nor was the fact of its being placed to his credit put on record for his sake only;
28047	45	4	24	 it was for our sakes too. Faith, before long, will be placed to the credit of us also who are believers in Him who raised Jesus, our Lord, from the dead,
28048	45	4	25	 who was surrendered to death  because of the offences we had committed, and was raised to life  because of the  acquittal secured for us.
28049	45	5	1	 Standing then acquitted as the result of faith,  let us enjoy peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ,
28050	45	5	2	 through whom also,  as the result of faith, we have obtained  an introduction into that state of favour with God in which we stand, and we exult in hope of  some day sharing in God's glory.
28051	45	5	3	 And not only so:  we also exult in our sufferings, knowing as we do, that  suffering produces fortitude;
28052	45	5	4	 fortitude, ripeness of character; and ripeness of character, hope;
28053	45	5	5	 and that  this hope never disappoints, because God's love for us  floods our hearts through the Holy Spirit who has been given  to us.
28054	45	5	6	 For already, while we were still helpless, Christ at the right moment died for the ungodly.
28055	45	5	7	 Why, it is scarcely conceivable that any one would die for a simply just man, although for a good and lovable man perhaps some one, here and there, will have the courage even to lay down his life.
28056	45	5	8	 But God gives proof of His love to us in Christ's dying for us while we were still sinners.
28057	45	5	9	 If therefore we have now been pronounced free from guilt through His blood, much more shall we be delivered from  God's anger through Him.
28058	45	5	10	 For if while we were hostile to God we were reconciled to Him through the death of His Son, it is still more certain that now that we are reconciled, we shall obtain salvation through Christ's life.
28059	45	5	11	 And not only so, but we also exult in God through our Lord Jesus Christ, through whom we have now obtained that reconciliation.
28060	45	5	12	 What follows? This comparison. Through one man sin entered into the world, and through sin death, and so death passed to all mankind in turn, in that all sinned.
28061	45	5	13	 For prior to the Law sin was already in the world; only it is not  entered in the account against us when no Law exists.
28062	45	5	14	 Yet Death reigned as king from Adam to Moses even over those who had not sinned, as Adam did, against Law. And in Adam we have a type of Him whose coming was still future.
28063	45	5	15	 But God's free gift immeasurably outweighs the  transgression. For if through the transgression of the one individual  the mass of mankind have died, infinitely greater is the generosity with which God's grace, and the gift given in His grace which found expression in the one man Jesus Christ, have been bestowed on the mass of mankind.
28064	45	5	16	 And it is not with the gift as it was with the results of one individual's sin; for the judgement which one individual provoked resulted in condemnation, whereas the free gift after a multitude of transgressions results in acquittal.
28065	45	5	17	 For if, through the transgression of the one individual, Death made use of the one individual to seize the sovereignty, all the more shall those who receive God's overflowing grace and gift of righteousness reign as kings in Life through the one individual, Jesus Christ.
28066	45	5	18	 It follows then that just as the result of a single transgression is a condemnation which extends to the whole race, so also the result of a single decree of righteousness is a  life-giving  acquittal which  extends to the whole race.
28067	45	5	19	 For as through the disobedience of the one individual the mass of mankind were constituted sinners, so also through the obedience of the One the mass of mankind will be constituted righteous.
28068	45	5	20	 Now Law was brought in later on, so  that transgression might increase. But where sin increased, grace  has overflowed;
28069	45	5	21	 in order that as sin has exercised kingly sway in inflicting death, so grace, too,  may exercise kingly sway in bestowing a righteousness which results in the Life of the Ages through Jesus Christ our Lord.
28070	45	6	1	 To what conclusion, then, shall we come? Are we to persist in sinning in order that the grace extended to us may be the greater?
28071	45	6	2	 No, indeed; how shall we who have died to sin, live in it any longer?
28072	45	6	3	 And do you not know that all of us who have been baptized  into Christ Jesus were baptized into His death?
28073	45	6	4	 Well, then,  we by our baptism were buried with Him  in death, in order that, just as Christ was raised from among the dead by the Father's  glorious power, we also should live an entirely new life.
28074	45	6	5	 For since we have become one with Him  by sharing in His death, we shall also be one with Him  by sharing in His resurrection.
28075	45	6	6	 This we know--that our old self was nailed to the cross with Him, in order that our sinful nature might be deprived of its power, so that we should no longer be the slaves of sin;
28076	45	6	7	 for he who  has paid the penalty of death  stands absolved from his sin.
28077	45	6	8	 But, seeing that we  have died with Christ, we believe that we shall also live with Him;
28078	45	6	9	 because we know that Christ, having come back to life, is no longer liable to die.
28079	45	6	10	 Death has no longer any power over Him. For by the death which He died He became, once for all, dead in relation to sin; but by the life which He now lives  He is alive in relation to God.
28080	45	6	11	 In the same way you also must regard yourselves as dead in relation to sin, but as alive in relation to God, because you are in Christ Jesus.
28081	45	6	12	 Let not Sin therefore reign as king in your mortal bodies, causing you to be in subjection to their cravings;
28082	45	6	13	 and no longer lend your faculties as unrighteous  weapons for Sin to use. On the contrary surrender your very selves to God  as living men who have risen from the dead, and surrender your several faculties to God, to be used as weapons to maintain the right.
28083	45	6	14	 For Sin shall not be lord over you, since you are subjects not of Law, but of grace.
28084	45	6	15	 Are we therefore to sin because we are no longer under the authority of Law, but under grace? No, indeed!
28085	45	6	16	 Do you not know that if you surrender yourselves as bondservants to obey any one, you  become the bondservants of him whom you obey, whether the bondservants of Sin (with death as the result) or of Duty (resulting in righteousness)?
28086	45	6	17	 But thanks be to God that though you were once in thraldom to Sin, you  have now yielded a hearty obedience to that  system of truth in which you have been  instructed.
28087	45	6	18	 You were set free from the tyranny of Sin, and became the bondservants of Righteousness--
28088	45	6	19	 your human infirmity leads me to employ these familiar figures--and just as you once surrendered your faculties into bondage to Impurity and ever-increasing disregard of Law, so you must now surrender them into bondage to Righteousness ever advancing towards perfect holiness.
28089	45	6	20	 For when you were the bondservants of sin, you were under no sort of subjection to Righteousness.
28090	45	6	21	 At that time, then, what benefit did you get from conduct which you now regard with shame? Why, such things finally result in death.
28091	45	6	22	 But now that you have been set free from the tyranny of Sin, and have become the bondservants of God, you have your reward in being made holy, and you have the Life of the Ages as the final result.
28092	45	6	23	 For the wages paid by Sin are death; but God's free gift is the Life of the Ages bestowed upon us in Christ Jesus our Lord.
28093	45	7	1	 Brethren, do you not know--for I am writing to people acquainted with the Law--that it is during our lifetime that we are subject to the Law?
28094	45	7	2	 A wife, for instance, whose husband is living is bound to him by the Law; but if her husband dies  the law that bound her to him has now no hold over her.
28095	45	7	3	 This accounts for the fact that if during her husband's life she lives with another man, she will be stigmatized as an adulteress; but that if her husband is dead she is  no longer under the old prohibition, and even though she marries again, she is not an adulteress.
28096	45	7	4	 So, my brethren,  to  you also the Law died through the  incarnation of Christ, that you might be wedded to Another, namely to Him who rose from the dead in order that  we might yield fruit to God.
28097	45	7	5	 For whilst we were under the thraldom of our earthly natures, sinful passions--  made sinful by the Law--were always  being aroused to action in our bodily faculties that they might yield fruit to death.
28098	45	7	6	 But seeing that we have died to that which once held us in bondage,  the Law has now no hold over us, so that we render a service which, instead of being old and  formal, is new and spiritual.
28099	45	7	7	 What follows? Is the Law itself a sinful thing? No, indeed; on the contrary, unless I had been taught by the Law, I  should have known nothing of sin as sin. For instance, I should not have known what covetousness is, if the Law had not  repeatedly said, <"Thou shalt not covet.">
28100	45	7	8	 Sin took advantage of this, and by means of  the Commandment stirred up within me  every kind of coveting; for apart from Law sin would be dead.
28101	45	7	9	 Once, apart from Law, I was alive, but when the Commandment came, sin  sprang into life, and I died;
28102	45	7	10	 and, as it turned out, the very Commandment which was to bring me life, brought me death.
28103	45	7	11	 For sin seized the advantage, and by means of the Commandment it completely deceived me, and  also put me to death.
28104	45	7	12	 So that the Law itself is holy, and the Commandment is holy, just and good.
28105	45	7	13	 Did then a thing which is good become death to me? No, indeed, but sin did; so that through its bringing about death by means of what was good, it might be seen in its true light as sin, in order that by means of the Commandment the unspeakable sinfulness of sin might be plainly shown.
28106	45	7	14	 For we know that the Law is a spiritual thing; but I am unspiritual--the slave, bought and sold, of sin.
28107	45	7	15	 For what I do,  I do not recognize as my own action. What I desire to do is not what I do, but what I am averse to is what I do.
28108	45	7	16	 But if I do that which I do not desire to do, I admit the excellence of the Law,
28109	45	7	17	 and now it is no longer I that do these things, but the sin which has its home within me does them.
28110	45	7	18	 For I know that in me, that is, in my  lower self, nothing good has its home; for while the will to do right  is present with me, the power to carry it out is not.
28111	45	7	19	 For what I do is not the good thing that I desire to do; but the evil thing that I desire not to do, is what I constantly do.
28112	45	7	20	 But if I do that which I desire not to do, it can no longer be said that it is I who do it, but the sin which has its home within me does it.
28113	45	7	21	 I find therefore the  law of my nature to be that when I desire to do what is right, evil is  lying in ambush for me.
28114	45	7	22	 For in my inmost self all my sympathy is with the Law of God;
28115	45	7	23	 but I discover within me  a different Law at war with the Law of my understanding, and leading me captive to the Law which  is everywhere at work in my body--the Law of sin.
28116	45	7	24	 (Unhappy man that I am! who will rescue me from this death-burdened body?
28117	45	7	25	 Thanks be to God through Jesus Christ our Lord!) To sum up then, with my understanding, I--my true self--am in servitude to the Law of God, but with my lower nature I am in servitude to the Law of sin.
28118	45	8	1	 There is therefore now no condemnation to those who are in Christ Jesus;
28119	45	8	2	 for the Spirit's Law--  telling of Life in Christ Jesus--has set  me free from the Law that deals only with sin and death.
28120	45	8	3	 For what was impossible to the Law--powerless as it was because it acted through frail  humanity--God effected. Sending His own Son in a body like that of sinful  human nature and as a sacrifice for sin, He  pronounced  sentence upon sin in human nature;
28121	45	8	4	 in order that in our case the requirements of the Law might be fully met. For our lives are regulated not by our earthly, but by our spiritual natures.
28122	45	8	5	 For if men are controlled by their earthly natures, they give their minds to earthly things. If they are controlled by their spiritual natures, they give their minds to spiritual things.
28123	45	8	6	 Because for the mind to be given up to earthly things means death; but for it to be given up to spiritual things means Life and peace.
28124	45	8	7	 Abandonment to earthly things is a state of enmity to God. Such a mind does not submit to God's Law, and indeed cannot do so.
28125	45	8	8	 And those whose hearts are absorbed in earthly things cannot please God.
28126	45	8	9	 You, however, are not devoted to earthly, but to spiritual things, if the Spirit of God is really dwelling in you; whereas if any man has not the Spirit of Christ, such a one does not belong to Him.
28127	45	8	10	 But if Christ is in you, though your body must die  because of sin, yet your spirit has Life because of righteousness.
28128	45	8	11	 And if the Spirit of Him who raised up Jesus from the dead is dwelling in you, He who raised up Christ from the dead will give Life also to your mortal bodies  because of His Spirit who dwells in you.
28129	45	8	12	 Therefore, brethren, it is not to our lower natures that we are under obligation that we should live by their rule.
28130	45	8	13	 For if you so live, death is near; but if, through being under the sway of  the spirit, you are putting  your old bodily habits to death, you will live.
28131	45	8	14	 For those who are led by God's Spirit are, all of them, God's sons.
28132	45	8	15	 You have not for the second time acquired the consciousness of being--a consciousness which fills you with terror. But you have acquired a deep inward conviction of having been adopted as sons--a conviction which prompts us to cry aloud, "Abba! our Father!"
28133	45	8	16	 The Spirit Himself bears witness, along with our own spirits, to the fact that we are children of God;
28134	45	8	17	 and if children, then heirs too--heirs of God and co-heirs with Christ; if indeed we are sharers in Christ's sufferings, in order that we may also be sharers in His glory.
28135	45	8	18	 Why, what we now suffer I count as nothing in comparison with the glory which is soon to be manifested in us.
28136	45	8	19	 For all creation, gazing eagerly as if with outstretched neck, is waiting and longing to see the manifestation of the sons of God.
28137	45	8	20	 For the Creation  fell into subjection to failure and unreality (not of its own choice, but by the will of Him who so subjected it).
28138	45	8	21	 Yet there was always the hope that at last the Creation itself would also be set free from the thraldom of decay so as to enjoy the liberty that will attend the glory of the children of God.
28139	45	8	22	 For we know that the whole of Creation is groaning together in the pains of childbirth until this hour.
28140	45	8	23	 And more than that,  we ourselves, though we possess the Spirit as a foretaste and pledge of the glorious future, yet we ourselves inwardly sigh, as we wait and long for open recognition as sons through the  deliverance of our bodies.
28141	45	8	24	 It is *in hope* that we have been saved. But  an object of hope is such no longer when it is present to view;  for when a man has a thing before his eyes, how can he be said to hope for it?
28142	45	8	25	 But if we hope for something which we do not see, then we eagerly and patiently wait for it.
28143	45	8	26	 In the same way the Spirit also helps us in our weakness; for we do not know what prayers to offer nor in what way to offer them. But the Spirit Himself pleads for us in yearnings that can find no words,
28144	45	8	27	 and the Searcher of hearts knows what the Spirit's meaning is,  because His intercessions for God's people are in harmony with God's will.
28145	45	8	28	 Now we know that for those who love God  all things are working together for good--for those, I mean, whom with deliberate purpose He has called.
28146	45	8	29	 For those whom He has  known beforehand He has also pre-destined to bear the likeness of His Son, that He might be the Eldest in a vast family of brothers;
28147	45	8	30	 and those whom He has pre-destined He also has called; and those whom He has called He has also declared free from guilt; and those whom He has declared free from guilt He has also crowned with glory.
28148	45	8	31	 What then shall we say to this? If God is on our side, who is there to appear against us?
28149	45	8	32	 He who did not withhold even His own Son, but gave Him up for all of us, will He not also with Him freely give us all things?
28150	45	8	33	 Who shall impeach those whom God has chosen?  God declares them free from guilt.
28151	45	8	34	 Who is there to condemn them? Christ  Jesus died, or rather has risen to life again.  He is also at the right hand of God, and is interceding for us.
28152	45	8	35	 Who shall separate us from Christ's love? Shall affliction or distress, persecution or hunger, nakedness or danger or the sword?
28153	45	8	36	 As it stands written in the Scripture, <"For Thy sake they are, all day long, trying to kill us. We have been looked upon as sheep destined for slaughter.">
28154	45	8	37	 Yet amid all these things we are  more than conquerors through Him who has loved us.
28155	45	8	38	 For I am convinced that neither death nor life, neither the lower ranks of evil angels nor the higher, neither things present nor  things future, nor the  forces of nature,
28156	45	8	39	 nor height nor depth, nor any other created thing, will be able to separate us from the love of God which rests upon us in Christ Jesus our Lord.
28157	45	9	1	 I am telling you the truth as a Christian man--it is no falsehood, for my conscience enlightened, as it is, by the Holy Spirit adds its testimony to mine--
28158	45	9	2	 when I declare that I have deep grief and unceasing anguish of heart.
28159	45	9	3	 For  I could pray to be  accursed from Christ on behalf of my brethren, my human kinsfolk--for such the Israelites are.
28160	45	9	4	 To them belongs recognition as God's sons, and they have His glorious Presence and the Covenants, and the giving of the Law, and the Temple service, and  the ancient Promises.
28161	45	9	5	 To them the Patriarchs belong, and from them in respect of His human lineage came the Christ, who is exalted above all, God blessed throughout the Ages. Amen.
28162	45	9	6	 Not however that God's word has failed; for all who have sprung from Israel do not count as Israel,
28163	45	9	7	 nor because they are Abraham's true children. But the promise was <"Through Isaac shall your posterity be reckoned.">
28164	45	9	8	 In other words, it is not the children by natural descent who count as God's children, but the children made such by the promise are regarded as Abraham's posterity.
28165	45	9	9	 For the words are the language of promise and run thus, <"About this time next year I will come, and Sarah shall have a son.">
28166	45	9	10	 Nor is that all:  later on there was Rebecca too. She was soon to bear two children to her husband, our forefather Isaac--
28167	45	9	11	 and even then, though they were not then born and had not done anything either good or evil, yet in order that God's electing purpose might not be frustrated, based, as it was, not on their actions but on the will of Him who called them, she was told,
28168	45	9	12	 <"The elder of them will be bondservant to the younger.">
28169	45	9	13	 This agrees with the other Scripture which says, <"Jacob I  have loved, but Esau I  have hated.">
28170	45	9	14	 What then are we to infer? That there is injustice in God?
28171	45	9	15	 No, indeed; the solution is found in His words to Moses, <"Wherever I show mercy it shall be nothing but mercy, and wherever I show compassion it shall be simply compassion.">
28172	45	9	16	 And from this we learn that everything  is dependent not on man's will or  endeavour, but upon God who has mercy. For the Scripture said to Pharaoh,
28173	45	9	17	 <"It is for this very purpose that I have lifted you so high--that I may make manifest in you My power, and that My name may be proclaimed far and wide in all the earth.">
28174	45	9	18	 This is a proof that wherever He chooses He shows mercy, and wherever he chooses He  hardens the heart.
28175	45	9	19	 "Why then does God still find fault?" you will ask; "for who is resisting His will?"
28176	45	9	20	 Nay, but who are you,  a mere man, that you should cavil against GOD? <Shall the thing moulded say to him who moulded it, "Why have you made me thus?">
28177	45	9	21	 Or has not the potter rightful power over the clay to make out of the same lump one vessel for more honourable and another for less honourable uses?
28178	45	9	22	 And what if God, while choosing to make manifest the terrors of His anger and to show what is possible with Him, has yet borne with long-forbearing patience with the subjects of His anger who  stand ready for destruction,
28179	45	9	23	  in order to make known  His infinite goodness towards the subjects of His mercy whom He has  prepared beforehand for glory,
28180	45	9	24	 even towards us whom He has called not only from among the Jews but also from among the Gentiles?
28181	45	9	25	 So also in Hosea He says, <"I will call that nation My People which was not My People, and I will call her beloved who was not beloved.
28182	45	9	26	 And in the place where it was said to them, `No people of Mine are you,' there shall they be called sons of the  everliving God.">
28183	45	9	27	 And Isaiah cries aloud concerning Israel, <"Though the number of the sons of Israel be like the sands of the sea, only a remnant of them shall be saved;
28184	45	9	28	 for the Lord will  hold a reckoning upon the earth, making it efficacious and brief.">
28185	45	9	29	 Even as Isaiah  says in an earlier place, <"Were it not that the Lord, the God of  Hosts, had left us some few descendants, we should have become like Sodom, and have come to resemble Gomorrah.">
28186	45	9	30	 To what conclusion does this bring us? Why, that the  Gentiles, who were not in  pursuit of righteousness, have overtaken it--a righteousness, however, which arises from faith;
28187	45	9	31	 while  the descendants of Israel, who were in pursuit of a Law that could give righteousness, have not arrived at one.
28188	45	9	32	 And why? Because they were pursuing a righteousness which should arise not from faith, but from  what they regarded as merit. They stuck their foot against the stone which lay in their way;
28189	45	9	33	 in agreement with the statement of Scripture, <"See, I am placing on Mount Zion a stone for people to stumble at, and a rock for them to trip over, and yet he whose faith rests upon it shall never have reason to feel ashamed.">
28190	45	10	1	 Brethren, the  longing of my heart, and my prayer to God, on behalf of my countrymen is for their salvation.
28191	45	10	2	 For I bear witness that they possess an enthusiasm for God, but it is an unenlightened enthusiasm.
28192	45	10	3	 Ignorant of the righteousness which God provides and  building their hopes upon a  righteousness of their own, they have refused submission to God's righteousness.
28193	45	10	4	 For as a means of righteousness Christ is the  termination of Law to every believer.
28194	45	10	5	 Moses  says that he whose actions conform to the righteousness required by the Law shall live by that righteousness.
28195	45	10	6	 But the righteousness which is based on faith speaks in a different tone. "Say not in your heart," it declares, "`Who shall ascend to Heaven?'" --that is, to bring Christ down;
28196	45	10	7	 "nor `Who shall go down into the  abyss?'" --that is, to bring Christ  up again from the grave.
28197	45	10	8	 But what does it say? "The Message is close to you, in your mouth and in your heart;" that is, the Message which we are publishing about the faith--
28198	45	10	9	 that if with your mouth you confess Jesus as Lord and in your heart believe that God brought Him back to life, you shall be saved.
28199	45	10	10	 For with the heart men believe and obtain righteousness, and with the mouth they make confession and obtain salvation.
28200	45	10	11	 The Scripture says, <"No one who believes in Him shall have reason to feel ashamed.">
28201	45	10	12	 Jew and Gentile are on precisely the same footing; for the same Lord is Lord over all,  and is infinitely kind to all who call upon Him for deliverance.
28202	45	10	13	 For <"every one, without exception, who calls on the name of the Lord shall be saved.">
28203	45	10	14	 But how are they to call on One in whom they have not believed? And how are they to believe in One whose voice they have never heard? And how are they to hear without a preacher?
28204	45	10	15	 And how are men to preach unless they have been sent to do so? As it is written, <"How beautiful are the feet of those who bring glad tidings of good!">
28205	45	10	16	 But, some will say, they have not all hearkened to the Good News. No, for Isaiah asks, <"Lord, who has believed the Message they have heard from us?">
28206	45	10	17	 And this proves that faith comes from a Message heard, and that the Message comes through its having been spoken by Christ.
28207	45	10	18	 But, I ask, have they not heard? Yes, indeed: <"To the whole world  the preachers' voices have sounded forth, and their words to the remotest parts of the earth.">
28208	45	10	19	 But again, did Israel fail to  understand? Listen to Moses first. He says, <"I will fire you with jealousy against a nation which is no nation, and with fury against a nation devoid of understanding.">
28209	45	10	20	 And Isaiah, with strange boldness, exclaims, <"I have been found by those who were not looking for Me, I have revealed Myself to those who were not inquiring of Me.">
28210	45	10	21	 While as to Israel he says, <"All day long I have stretched out My  arms to a self-willed and fault-finding people.">
28211	45	11	1	 I ask then, Has God cast off His People? No, indeed. Why, I myself am an Israelite, of the posterity of Abraham and of the tribe of Benjamin.
28212	45	11	2	 God has not cast off His People whom He knew beforehand. Or are you ignorant of what Scripture says in speaking of Elijah--how he pleaded with God against Israel, saying,
28213	45	11	3	 <"Lord, they have put Thy Prophets to death, and have  overthrown Thy altars; and, now that I alone remain, they are thirsting for my blood"?>
28214	45	11	4	 But what did God say to him in reply? <"I have reserved for Myself 7,000 men who have never bent the knee to Baal.">
28215	45	11	5	 In the same way also at the present time there has come to be a remnant whom God in His grace has selected.
28216	45	11	6	 But if it is in His grace that He has selected them, then His choice is no longer determined by human actions. Otherwise grace would be grace no longer.
28217	45	11	7	 How then does the matter stand? It stands thus. That which Israel are in earnest pursuit of, they have not obtained; but God's chosen servants have obtained it, and the rest have become hardened.
28218	45	11	8	 And so Scripture says, <"God has given them a spirit of drowsiness--eyes to see nothing with and ears to hear nothing with--even until now.">
28219	45	11	9	 And David says, <"Let their very food become a snare and a trap to them, a stumbling-block and a retribution.
28220	45	11	10	 Let darkness come over their eyes that they may be unable to see, and make Thou their backs continually to stoop.">
28221	45	11	11	 I ask, however, "Have they stumbled so as to be finally ruined?" No, indeed; but by their lapse salvation has come to the Gentiles in order to arouse the jealousy of the descendants of Israel;
28222	45	11	12	 and if their lapse is the  enriching of the world, and their overthrow the  enriching of the Gentiles, will not still greater good follow their restoration?
28223	45	11	13	 But to you Gentiles I say that,  since I am an Apostle specially sent to the Gentiles, I take pride in my ministry,
28224	45	11	14	 trying whether I can succeed in rousing my own countrymen to jealousy and thus save some of them.
28225	45	11	15	 For if their having been cast aside has carried with it the reconciliation of the world, what will their being accepted again be but Life out of death?
28226	45	11	16	 Now if the firstfruits of the dough are holy, so also is the whole mass; and if the root of a tree is holy, so also are the branches.
28227	45	11	17	 And if some of the branches have been pruned away, and you, although you were but a wild olive, have been grafted in among them and have become a sharer with others in the  rich sap of the root of the olive tree,
28228	45	11	18	 beware of glorying over the natural branches. Or if you are so glorying, do not forget that it is not you who uphold the root: the root upholds you.
28229	45	11	19	 "Branches have been lopped off," you will say, "for the sake of my being grafted in."
28230	45	11	20	 This is true; yet it was their unbelief that cut them off, and you only stand through your faith.
28231	45	11	21	 Do not be puffed up with pride. Tremble rather--for if God did not spare the natural branches, neither will He spare you.
28232	45	11	22	 Notice therefore God's kindness and God's severity. On those who have fallen His severity has descended, but upon you His kindness has come, provided that you do not cease to respond to that kindness. Otherwise you will be cut off also.
28233	45	11	23	 Moreover, if they turn from their unbelief, they too will be grafted in. For God is powerful enough to graft them in again;
28234	45	11	24	  and if you were cut from that which by nature is a wild olive and contrary to nature were grafted into the good olive tree, how much more certainly will these natural branches be grafted on their own olive tree?
28235	45	11	25	 For there is a truth, brethren, not revealed hitherto, of which I do not wish to leave you in ignorance, for fear you should attribute superior wisdom to yourselves--the truth, I mean, that partial blindness has fallen upon Israel until the great mass of the  Gentiles have come in;
28236	45	11	26	 and so all Israel will be saved. As is declared in Scripture, <"From Mount Zion  a Deliverer will come: He will remove  all ungodliness from  Jacob;
28237	45	11	27	 and this shall be My Covenant with them; when I have taken away their sins.">
28238	45	11	28	 In relation to the Good News, the Jews are God's enemies for your sakes; but in relation to God's choice they are dearly loved for the sake of their forefathers.
28239	45	11	29	 For God does not repent of His free gifts nor of His call;
28240	45	11	30	  but just as you were formerly disobedient to Him, but now have received mercy at a time when they are disobedient,
28241	45	11	31	 so now they also have been disobedient at a time when you are receiving mercy; so that to them too there  may now be mercy.
28242	45	11	32	 For God has locked up all in the prison of unbelief, that upon all alike He may have mercy.
28243	45	11	33	 Oh, how inexhaustible are God's resources and God's wisdom and God's knowledge! How impossible it is to search into His decrees or trace His footsteps!
28244	45	11	34	 <"Who has ever known the mind of the Lord, or shared His counsels?"
28245	45	11	35	 "Who has first given God anything, so as to receive payment in return?">
28246	45	11	36	 For the universe owes its origin to Him, was created by Him, and has its aim and purpose in Him. To Him be the glory throughout the Ages! Amen.
28247	45	12	1	 I plead with you therefore, brethren, by the  compassionsof God, to present  all your faculties to Him as a living and holy sacrifice acceptable to Him. This with you will be an act of reasonable worship.
28248	45	12	2	 And do not follow the customs of the present age, but be transformed by the entire renewal of your minds, so that you may  learn by experience what God's will is--that will which is good and beautiful and perfect.
28249	45	12	3	 For through the  authority graciously given to me I warn every individual among you  not to value himself unduly, but to cultivate sobriety of judgement in accordance with the amount of faith which God has allotted to each one.
28250	45	12	4	 For just as there are in the one human body many parts, and these parts have not all the same function;
28251	45	12	5	 so collectively we form one body in Christ, while individually we are linked to one another as its members.
28252	45	12	6	 But since we have special gifts which differ in accordance with the diversified  work graciously entrusted to us, if it is prophecy, let the prophet speak  in exact proportion to his faith;
28253	45	12	7	 if it is the gift of  administration, let the administrator exercise a sound judgement in his duties.
28254	45	12	8	 The teacher must do the same in his teaching; and he who exhorts others, in his exhortation. He who gives should be liberal; he who is in authority should be energetic and alert; and he who succours the afflicted should do it cheerfully.
28255	45	12	9	 Let your love be perfectly sincere. Regard with horror what is evil; cling to what is right.
28256	45	12	10	 As for brotherly love, be affectionate to one another; in matters of worldly honour, yield to one another.
28257	45	12	11	 Do not be indolent when zeal is required. Be thoroughly warm-hearted,  the Lord's own servants,
28258	45	12	12	 full of joyful hope, patient under persecution, earnest and persistent in prayer.
28259	45	12	13	 Relieve the necessities of God's people; always practise hospitality.
28260	45	12	14	 Invoke blessings on your persecutors--blessings, not curses.
28261	45	12	15	 Rejoice with those who rejoice; weep with those who weep.
28262	45	12	16	 Have full sympathy with one another. Do not give your mind to high things, but  let humble ways content you. <Do not be wise in your own conceits.>
28263	45	12	17	 Pay back to no man evil for evil. <Take thought for what is right and seemly in every one's esteem.>
28264	45	12	18	 If you can, so far as it depends on you, live at peace with all the world.
28265	45	12	19	 Do not be revengeful, my dear friends, but give way before  anger; for it is written, <"`Revenge belongs to Me: I will pay back,'> says the Lord."
28266	45	12	20	 On the contrary, therefore, <if your enemy is hungry, give him food; if he is thirsty, quench his thirst. For by doing this you will be  heaping burning coals upon his head.>
28267	45	12	21	 Do not be overcome by evil, but overcome the evil with goodness.
28268	45	13	1	 Let every individual be obedient to those who rule over him; for no one is a ruler except by God's permission, and our present rulers have had their rank and power assigned to them by Him.
28269	45	13	2	 Therefore the man who rebels against his ruler is resisting God's will; and those who thus resist will bring punishment upon themselves.
28270	45	13	3	 For judges and magistrates  are to be feared not by right-doers but by wrong-doers. You desire--do you not? --to have no reason to fear your ruler. Well, do the thing that is right, and then he will commend you.
28271	45	13	4	 For he is God's servant for your benefit. But if you do what is wrong, be afraid. He does not wear the sword to no purpose: he is God's servant--an administrator to inflict  punishment upon evil-doers.
28272	45	13	5	 We must obey therefore, not only in order to escape punishment, but also for conscience' sake.
28273	45	13	6	 Why, this is really the reason you pay  taxes; for  tax-gatherers are  ministers of God, devoting their energies to this very work.
28274	45	13	7	 Pay  promptly to all men what is due to them: taxes to those to whom taxes are due, toll to those to whom toll is due, respect to those to whom respect is due, honour to those to whom honour is due.
28275	45	13	8	 Owe nothing to any one except  mutual love; for he who loves his fellow man has satisfied the demands of Law.
28276	45	13	9	 For the precepts, <"Thou shalt not commit adultery," "Thou shalt do no murder," "Thou shalt not steal," "Thou shalt not covet,"> and all other precepts, are summed up in this one command, <"Thou shalt love thy fellow man as much as thou lovest thyself.">
28277	45	13	10	 Love avoids doing any wrong to one's fellow man, and is therefore complete obedience to Law.
28278	45	13	11	 Carry out these injunctions because you know the critical period at which we are living, and that it is now high time,  to rouse yourselves from sleep; for salvation is now nearer to us than when we  first became believers.
28279	45	13	12	 The night is far advanced, and day is about to dawn. We must therefore lay aside the deeds of darkness, and clothe ourselves with the armour of Light.
28280	45	13	13	 Living as we do in broad daylight, let us conduct ourselves becomingly, not indulging in revelry and drunkenness, nor in lust and debauchery, nor in quarrelling and  jealousy.
28281	45	13	14	 On the contrary, clothe yourselves with the Lord Jesus Christ, and make no provision for gratifying your earthly cravings.
28282	45	14	1	 I now pass to another subject. Receive as a friend a man whose faith is weak, but not for the purpose of deciding  mere matters of opinion.
28283	45	14	2	 One man's faith allows him to eat anything, while a man of weaker faith eats nothing but vegetables.
28284	45	14	3	 Let not him who eats certain food look down upon him who abstains from it, nor him who abstains from it find fault with him who eats it; for God has received both of them.
28285	45	14	4	 Who are you that you should find fault with the servant of another?  Whether he stands or falls is a matter which concerns his own master. But stand he will; for the Master can give him power to stand.
28286	45	14	5	 One man esteems one day more highly than another; another esteems all days alike. Let every one be thoroughly convinced in his own mind.
