28287	45	14	6	 He who regards the day as sacred, so regards it for the Master's sake; and he who eats certain food eats it for the Master's sake, for he gives thanks to God; and he who refrains from eating it refrains for the Master's sake, and he also gives thanks to God.
28288	45	14	7	 For not one of us lives to himself, and not one dies to himself.
28289	45	14	8	 If we live, we live to the Lord: if we die, we die to the Lord. So whether we live or die, we belong to the Lord.
28290	45	14	9	 For this was the purpose of Christ's dying and coming to life--namely that He might be Lord both of the dead and the living.
28291	45	14	10	 But you, why do you find fault with your brother? Or you, why do you look down upon your brother? We shall all stand before God to be judged;
28292	45	14	11	 for it is written, <"`As I live,'> says the Lord, <`to Me every knee shall bow, and every tongue shall make confession to God.'">
28293	45	14	12	 So we see that every one of us will give account of himself to God.
28294	45	14	13	 Therefore let us no longer judge one another; but, instead of that, you should come to this judgement--that we must not put a stumbling-block in our brother's path, nor anything to trip him up.
28295	45	14	14	 As one who lives in union with the Lord Jesus, I know and am certain that in its own nature  no food is `impure'; but if people regard any food as impure, to them it is.
28296	45	14	15	 If your brother is pained by the food you are eating, your conduct is no longer controlled by love.  Take care lest, by the food you eat, you lead to ruin a man for whom Christ died.
28297	45	14	16	 Therefore do not let  the boon which is yours  in common  be exposed to reproach.
28298	45	14	17	 For the Kingdom of God does not consist of eating and drinking, but of right conduct, peace and joy, through the Holy Spirit;
28299	45	14	18	 and whoever in this way devotedly serves Christ, God takes pleasure in him, and men  highly commend him.
28300	45	14	19	 Therefore let us aim at whatever makes for peace and mutual upbuilding of character.
28301	45	14	20	 Do not for food's sake be throwing down God's work.  All food is pure; but a man is in the wrong if his food is a snare  to others.
28302	45	14	21	 The right course is to forego eating meat or drinking wine or doing anything that tends to your brother's  fall.
28303	45	14	22	 As for you and your faith, keep your faith to yourself in the presence of God. The man is to be congratulated who does not pronounce judgement on himself in what his actions sanction.
28304	45	14	23	 But he who has misgivings and yet eats meat is condemned already, because his conduct is not based on faith; for all conduct not based on faith is sinful.
28305	45	15	1	 As for us who are strong, our duty is to bear with the weaknesses of those who are not strong, and not seek our own pleasure.
28306	45	15	2	 Let each of us endeavour to please his fellow Christian, aiming at a blessing calculated to build him up.
28307	45	15	3	 For even the Christ did not seek His own pleasure. His principle was, <"The reproaches which they  addressed to Thee have fallen on me.">
28308	45	15	4	 For all that was written of old has been written for our instruction, so that we may always have hope through the power of endurance and the  encouragement which the Scriptures afford.
28309	45	15	5	 And may God,  the giver of power of endurance and of that encouragement, grant you to be in full sympathy with one another in accordance with the example of Christ Jesus,
28310	45	15	6	 so that with oneness both of heart and voice you may glorify the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ.
28311	45	15	7	 Habitually therefore give one another a friendly reception, just as Christ also has received you, and thus promote the glory of God.
28312	45	15	8	  My meaning is that Christ has become  a servant to the people of Israel in vindication of God's truthfulness--  in showing how sure are the promises made to our forefathers--
28313	45	15	9	 and that the Gentiles also have glorified God in acknowledgment of His mercy. So it is written, <"For this reason I will praise Thee among the Gentiles, and sing psalms in honour of Thy name.">
28314	45	15	10	 And again the Psalmist says, <"Be glad, ye Gentiles, in company with His People.">
28315	45	15	11	 And again, <"Praise the Lord, all ye Gentiles, and let all the people extol Him.">
28316	45	15	12	 And again Isaiah says, <"There shall be the Root of Jesse and One who rises up to rule the Gentiles. On Him shall the Gentiles build their hopes.">
28317	45	15	13	 May God, the giver of hope, fill you with  continual joy and peace  because you trust in Him--so that you may have abundant hope through the power of the Holy Spirit.
28318	45	15	14	 But as to you, brethren, I am convinced--  yes, I Paul am convinced--that, even apart from my teaching, you are already full of goodness of heart, and enriched with complete Christian knowledge, and are also competent to instruct one another.
28319	45	15	15	 But I write to you the more boldly--partly as reminding you of what you already know--because of the  authority graciously entrusted to me by God,
28320	45	15	16	 that I should be a minister of Christ Jesus among the Gentiles, doing priestly duties in connexion with God's Good News so that the sacrifice--namely the Gentiles--may be acceptable to Him, being (as it is) an offering which the Holy Spirit has made holy.
28321	45	15	17	 I can therefore glory in Christ Jesus concerning the work for God in which I am engaged.
28322	45	15	18	 For I will not presume to mention any of the results that Christ has brought about by other agency than mine in securing the obedience of the Gentiles by word or deed,
28323	45	15	19	 with power manifested in signs and marvels, and through the power of the Holy Spirit.  But--to speak simply of my own labours--beginning in Jerusalem and the outlying districts, I  have proclaimed without reserve, even as far as Illyricum, the Good News of the Christ;
28324	45	15	20	 making it my ambition, however, not to tell the Good News where Christ's name was already known, for fear I should be building on another man's foundation.
28325	45	15	21	 But, as Scripture says, <"Those shall see, to whom no report about Him has hitherto come, and those who until now have not heard shall understand.">
28326	45	15	22	 And it is really  this which has again and again prevented my coming to you.
28327	45	15	23	 But now, as there is no more unoccupied ground in this part of the world, and I have for years past been eager to pay you a visit,
28328	45	15	24	 I hope, as soon as ever I extend my travels into Spain, to see you on my way and be helped forward by you on my journey, when I have first enjoyed being with you for a time.
28329	45	15	25	 But at present I am going to Jerusalem to serve God's people,
28330	45	15	26	 for Macedonia and Greece have kindly contributed a certain sum in relief of the poor among God's people, in Jerusalem.
28331	45	15	27	 Yes, they have kindly done this, and, in fact, it was a debt they owed them. For seeing that the Gentiles have been admitted in to partnership with the Jews in their spiritual blessings, they in turn are under an obligation to render sacred service to the Jews in temporal things.
28332	45	15	28	 So after  discharging this duty, and making sure that these kind gifts reach  those for whom they are intended, I shall start for Spain, passing through Rome on my way there;
28333	45	15	29	 and I know that when I come to you it will be with a vast amount of blessing from Christ.
28334	45	15	30	  But I entreat you, brethren, in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ and by the love which His Spirit inspires, to help me by wrestling in prayer to God on my behalf,
28335	45	15	31	 asking that I may escape unhurt from those in Judaea who are disobedient, and that the service which I am going to Jerusalem to render may be well received by the Church there,
28336	45	15	32	 in order that if God be willing I may come to you with a glad heart, and may enjoy a time of rest with you.
28337	45	15	33	 May God, who gives peace be with you all! Amen.
28338	45	16	1	 Herewith I introduce our sister Phoebe to you,  who is a  servant of the Church at Cenchreae,
28339	45	16	2	 that you may receive her as a fellow Christian in a manner worthy of God's people, and may assist her in any matter in which she may need help. For she has indeed been a kind friend to many, including myself.
28340	45	16	3	 Greetings to Prisca and Aquila my fellow labourers in the work of Christ Jesus--
28341	45	16	4	 friends who have endangered their own lives for mine. I am grateful to them, and not I alone, but all the Gentile Churches also.
28342	45	16	5	 Greetings, too, to  the Church that meets at their house. Greetings to my dear Epaenetus, who was the earliest convert to Christ in the province of Asia;
28343	45	16	6	 to Mary who has laboured strenuously among you;
28344	45	16	7	 and to Andronicus and  Junia, my  countrymen, who once shared my imprisonment. They  are of note among the Apostles, and  are Christians of longer standing than myself.
28345	45	16	8	 Greetings to Ampliatus, dear to me in the Lord;
28346	45	16	9	 to Urban, our fellow labourer in Christ, and to my dear Stachys.
28347	45	16	10	 Greetings to Apella, that veteran believer; and to the members of the household of Aristobulus.
28348	45	16	11	 Greetings to my countryman, Herodion; and to the believing members of the household of Narcissus.
28349	45	16	12	 Greetings to those Christian workers, Tryphaena and Tryphosa; also to dear Persis, who has laboured strenuously in the Lord's work.
28350	45	16	13	 Greetings to Rufus, who is one of the Lord's chosen people; and to his mother, who has also been a mother to me.
28351	45	16	14	 Greetings to Asyncritus, Phlegon, Hermes, Patrobas, Hermas, and to the brethren associated with them;
28352	45	16	15	 to Philologus and Julia, Nereus and his sister and Olympas, and to all God's people associated with them.
28353	45	16	16	 Salute one another with a holy kiss. All the Churches of Christ send greetings to you.
28354	45	16	17	 But I beseech you, brethren, to keep a watch on those who are causing the divisions among you, and are leading others into sin, in defiance of the instruction which you have received; and  habitually to shun them.
28355	45	16	18	 For men of that stamp are not bondservants of Christ our Lord, but are slaves to their own appetites; and by their plausible words and their flattery they utterly deceive the minds of the simple.
28356	45	16	19	 Your  fidelity to the truth is everywhere known. I rejoice over you, therefore, but I wish you to be wise as to what is good, and simple-minded as to what is evil.
28357	45	16	20	 And  before long, God  the giver of peace will crush Satan under your feet. The grace of our Lord Jesus  Christ be with you!
28358	45	16	21	 Timothy, my fellow worker, sends you greetings, and so do my countrymen Lucius, Jason and Sosipater.
28359	45	16	22	 I, Tertius, who write this letter, send you Christian greetings.
28360	45	16	23	 Gaius, my host, who is also the host  of the whole Church, greets you. So do Erastus, the treasurer of the city, and Quartus our brother.
28361	45	16	24	  []
28362	45	16	25	  To Him who has it in His power to make you strong, as declared in the Good News which I am spreading, and the proclamation concerning Jesus Christ, in harmony with the unveiling of the Truth which in the periods of past Ages remained unuttered,
28363	45	16	26	 but has now been brought fully to light, and by the command of the God of the Ages has been made known by the writings of the Prophets among all the Gentiles to win them to  obedience to the faith--
28364	45	16	27	 to God, the only wise, through Jesus Christ,  even to Him be the glory through all the Ages! Amen.
28365	46	1	1	 Paul, called to be an Apostle of  Christ Jesus through the will of God--and our brother Sosthenes:
28366	46	1	2	 To the Church of God in Corinth, men and women  consecrated in Christ Jesus, called  to be  saints, with all in every place who call on the name of our Lord Jesus Christ--  their Lord as well as ours.
28367	46	1	3	 May grace and peace be granted to you from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
28368	46	1	4	 I thank my God continually on your behalf for the grace of God bestowed on you  in Christ Jesus--
28369	46	1	5	 that you have been  so richly blessed in Him, with readiness of speech and fulness of knowledge.
28370	46	1	6	 Thus my testimony as to the Christ has been confirmed in your experience,
28371	46	1	7	 so that there is no gift of God in which you  consciously come short while patiently waiting for the reappearing of our Lord Jesus Christ,
28372	46	1	8	 who will also keep you stedfast to the very End, so that you will be free from reproach on the day of our Lord Jesus Christ.
28373	46	1	9	 God is ever true to His promises, and it was by Him that you were, one and all, called  into fellowship with his Son Jesus Christ, our Lord.
28374	46	1	10	 Now I entreat you, brethren, in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, to  cultivate a spirit of harmony--all of you--and that there be no divisions among you, but rather a perfect union through your having one mind and one judgement.
28375	46	1	11	 For I have been distinctly informed, my brethren, about you by Chloe's people, that there are dissensions among you.
28376	46	1	12	 What I mean is that each of you is a partisan. One man says "I belong to Paul;" another "I belong to Apollos;" a third "I belong to  Peter;" a fourth "I belong to Christ."
28377	46	1	13	 Is the Christ  in fragments? Is it Paul who was crucified on your behalf? Or were you baptized  to be Paul's adherents?
28378	46	1	14	 I thank God that I did not baptize any of you except Crispus and Gaius--
28379	46	1	15	 for fear people should say that you were baptized  to be my adherents.
28380	46	1	16	 I did, however, baptize Stephanas' household also: but I do not think that I baptized any one else.
28381	46	1	17	 Christ did not send me to baptize, but to proclaim the Good News; and not in merely wise words--lest the Cross of Christ should be deprived of its power.
28382	46	1	18	 For  the Message of the Cross is  foolishness to those who are on the way to perdition, but it is the power of God to those whom He is saving.
28383	46	1	19	 For so it stands written, <"I will exhibit the nothingness of the wisdom of  the wise, and the intelligence of the intelligent I will bring to nought.">
28384	46	1	20	 Where is your wise man? Where your expounder of the Law? Where your investigator of the questions of this present age? Has not God shown the world's wisdom to be utter foolishness?
28385	46	1	21	 For after the world by its wisdom--as God in His wisdom had ordained--had failed to gain the knowledge of God, God was pleased, by the apparent foolishness of the Message which we preach, to save those who accepted it.
28386	46	1	22	 Seeing that Jews demand  miracles, and Greeks go in search of wisdom,
28387	46	1	23	 while we proclaim a Christ who has been crucified--to the Jews a stumbling-block, to Gentiles foolishness,
28388	46	1	24	 but to those who have received the Call, whether Jews or Greeks, Christ the power of God and the wisdom of God.
28389	46	1	25	 Because that which the world deems foolish in God is wiser than men's wisdom, and that which it deems feeble in God is mightier than men's might.
28390	46	1	26	 For consider, brethren, God's call to you.  Not many who are wise with merely human wisdom, not many of position and influence, not many of noble birth have been called.
28391	46	1	27	 But God has chosen the things which the world regards as foolish, in order to put its wise men to shame; and God has chosen the things which the world regards as destitute of influence, in order to put its powerful things to shame;
28392	46	1	28	 and the things which the world regards as base, and those which it sets utterly at nought--things  that have no existence--God has chosen in order to reduce to nothing things that do exist;
28393	46	1	29	 to prevent any mortal man from boasting in the presence of God.
28394	46	1	30	 But you--and it is all God's doing--are in Christ Jesus: He has become for us a wisdom which is from God, consisting of righteousness and sanctification and  deliverance;
28395	46	1	31	 in order that it may be as Scripture says, <"He who boasts--let his boast be in the Lord.">
28396	46	2	1	 And as for myself, brethren, when I came to you, it was not with surpassing power of eloquence or earthly wisdom that I came, announcing to you  that which God had commanded me to bear witness to.
28397	46	2	2	  For I determined to be utterly ignorant, when among you, of everything except of Jesus Christ, and of Him as having been crucified.
28398	46	2	3	 And so far as I myself was concerned, I came to you  in conscious feebleness and in fear and in deep anxiety.
28399	46	2	4	 And my language and the Message that I proclaimed were not adorned with persuasive words of earthly wisdom, but depended upon truths which the Spirit taught and mightily carried home;
28400	46	2	5	 so that your trust might rest not on the wisdom of man but on the power of God.
28401	46	2	6	 Yet when we are among mature believers we do speak words of wisdom; a wisdom not belonging, however, to the present age nor to the leaders of the present age who are soon to pass away.
28402	46	2	7	 But in dealing with truths hitherto kept secret we speak of God's wisdom--that hidden wisdom which, before the world began, God pre-destined, so that it should result in glory to us;
28403	46	2	8	 a wisdom which not one of the leaders of the present age  possesses, for if they had  possessed it, they would never have crucified the Lord of glory.
28404	46	2	9	 But--to use the words of Scripture--we speak of <things which eye has not seen nor ear heard,> and which have never entered the heart of man: <all that God has in readiness for them that love Him.>
28405	46	2	10	 For us, however, God has drawn aside the veil through the teaching of the Spirit; for the Spirit searches everything, including the depths of the divine nature.
28406	46	2	11	 For, among human beings, who knows a man's inner thoughts except the man's own spirit within him? In the same way, also, only God's Spirit is acquainted with God's inner thoughts.
28407	46	2	12	 But we have not received  the spirit of the world, but the Spirit which comes forth from God, that we may know the blessings that have been so freely given to us by God.
28408	46	2	13	 Of these we speak--not in language which man's wisdom teaches us, but in that which the Spirit teaches--adapting, as we do, spiritual words to spiritual  truths.
28409	46	2	14	 The  unspiritual man rejects the  things of the Spirit of God, and cannot attain to the knowledge of them, because they are spiritually judged.
28410	46	2	15	 But the spiritual man judges of everything, although he is himself judged by no one.
28411	46	2	16	 For <who has penetrated the mind of the Lord, and will instruct Him?> But *we* have the mind of Christ.
28412	46	3	1	 And as for myself, brethren, I found it impossible to speak to you as spiritual men. It had to be as to worldlings--mere babes in Christ.
28413	46	3	2	  I fed you with milk and not with solid food, since for this you were not yet strong enough. And even now you are not strong enough:
28414	46	3	3	 you are still unspiritual. For  so long as jealousy and strife continue among you, can it be denied that you are unspiritual and are living and acting like mere men of the world?
28415	46	3	4	 For when some one says, "I belong to Paul," and another says, "I belong to Apollos," is not this the way men of the world speak?
28416	46	3	5	 What then is Apollos? And what is Paul? They are just God's servants, through whose efforts, and as the Lord granted power to each, you accepted the faith.
28417	46	3	6	 I planted and Apollos watered; but it was God who was, all the time, giving the increase.
28418	46	3	7	 So that neither the planter nor the waterer is of any importance. God who gives the increase is all in all.
28419	46	3	8	 Now in aim and purpose the planter and the waterer are one; and yet each will receive his own special reward, answering to his own special work.
28420	46	3	9	  Apollos and I are simply fellow workers  for and with God, and you are *God's* field-- *God's* building.
28421	46	3	10	  In discharge of the task which God graciously entrusted to me, I--like a competent master-builder--have laid a foundation, and others are building upon it. But let every one be careful how and what he builds.
28422	46	3	11	 For no one can lay any other foundation in addition to that which is already laid, namely Jesus Christ.
28423	46	3	12	 And whether the building which any one  is erecting on that foundation be of gold or silver or costly stones, of timber or hay or straw--
28424	46	3	13	 the true character of each individual's work will become manifest. For  the day of Christ will disclose it, because that day  is soon to come upon us clothed in fire, and as for the quality of every one's work-- the fire is the thing which will test it.
28425	46	3	14	 If any one's work--the building which he has erected--stands the test, he will be rewarded.
28426	46	3	15	  If any one's work is burnt up, he will suffer the loss of it; yet he will himself be rescued, but only, as it were, by passing through the fire.
28427	46	3	16	 Do you not know that you are God's Sanctuary, and that the Spirit of God has His home within you?
28428	46	3	17	 If any one is marring the Sanctuary of God, him will God mar; for the Sanctuary of God is holy, which you all are.
28429	46	3	18	 Let no one deceive himself. If any man imagines that he is wise,  compared with the rest of you, with the wisdom of the present age, let him become "foolish" so that he may be wise.
28430	46	3	19	 This world's wisdom is "foolishness" in God's sight; for it is written, <"He snares the wise with their own cunning.">
28431	46	3	20	 And again, <"The Lord takes knowledge of the reasonings of the wise--how useless they are.">
28432	46	3	21	 Therefore let no one boast about  his human teachers.
28433	46	3	22	 For everything belongs to you--be it Paul or Apollos or  Peter, the world or life or death,  things present or future--everything belongs to you;
28434	46	3	23	 and you belong to Christ, and Christ belongs to God.
28435	46	4	1	 As for  us Apostles, let any one take this view of us--we are Christ's  officers, and stewards of God's secret truths.
28436	46	4	2	 This being so, it follows that fidelity is what is required in stewards.
28437	46	4	3	  I however am very little concerned at undergoing your scrutiny, or that of other men; in fact I do not even scrutinize myself.
28438	46	4	4	 Though I am not conscious of having been in any way unfaithful, yet I do not for that reason stand acquitted; but He whose scrutiny I must undergo is the Lord.
28439	46	4	5	 Therefore form no premature judgements, but wait until the Lord  returns. He will  both bring to light the secrets of darkness and will openly disclose the motives that have been in people's hearts; and then the praise which each man deserves will come to him from God.
28440	46	4	6	 In writing this much, brethren,  with special reference  to Apollos and myself, I have done so for your sakes, in order to teach you by our example what those words mean, which say, "Nothing beyond what is written!" --so that you may cease to take sides in boastful rivalry, for one teacher against another.
28441	46	4	7	  Why, who gives you your superiority, my brother? Or what have you that you did not receive? And if you really  did receive it, why boast as if this were not so?
28442	46	4	8	 Every one of you already  has all that heart can desire; already you  have grown rich; without waiting for us, you  have ascended your thrones! Yes indeed, would to God that you had ascended your thrones, that we also might reign with you!
28443	46	4	9	 God, it seems to me, has  exhibited us Apostles last of all, as men condemned to death; for we have come to be a spectacle to all creation--alike to angels and to men.
28444	46	4	10	 We, for Christ's sake, are labeled as "foolish";  you, as Christians, are men of shrewd intelligence. We are mere weaklings: you are strong. You are in high repute: we are outcasts.
28445	46	4	11	 To this very moment we endure both hunger and thirst, with scanty clothing and many a blow.
28446	46	4	12	 Homes we have none. Wearily we toil, working with our own hands. When reviled, we bless; when persecuted, we bear it patiently;
28447	46	4	13	 when slandered, we try to conciliate. We have  come to be regarded as the mere dirt and filth of the world--the refuse of the universe, even to this hour.
28448	46	4	14	 I am not writing all this to shame you, but I am offering you advice as my dearly-loved children.
28449	46	4	15	 For even if you were to have ten thousand  spiritual instructors--for all that you could not have several fathers. It is I who in Christ Jesus became your father through the Good News.
28450	46	4	16	 I entreat you therefore to become like me.
28451	46	4	17	 For this reason I  have sent Timothy to you.  Spiritually he is my dearly-loved and faithful child. He will remind you of my  habits as a Christian teacher--the manner in which I teach everywhere in every Church.
28452	46	4	18	 But some of you have been puffed up through getting the idea that I am not coming to  Corinth.
28453	46	4	19	 But, if the Lord is willing, I shall come to you without delay; and then I shall know not the fine speeches of these conceited people, but their power.
28454	46	4	20	 For  Apostolic authority is not a thing of words, but of power.
28455	46	4	21	 Which shall it be? Shall I come to you with a rod, or in a loving and tender spirit?
28456	46	5	1	 It is actually reported that there is fornication among you, and of a kind unheard of even among the Gentiles--a man has his father's wife!
28457	46	5	2	 And you, instead of mourning and removing from among you the man who has done this deed of shame, are filled with self-complacency!
28458	46	5	3	 I for my part, present with you in spirit although absent in body, have already, as though I were present, judged him who has so acted.
28459	46	5	4	 In the name of our Lord Jesus, when you are all assembled and my spirit is with you, together with the power of our Lord Jesus,
28460	46	5	5	 I have handed over such a man to Satan for the  destruction of his  body, that his spirit may be saved on the day of the Lord  Jesus.
28461	46	5	6	 It is no good thing--this which you make the ground of your boasting. Do you not know that a little  yeast  corrupts the whole of the dough?
28462	46	5	7	 Get rid of the old yeast so that you may be dough of a new kind; for in fact you *are*  free from corruption. For our Passover Lamb has already been offered in sacrifice--even Christ.
28463	46	5	8	 Therefore let us keep our festival not with old yeast nor with the yeast of what is evil and mischievous, but with bread free from yeast--the bread of  transparent sincerity and of truth.
28464	46	5	9	 I wrote to you  in that letter that you were not to associate with fornicators;
28465	46	5	10	  not that in this world you are to keep wholly aloof from such as they, any more than from people who are avaricious and greedy of gain, or from worshippers of idols. For that would mean that you would be compelled to go out of the world altogether.
28466	46	5	11	 But what I meant was that you were not to associate with any one bearing the name of "brother," if he was addicted to fornication or avarice or idol-worship or abusive language or hard-drinking or greed of gain. With such a man you ought not even to eat.
28467	46	5	12	 For what business of mine is it to judge outsiders? Is it not for you to judge those who are within the Church
28468	46	5	13	 while you leave to God's judgement those who are outside? Remove the wicked man from among you.
28469	46	6	1	 If one of you has a grievance against an opponent, does he dare to go to law before irreligious men and not before God's people?
28470	46	6	2	 Do you not know that God's people will sit in judgement upon the world? And if you are the court before which the world  is to be judged, are you unfit to deal with these petty matters?
28471	46	6	3	 Do you not know that we are to sit in judgement upon angels--to say nothing of things belonging to this life?
28472	46	6	4	 If therefore you have things belonging to this life which need to be decided, is it  men who are absolutely nothing in the Church--is it *they* whom you make your judges?
28473	46	6	5	 I say this to put you to shame. Has it come to this, that there does not exist among you a single wise man competent to decide between  a man and his brother,
28474	46	6	6	 but brother goes to law with brother, and that before unbelievers?
28475	46	6	7	  To say no more, then, it is altogether a defect in you that you have law-suits with one another. Why not rather endure injustice? Why not rather submit to being defrauded?
28476	46	6	8	 On the contrary you yourselves inflict injustice and fraud, and upon brethren too.
28477	46	6	9	 Do you not know that unrighteous men will not inherit God's Kingdom? Cherish no delusion here. Neither fornicators, nor idolaters, nor adulterers, nor any who are guilty of unnatural crime,
28478	46	6	10	 nor theives, nor avaricious people, nor any who are addicted to hard drinking, to abusive language or to greed of gain, will inherit God's Kingdom.
28479	46	6	11	 And all this describes what some of you were.  But now you have had every stain washed off: now you have been set apart as holy: now you have been pronounced free from guilt; in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ and through the Spirit of our God.
28480	46	6	12	 Everything is allowable to me, but not everything is profitable. Everything is allowable to me, but  to nothing will I become a slave.
28481	46	6	13	 Food of all kinds is meant for the stomach, and the stomach is meant for food, and God will cause both of them to perish. Yet the body does not exist for the purpose of fornication, but for the Master's service, and the Master exists for the body;
28482	46	6	14	 and as God by His power raised the Master to life, so He will also raise us up.
28483	46	6	15	 Do you not know that your bodies are  members of Christ? Shall I then take away the members of Christ and make them the members of a prostitute? No, indeed.
28484	46	6	16	 Or do you not know that a man who has to do with a prostitute is one with her in body? For God says, <"The two shall become one.">
28485	46	6	17	 But he who is in union with the Master is one with Him in spirit.
28486	46	6	18	 Flee from fornication. Any other sin that a human being commits lies outside the body; but he who commits fornication sins against his own body.
28487	46	6	19	 Or do you not know that your bodies are a sanctuary of the Holy Spirit who is within you--the Spirit whom you have from God?
28488	46	6	20	 And you are not your own, for you have been  redeemed at infinite cost. Therefore glorify God in your bodies.
28489	46	7	1	 I now deal with the subjects mentioned in your letter. It is well for a man to abstain altogether from marriage.
28490	46	7	2	 But because there is so much fornication every man should have a wife of his own, and every woman should have a husband.
28491	46	7	3	 Let a man pay his wife her due, and let a woman also pay her husband his.
28492	46	7	4	 A married woman is not mistress of her own person: her husband has certain rights. In the same way a married man is not master of his own person: his wife has certain rights.
28493	46	7	5	  Do not refuse one another, unless perhaps it is just for a time and by mutual consent, so that you may devote yourselves to prayer and may then associate again; lest the Adversary begin to tempt you because of your deficiency in self-control.
28494	46	7	6	 Thus much in the way of concession, not of command.
28495	46	7	7	 Yet I would that everybody lived as I do; but each of us has his own special gift from God--one in one direction and one in another.
28496	46	7	8	 But I tell the unmarried, and women who are widows, that it is well for them to remain as I am.
28497	46	7	9	 If, however, they cannot maintain self-control, by all means let them marry; for marriage is better than the fever of passion.
28498	46	7	10	 But to those already married my instructions are--yet not mine, but the Lord's--that a wife is not to leave her husband;
28499	46	7	11	 or if she has already left him, let her either remain as she is or be reconciled to him; and that a husband is not to send away his wife.
28500	46	7	12	 To  the rest it is I who speak--not the Lord. If a brother has a wife who is an unbeliever, and she consents to live with him, let him not send her away.
28501	46	7	13	 And a woman who has an unbelieving husband--if he consents to live with her, let her not separate from him.
28502	46	7	14	 For, in such cases, the unbelieving husband  has become--and is--holy through union with a Christian woman, and the unbelieving wife is holy through union with a Christian brother. Otherwise your children would be unholy, but in reality they have a place among God's people.
28503	46	7	15	 If, however, the unbeliever  is determined to leave, let him or her do so. Under such circumstances the Christian man or woman is no slave; God  has called us  to live lives of peace.
28504	46	7	16	 For what assurance have you, O woman, as to whether  you will save your husband? Or what assurance have you, O man, as to whether you will save your wife?
28505	46	7	17	  Only, whatever be  the condition in life which the Lord has assigned to each individual--and whatever the condition in which he was living when God called him--in that let him continue.
28506	46	7	18	 This is what I command in all the Churches. Was any one already circumcised when called? Let him not have recourse to the surgeons. Was any one uncircumcised when called? Let him remain uncircumcised.
28507	46	7	19	 Circumcision is nothing, and uncircumcision is nothing: obedience to God's commandments is everything.
28508	46	7	20	 Whatever be the  condition in life in which a man was, when he was called, in that let him continue.
28509	46	7	21	 Were you a slave when God called you? Let not that weigh on your mind. And yet if you can get your freedom, take advantage of the opportunity.
28510	46	7	22	 For  a Christian, if he was a slave when called, is the Lord's freed man, and in the same way a free man, if called, becomes the slave of Christ.
28511	46	7	23	 You have all been  redeemed at infinite cost:  do not become slaves to men.
28512	46	7	24	 Where each one stood when he was called, there, brethren, let him still stand--close to God.
28513	46	7	25	 Concerning unmarried women I have no command to give you from the Lord; but I offer you my opinion, which is that of a man who, through the Lord's mercy, is deserving of your confidence.
28514	46	7	26	 I think then that, taking into consideration the distress which is now upon us, it is well for a man to remain as he is.
28515	46	7	27	 Are you bound to a wife? Do not seek to get free. Are you free from the marriage bond? Do not seek for a wife.
28516	46	7	28	 Yet  if you marry, you have not sinned; and if a maiden marries, she has not sinned. Such people, however, will have  outward trouble. But I am for sparing you.
28517	46	7	29	 Yet of this I warn you, brethren:  the time has been  shortened--so that henceforth those who have wives should be as though they had none,
28518	46	7	30	 those who weep as though they did not weep, those who rejoice as though they did not rejoice, those who buy as though they did not possess,
28519	46	7	31	 and those who use the world as not using it to the full. For the world as it now exists is passing away.
28520	46	7	32	 And I would have you free from worldly anxiety. An unmarried man concerns himself with the Lord's business--how he shall please the Lord;
28521	46	7	33	 but a married man concerns himself with the business of the world--how he shall please his wife.
28522	46	7	34	 There is a difference too between a married and an unmarried woman. She who is unmarried concerns herself with the Lord's business--that she may be holy both in body and spirit; but the married woman concerns herself with the business of the world--how she shall please her husband.
28523	46	7	35	 Thus much I say in your own interest; not to lay a trap for you, but to help towards what is becoming, and enable you to wait on the Lord without distraction.
28524	46	7	36	 If, however, a father thinks he is acting unbecomingly towards his still unmarried daughter if she be past the bloom of her youth, and so the matter is urgent, let him do what she desires; he commits no sin;  she and her suitor should be allowed to marry.
28525	46	7	37	 But if a father stands firm in his resolve, being free from all external constraint and having a legal right to act as he pleases, and in his own mind has come to the decision to keep his daughter unmarried, he will do well.
28526	46	7	38	 So that he who gives his daughter in marriage does well, and yet he who does not give her in marriage will do better.
28527	46	7	39	 A woman is bound to her husband during the whole period that he lives; but if her husband  dies, she is at liberty to marry whom she will, provided that he is a Christian.
28528	46	7	40	 But in my judgement, her state is a  more enviable one if she remains as she is; and I also think that I have the Spirit of God.
28529	46	8	1	 Now as to things which have been sacrificed to idols. This is a subject which we  already understand--because we all have knowledge of it. Knowledge, however, tends to make people conceited; it is love that builds us up.
28530	46	8	2	 If any one imagines that he already possesses any true knowledge, he has as yet attained to no knowledge of the kind to which he ought to have attained;
28531	46	8	3	 but if any one loves God, that man is known by God.
28532	46	8	4	 As to eating things which have been sacrificed to idols, we are fully aware  that an idol is nothing in the world, and that there is no God but One.
28533	46	8	5	 For if so-called gods do exist, either in Heaven or on earth--and in fact there are many such gods and many such lords--
28534	46	8	6	 yet *we* have but one God, the Father, who is the source of all things and for whose service we exist, and but one Lord, Jesus Christ, through whom we and all things exist.
28535	46	8	7	 But  all believers do not recognize these facts. Some,  from force of habit in relation to the idol, even now eat idol sacrifices as such, and their consciences, being but weak, are polluted.
28536	46	8	8	 It is true that a particular kind of food will not bring us into God's presence; we are neither inferior to others if we abstain from it, nor superior to them if we eat it.
28537	46	8	9	 But take care lest this liberty of yours should prove a hindrance to the progress of weak believers.
28538	46	8	10	 For if any one were to see you, who know the real truth of this matter, reclining  at table in an idol's temple, would not his conscience (supposing him to be a weak believer)  be emboldened to eat the food which has been sacrificed to the idol?
28539	46	8	11	 Why,  your knowledge becomes the ruin of the weak believer--your brother, for whom Christ died!
28540	46	8	12	 Moreover when you thus sin against the brethren and wound their weak consciences, you are, in reality, sinning against Christ.
28541	46	8	13	 Therefore if what I eat causes my brother to fall, never again to the end of my days will I touch any kind of animal food, for fear I should cause my brother to fall.
28542	46	9	1	 Am I not free? Am I not an Apostle? Can it be denied that I  have seen Jesus, our Lord? Are not you yourselves my work in the Lord?
28543	46	9	2	 If to other men I am not an Apostle, yet at any rate I am one to you; for your very existence as a Christian Church is the seal of my Apostleship.
28544	46	9	3	 That is how I vindicate myself to those who criticize me.
28545	46	9	4	 Have we not a right  to claim food and drink?
28546	46	9	5	 Have we not a right to take with us on our journeys a Christian sister as our wife, as the rest of the Apostles do--and the Lord's brothers and  Peter?
28547	46	9	6	 Or again, is it only  Barnabas and myself who are not at liberty to give up working with our hands?
28548	46	9	7	 What soldier ever serves at his own cost? Who plants a vineyard and yet does not eat any of the grapes? Or who tends a  herd of cattle and yet does not taste their milk?
28549	46	9	8	 Am I making use of merely worldly illustrations? Does not the Law speak in the same tone?
28550	46	9	9	 For in the Law of Moses it is written, <"Thou shalt not muzzle an ox while it is treading out the grain.">
28551	46	9	10	 Is God simply thinking about the oxen? Or is it really in our interest that He speaks? Of course, it was written in our interest, because  it is His will that when a plough-man ploughs, and a thresher threshes, it should be in the hope of sharing that which comes as the result.
28552	46	9	11	 If it is we who sowed the spiritual grain in you, is it a great thing that we should reap a temporal harvest from you?
28553	46	9	12	 If other teachers  possess that right over you, do not we possess it much more? Yet we have not availed ourselves of the right, but we patiently endure all things rather than hinder in the least degree the progress of the Good News of the Christ.
28554	46	9	13	 Do you not know that those who perform the sacred rites have their food from  the sacred place, and that those who serve at the altar all alike share with the altar?
28555	46	9	14	 In the same way the Lord also  directed those who proclaim the Good News to maintain themselves by the Good News.
28556	46	9	15	 But I, for my part,  have not used, and do not use, my full rights in any of  these things. Nor do I now write with that object so far as I myself am concerned, for I would rather die than have anybody make this boast of mine an empty one.
28557	46	9	16	 If I go on preaching the Good News, that is nothing for me to boast of; for the necessity is imposed upon me; and alas for me, if I fail to preach it!
28558	46	9	17	 And if I preach willingly, I receive my wages; but if against my will, a stewardship has nevertheless been entrusted to me.
28559	46	9	18	 What are  my wages then? The very fact that the Good News which I preach will cost my hearers nothing,  so that I cannot be charged with  abuse of my privileges as a Christian preacher.
28560	46	9	19	 Though free from all human control, I  have made myself the slave of all in the hope of winning  as many converts as possible.
28561	46	9	20	 To the Jews I have become like a Jew in order to win Jews; to men under the Law as if I were under the Law--although I am not--in order to win those who are under the Law;
28562	46	9	21	 to men without Law as if I were without Law--although I am not without Law in relation to God but am abiding in Christ's Law--in order to win those who are without Law.
28563	46	9	22	 To the weak I have become weak, so as to gain the weak. To all men I have become all things, in the hope that in every one of these ways I may save some.
28564	46	9	23	 And I do everything for the sake of the Good News, that I may share with my hearers in its benefits.
28565	46	9	24	  Do you not know that in the foot-race the runners all run, but that only one gets the prize? You must run like him, in order to win with certainty.
28566	46	9	25	 But every competitor in an athletic contest practices abstemiousness in all directions. They indeed do this for the sake of securing a perishable wreath, but we for the sake of securing one that will not perish.
28567	46	9	26	 That is how I run, not being in any doubt as to my goal. I am a boxer who does not inflict blows on the air,
28568	46	9	27	 but I hit hard and straight at my own body and lead it off into slavery, lest possibly,  after I have been a herald to others, I should myself be  rejected.
28569	46	10	1	 For I would have you remember, brethren, how our forefathers were all of them  sheltered by the cloud, and all got safely through the  Red Sea.
28570	46	10	2	 All were baptized in the cloud and in the sea  to be followers of Moses.
28571	46	10	3	 All ate the same  spiritual food,
28572	46	10	4	 and all drank the same  spiritual drink; for they long drank the water that flowed from the spiritual rock that went with them--and that rock was the Christ.
28573	46	10	5	 But with most of them God was not well pleased; for they were laid low in the Desert.
28574	46	10	6	 And in this they became a warning to us, to teach us not to be eager, as they were eager, in pursuit of what is evil.
28575	46	10	7	 And you must not be worshippers of idols, as some of them were. For it is written, <"The People sat down to eat and drink, and stood up  to dance.">
28576	46	10	8	 Nor may we be fornicators, like some of them who committed fornication and on a single day  23,000 of them fell dead.
28577	46	10	9	 And do not let us  test the Lord too far, as some of them tested Him and were destroyed by the serpents.
28578	46	10	10	 And do not be discontented, as some of them were, and they were destroyed by the Destroyer.
28579	46	10	11	 All this kept happening to them with a figurative meaning; but it was put on record by way of admonition to us  upon whom the  ends of the Ages have come.
28580	46	10	12	 So then let him who thinks he is standing securely beware of falling.
28581	46	10	13	 No  temptation  has you in its power but such as is common to human nature; and God is faithful and will not allow you to be tempted beyond your strength. But, when the temptation comes, He will also provide the way of escape; so that you may be able to bear it.
28582	46	10	14	 Therefore, my dear friends, avoid all connection with the worship of idols.
28583	46	10	15	 I speak as to men of sense: judge for yourselves of what I say.
28584	46	10	16	 The cup of blessing, which we bless, does it not mean a joint-participation in the blood of Christ? The loaf of bread which we break, does it not mean a joint-participation in the body of Christ?
28585	46	10	17	  Since there is one loaf, we who are many are one body; we, all of us, share in that one loaf.
28586	46	10	18	 Look at the Israelites--the nation and their ritual. Are not those who eat the sacrifices joint-partakers in the altar?
28587	46	10	19	 Do I mean that a thing sacrificed to an idol is what it claims to be, or that an idol is a real thing?
28588	46	10	20	 No, but that which  the Gentiles sacrifice, they sacrifice to demons, not to God; and I would not have you  have fellowship with one another through the demons.
28589	46	10	21	 You cannot drink the Lord's cup and the cup of demons: you cannot be joint-partakers both in the table of the Lord and in the table of demons.
28590	46	10	22	 Or are we actually arousing the Lord  to jealousy. Are we stronger than He is?
28591	46	10	23	 Everything is allowable, but not everything is profitable. Everything is allowable, but everything does not build others up.
28592	46	10	24	 Let no one be for ever seeking his own good, but let each seek that of his fellow man.
28593	46	10	25	 Anything that is for sale in the meat market, eat, and ask no questions  for conscience' sake;
28594	46	10	26	 for <the earth is the Lord's, and all that it contains.>
28595	46	10	27	 If an unbeliever gives you an invitation and you are disposed to accept it, eat whatever is put before you, and ask no questions for conscience' sake.
28596	46	10	28	 But  if any one tells you, "This food has been offered in sacrifice;" abstain from eating it--out of respect for him who warned you, and, as before, for conscience' sake.
28597	46	10	29	 But now I mean his conscience, not your own.  "Why, on what ground," you may object, "is the question of my liberty of action to be decided by a conscience not my own?
28598	46	10	30	 If, so far as I am concerned, I partake with a grateful heart, why am I to be found fault with in regard to a thing for which I give thanks?"
28599	46	10	31	 Whether, then, you are eating or drinking, or whatever you are doing, let everything be done to the glory of God.
28600	46	10	32	 Do not be causes of stumbling either to Jews or to Gentiles, nor to the Church of God.
28601	46	10	33	 That is the way that I also seek in everything the approval of all men, not aiming at my own profit, but at that of the many, in the hope that they may be saved.
28602	46	11	1	 Be imitators of me, in so far as I in turn am an imitator of Christ.
28603	46	11	2	 Now I commend you for remembering me in everything, and because you hold fast truths and practices precisely as I have taught them to you.
28604	46	11	3	 I would have you know, however, that of every man, Christ is the Head, that of a woman her husband is the Head, and that God is Christ's Head.
28605	46	11	4	 A man  who wears a veil when praying or  prophesying dishonors his Head;
28606	46	11	5	 but  a woman who prays or prophesies with her head uncovered dishonors her Head, for  it is exactly the same as if she had her hair cut short.
28607	46	11	6	 If a woman will not wear a veil, let her also cut off her hair. But since it is a dishonor to a woman to have her hair cut off or her head shaved, let her wear a veil.
28608	46	11	7	 For a man ought not to have a veil on his head, since he is the image and glory of God; while woman is the glory of man.
28609	46	11	8	 Man does not take his origin from woman, but woman takes hers from man.
28610	46	11	9	 For man was not created for woman's sake, but woman for man's.
28611	46	11	10	 That is why a woman ought to have on her head  a symbol of subjection,  because of the angels.
28612	46	11	11	 Yet,  in the Lord, woman is not independent of man nor man independent of woman.
28613	46	11	12	 For  just as woman originates from man, so also man comes into existence through woman, but everything springs originally from God.
28614	46	11	13	 Judge of this for your own selves: is it seemly for a woman to pray to God when she is unveiled?
28615	46	11	14	 Does not  Nature itself teach you that if a man has long hair it is a dishonor to him,
28616	46	11	15	 but that if a woman has long hair it is her glory, because her hair  was given her for a covering?
28617	46	11	16	 But if any one is inclined to be contentious on the point, we have no such custom, nor have the Churches of God.
28618	46	11	17	 But while giving you these instructions, there is one thing I cannot praise--your meeting together, with bad rather than good results.
28619	46	11	18	 for, in the first place, when you meet  as a Church, there are divisions among you. This is what I am told, and I believe that there is some truth in it.
28620	46	11	19	  For there must of necessity be differences of opinion among you, in order that it may be plainly seen who are the men of sterling worth among you.
28621	46	11	20	 When, however, you meet in one place, there is no eating the Supper of the Lord;
28622	46	11	21	 for it is his own supper of which each of you is in a hurry to partake, and  one eats like a hungry man, while another has already drunk to excess.
28623	46	11	22	 Why, have you no homes in which to eat and drink? Or do you wish to show your contempt for the Church of God and make those who have no homes feel ashamed? What shall I say to you? Shall I praise you? In this matter I certainly do not praise you.
28624	46	11	23	 For it was from the Lord that I received the facts which, in turn, I handed on to you;  how that the Lord Jesus, on the night He  was to be betrayed, took some bread,
28625	46	11	24	 and after giving thanks He broke it and said, "This is my body which is  about to be broken for you. Do this in memory of me."
28626	46	11	25	 In the same way, when the meal was over, He also took the cup. "This cup," He said, "is the new Covenant  of which my blood is the pledge. Do this, every time that you drink it, in memory of me."
28627	46	11	26	 For every time that you eat this bread and drink from the cup, you are proclaiming the Lord's death--until He  returns.
28628	46	11	27	 Whoever, therefore,  in an unworthy manner, eats the bread or drinks from the cup of the Lord  sins against the body and blood of the Lord.
28629	46	11	28	 But let a man examine himself, and, having done that, then let him eat the bread and drink from the cup.
28630	46	11	29	 For any one who eats and drinks, eats and drinks judgement to himself, if he fails to  estimate the body aright.
28631	46	11	30	 That is why many among you are sickly and out of health, and why not a few  die.
28632	46	11	31	 If, however, we estimated ourselves aright, we should not be judged.
28633	46	11	32	 But when we are judged by the Lord, chastisement follows, to save us from being condemned along with the world.
28634	46	11	33	 Therefore, brethren, when you come together for this meal, wait for one another.
28635	46	11	34	 If any one is hungry, let him eat at home; so that your coming together may not lead to judgement.  The other matters I will deal with whenever I come.
28636	46	12	1	 It is important, brethren, that you should have clear knowledge on the subject of spiritual  gifts.
28637	46	12	2	 You know that when you were heathens you went astray after dumb idols, wherever you  happened to be led.
28638	46	12	3	 For this reason I would have you understand that no one speaking under the influence of The Spirit of God ever says, "Jesus is accursed," and that no one is able to say, "Jesus is Lord," except under the influence of the Holy Spirit.
28639	46	12	4	 Now there are various kinds of gifts, but there is one and the same Spirit;
28640	46	12	5	 various forms of official service, and yet one and the same Lord;
28641	46	12	6	 diversities in work, and yet one and the same God--He who in each person brings about the whole result.
28642	46	12	7	 But to each of us a manifestation of the Spirit has been granted for the common good.
28643	46	12	8	 To one the utterance of wisdom has been granted through the Spirit; to another the utterance of knowledge  in accordance with the will of the same Spirit;
28644	46	12	9	 to a third man, by means of the same Spirit, special faith; to another various gifts of healing, by means of the one Spirit;
28645	46	12	10	 to another the exercise of miraculous powers;  to another the gift of  prophecy; to another the power of discriminating between prophetic utterances; to another varieties of the gift of `tongues;' to another the interpretation of tongues.
28646	46	12	11	 But these results are all brought about by one and the same Spirit, who  bestows His gifts upon each of us in accordance with His own will.
28647	46	12	12	 For just as the human body is one and yet has many parts, and all its parts, many as they are, constitute but one body,  so it is with  the Church of Christ.
28648	46	12	13	 For, in fact, in one Spirit all of us--whether we are Jews or  Gentiles, slaves or free men--were baptized to form but one body; and we were all  nourished by that one Spirit.
28649	46	12	14	 For the human body does not consist of one part, but of many.
28650	46	12	15	 Were the foot to say, "Because I am not a  hand I am not a part of the body," that would not make it any the less a part of the body.
28651	46	12	16	 Or were the ear to say, "Because I am not an eye, I am not a part of the body," that would not make it any the less a part of the body.
28652	46	12	17	 If the whole body were an eye, where would the hearing be? If the whole body were an ear, where would the nostrils be?
28653	46	12	18	 But, as a matter of fact, God has arranged the parts in the body--every one of them--as He has seen fit.
28654	46	12	19	 If they were all one part, where would the body be?
28655	46	12	20	 But, as a matter of fact, there are many parts and but one body.
28656	46	12	21	 It is also impossible for the eye to say to the hand, "I do not need you;" or again for the head to say to the feet, "I do not need you."
28657	46	12	22	 No, it is quite otherwise. Even those parts of the body which are apparently somewhat feeble are yet indispensable;
28658	46	12	23	 and those which we deem less honorable we clothe with more abundant honor; and so our ungraceful parts come to have a more abundant grace, while our graceful parts have everything they need.
28659	46	12	24	 But it was God who  built up the body, and bestowed more abundant honor on the part that felt the need,
28660	46	12	25	 that there might be no disunion in the body, but that all the members might entertain the same anxious care for one another's welfare.
28661	46	12	26	 And if one part is suffering, every other part suffers with it; or if one part is receiving special honor, every other part  shares in the joy.
28662	46	12	27	 As for you, you are the body of Christ, and individually you are members of it.
28663	46	12	28	 And  by God's appointment there are in the Church--first Apostles, secondly  Prophets, thirdly teachers. Then come miraculous powers, and then ability to cure diseases or render loving service, or powers of organization, or varieties of the gift of `tongues.'
28664	46	12	29	 Are all Apostles? Are all Prophets? Are all teachers?
28665	46	12	30	 Have all miraculous powers? Have all ability to cure diseases? Do all speak in `tongues'? Do all interpret?
28666	46	12	31	 But always seek to excel in the greater gifts. And now I will point out to you a way of life which transcends all others.
28667	46	13	1	 If I can speak with the tongues of men and of angels, but am destitute of Love, I have but become a loud-sounding trumpet or a clanging cymbal.
28668	46	13	2	 If I possess the gift of prophecy and am versed in all mysteries and all knowledge, and have such absolute faith that I can remove mountains, but am destitute of Love, I am nothing.
28669	46	13	3	 And if I  distribute all my possessions to the poor, and give up my body  to be burned, but am destitute of Love, it profits me nothing.
28670	46	13	4	 Love is patient and kind. Love knows neither envy nor jealousy.  Love is not forward and self-assertive, nor boastful and conceited.
28671	46	13	5	 She does not behave unbecomingly, nor seek to aggrandize herself, nor blaze out in passionate anger, nor brood over wrongs.
28672	46	13	6	 She finds no pleasure in injustice done to others, but joyfully sides with the truth.
28673	46	13	7	 She knows how to be silent. She is full of trust, full of hope, full of patient endurance.
28674	46	13	8	 Love never fails. But if there are prophecies, they will be  done away with; if there are languages, they will cease; if there is knowledge, it will be  brought to an end.
28675	46	13	9	 For our knowledge is imperfect, and so is our prophesying;
28676	46	13	10	 but when the perfect state of things is come, all that is imperfect will be brought to an end.
28677	46	13	11	 When I was a child, I talked like a child,  felt like a child, reasoned like a child: when I  became a man,  I  put from me childish ways.
28678	46	13	12	 For the present we see things as if in a mirror,  and are puzzled; but then we shall see them face to face. For the present the knowledge I gain is imperfect; but then I shall know fully, even as  I am fully known.
28679	46	13	13	  And so there remain Faith, Hope, Love--these three; and of these the greatest is Love.
28680	46	14	1	 Be eager in your pursuit of this Love, and be earnestly ambitious for spiritual gifts, but let it be chiefly so in order that you may prophesy.
28681	46	14	2	 For he who speaks in an unknown tongue is not speaking to men, but to God; for no one understands him. Yet in the Spirit he is speaking secret truths.
28682	46	14	3	 But he who  prophesies speaks to men words of edification,  encouragement and comfort.
28683	46	14	4	 He who speaks in an unknown tongue  does good to himself, but he who prophesies  does good to the Church.
28684	46	14	5	 I should be right glad were you all to speak in `tongues,' but yet more glad were you all to prophesy. And, in fact, the man who prophesies is superior to him who speaks in `tongues,' except when the latter  can interpret in order that the Church may get a blessing.
28685	46	14	6	 But, brethren, as things are, if I come to you speaking in `tongues,' what benefit shall I confer on you,  if the utterance is neither in the form of a revelation nor of additional knowledge nor of prophecy nor of teaching?
28686	46	14	7	 Even inanimate things--flutes or harps, for instance--when yielding a sound, if they make no distinction in the notes, how shall the tune which is played on the flute or the harp be known?
28687	46	14	8	 If the bugle--to take another example--gives an uncertain sound, who will prepare for battle?
28688	46	14	9	 And so with you; if with the living voice you fail to utter intelligible words, how will people know what you are saying? You will be talking to the winds.
28689	46	14	10	 There are, we will suppose, a great number of languages in the world, and no creature is without a language.
28690	46	14	11	 If, however, I do not know the meaning of the particular language, I shall seem to the speaker of it, and he to me, to be merely talking some foreign tongue.
28691	46	14	12	 Therefore, seeing that you are ambitious for spiritual gifts, seek to excel in them so as to  benefit the Church.
28692	46	14	13	 Therefore let a man who has the gift of tongues pray for the power of interpreting them.
28693	46	14	14	 For if I pray in an unknown tongue,  my spirit prays, but my understanding is barren.
28694	46	14	15	 How then does the matter stand? I will pray in spirit, and I will pray with my understanding also. I will  praise God in spirit, and I will praise Him with my understanding also.
28695	46	14	16	 Otherwise, if you bless God in spirit only, how shall he who is in the position of an ungifted man say the `Amen' to your giving of thanks, when he does not know what your words mean?
28696	46	14	17	 Rightly enough you are giving thanks, and yet your neighbor is not  benefited.
28697	46	14	18	 I speak in a tongue, thank God, more than all of you;
28698	46	14	19	 but in the Church I would rather speak five words with my understanding--so as to instruct others also--than ten thousand words in an unknown tongue.
28699	46	14	20	 Brethren, do not prove yourselves to be children in your minds. As regards evil, indeed, be utter babes, but as regards your minds prove yourselves to be men of ripe years.
28700	46	14	21	 In the Law it stands written, <"`By men of unknown tongues and by the lips of an unknown nation will I speak to this People, but even then they will not listen to Me',> says the Lord."
28701	46	14	22	 This shows that the gift of tongues is intended as a sign not to those who believe but to unbelievers, but  prophecy is intended not for unbelievers but for those who believe.
28702	46	14	23	 Accordingly if the whole Church has assembled and all are speaking in `tongues,' and there come in ungifted men, or unbelievers, will they not say that you are all mad?
28703	46	14	24	 If, on the other hand, every one is prophesying and an unbeliever or an ungifted man comes in, he is convicted by all and closely examined by all,
28704	46	14	25	 and the hidden evils of his heart are brought to light. And, as the result, he will fall on his face and worship God, and will report to others that of a truth God is among you.
28705	46	14	26	 What then, brethren? Whenever you assemble, there is not one of you who is not ready either with a song of praise, a sermon, a revelation, a `tongue,' or an interpretation. Let everything be done with a view to the  building up of faith and character.
28706	46	14	27	 If there is speaking in an unknown tongue, only two or at the most three should speak, and they should do so one at a time, and one should interpret;
28707	46	14	28	 or if there is no interpreter, let the man with the gift be silent in the Church, speaking to himself and to God.
28708	46	14	29	 But if there are Prophets, let two or three speak and let the rest  judge.
28709	46	14	30	 And if anything is revealed to some one else who is  seated there, let the first be silent.
28710	46	14	31	 For you can all prophesy one by one, so that all may learn and all be encouraged:
28711	46	14	32	 and the spirits of Prophets yield submission to Prophets.
28712	46	14	33	 For God is not a God of disorder, but of peace,  as He is in all the Churches of His people.
28713	46	14	34	 Let  married women be silent in the Churches, for they are not permitted to speak. They must be content with a subordinate place, as the Law also says;
28714	46	14	35	 and if they wish to ask questions, they should ask  their own husbands at home. For it is disgraceful for a married woman to speak at a Church assembly.
28715	46	14	36	  Was it from you that God's Message first went forth, or is it to you only that it has come?
28716	46	14	37	 If any one deems himself to be a Prophet or a man with spiritual gifts,  let him recognize as the Lord's command all that I am now writing to you.
28717	46	14	38	 But if any one is ignorant,  let him be ignorant.
28718	46	14	39	 The conclusion, my brethren, is this. Be earnestly ambitious to prophesy, and do not check speaking with tongues;
28719	46	14	40	 only let everything be done in a becoming and orderly manner.
28720	46	15	1	 But let me recall to you, brethren, the Good News which I brought you, which you accepted, and on which you are standing,
28721	46	15	2	 through which also you are obtaining salvation, if you bear in mind the words in which I proclaimed it--unless indeed your faith has been unreal  from the very first.
28722	46	15	3	 For I repeated to you the all-important fact which also I had been taught, that Christ died for our sins in accordance with the Scriptures;
28723	46	15	4	 that He was buried; that He rose to life again on the third day in accordance with the Scriptures,
28724	46	15	5	 and was seen by  Peter, and then by the Twelve.
28725	46	15	6	 Afterwards He was seen by more than five hundred brethren  at once, most of whom are still alive, although some of them have now fallen asleep.
28726	46	15	7	 Afterwards He was seen by James, and then by all the Apostles.
28727	46	15	8	 And last of all, as to one of untimely birth, He appeared to me also.
28728	46	15	9	 For I am  the least of the Apostles, and am not fit to be called an Apostle--because I persecuted the Church of God.
28729	46	15	10	 But what I am I am by the grace of God, and His grace bestowed upon me did not prove ineffectual. But I labored more strenuously than all the rest--yet it was not I, but God's grace working with me.
28730	46	15	11	 But whether it is I or they, this is the way we preach and the way that you came to believe.
28731	46	15	12	 But if Christ is preached as having risen from the dead, how is it that some of you say that there is no such thing as a resurrection of the dead?
28732	46	15	13	 If there is no such thing as a resurrection of the dead, then Christ Himself has not risen to life.
28733	46	15	14	 And if Christ has not risen, it follows that what we preach is a delusion, and that your faith also is  a delusion.
28734	46	15	15	 Nay more, we are actually being discovered to be bearing false witness about God, because we have testified that God raised Christ to life, whom He did not raise, if in reality none of the dead are raised.
28735	46	15	16	 For if none of the dead are raised to life, then Christ has not risen;
28736	46	15	17	 and if Christ has not risen, your faith is  a vain thing--you are still in your sins.
28737	46	15	18	 It follows also that those who  have fallen asleep in Christ  have perished.
28738	46	15	19	 If in this present life we  have a *hope* resting on Christ,  and nothing more, we are more to be pitied than all the rest of the world.
28739	46	15	20	 But, in reality, Christ *has* risen from among the dead, being the first to do so of those who are asleep.
28740	46	15	21	 For seeing that death came through man, through man comes also the resurrection of the dead.
28741	46	15	22	 For just as through Adam all die, so also through Christ all will be made alive again.
28742	46	15	23	 But this will happen to each in the right order--Christ having been the first to rise, and afterwards Christ's people rising at His return.
28743	46	15	24	  Later on, comes  the End, when He is to surrender the Kingship  to God, the Father, when He shall have  overthrown all other government and all other authority and power.
28744	46	15	25	 For He must continue King until  He shall have put all His enemies under His feet.
28745	46	15	26	 The last enemy that is to be  overthrown is Death;
28746	46	15	27	 for He  will have put all things in subjection under His feet. And when He shall have declared that "All things  are in subjection," it will be with the manifest exception of Him who has reduced them all to subjection to Him.
28747	46	15	28	 But when the whole universe has been made subject to Him, then the Son Himself will also become subject to Him who has made the universe subject to Him, in order that GOD may be  all in all.
28748	46	15	29	  Otherwise  what will become of those who got themselves baptized for the dead? If the dead do not rise at all,  why are these baptized for them?
28749	46	15	30	 Why also do  we Apostles expose ourselves to danger every hour?
28750	46	15	31	 I protest, brethren, as surely as I glory over you--which I may justly do in Christ Jesus our Lord--that I die day by day.
28751	46	15	32	 If from merely human motives I  have fought with  wild beasts in Ephesus, what profit is it to me? If the dead do not rise, let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we are to die.
28752	46	15	33	 Do not deceive yourselves: "Evil companionships corrupt good morals."
28753	46	15	34	 Wake from this drunken fit; live righteous lives, and cease to sin; for some have no knowledge of God: I speak thus in order to move you to shame.
28754	46	15	35	 But some one will say, "How can the dead rise? And with what kind of body do they come back?"
28755	46	15	36	  Foolish man! the seed you yourself sow has no life given to it unless it first dies;
28756	46	15	37	 and as for what you sow, it is not the plant which is to be that you are sowing, but a bare grain, of wheat (it may be) or of something else, and God gives it a body as He has seen fit,
28757	46	15	38	 and to each kind of seed a body of its own.
28758	46	15	39	 All flesh is not the same: there is human flesh, and flesh of cattle, of birds, and of fishes.
28759	46	15	40	 There are bodies which are celestial and there are bodies which are earthly, but the glory of the celestial ones is one thing, and that of the earthly ones is another.
28760	46	15	41	 There is one glory of the sun, another of the moon, and another of the stars; for star differs from star in glory.
28761	46	15	42	  It is the same with the resurrection of the dead. The body is sown in a state of decay, it is raised free from decay;
28762	46	15	43	 it is sown in dishonor, it is raised in glory; it is sown in weakness, it is raised in power;
28763	46	15	44	  an  animal body is sown, a spiritual body is raised.  As surely as there is an animal body, so there is also a spiritual body.
28764	46	15	45	 In the same way also it is written, <"The first man Adam became a living animal";> the last Adam is a life-giving Spirit.
28765	46	15	46	 Nevertheless, it is not what is spiritual that came first, but what is animal; what is spiritual came afterwards.
28766	46	15	47	 The first man is a man of earth, earthy; the second man is from Heaven.
28767	46	15	48	 What the earthy one is, that also are those who are earthy; and what the heavenly One is, that also are those who are heavenly.
28768	46	15	49	 And as we have borne a resemblance to the earthy one, let us see to it that we also bear a resemblance to the heavenly One.
28769	46	15	50	 But this I tell you, brethren:  our mortal bodies cannot inherit the Kingdom of God, nor will what is perishable inherit what is imperishable.
28770	46	15	51	 I tell you  a truth hitherto kept secret: we shall not all sleep, but we shall all be changed,
28771	46	15	52	 in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the sounding of  the last trumpet; for the trumpet will sound, and the dead will be raised incapable of decay, and *we* shall be changed.
28772	46	15	53	 For so it must be: this perishable nature must clothe itself with what is imperishable, and this mortality must clothe itself with immortality.
28773	46	15	54	 But when this perishable nature has put on what is imperishable, and this mortality has put on immortality, then will the words of Scripture be fulfilled, <"Death has been swallowed up in victory.">
28774	46	15	55	 <"Where, O death, is thy victory? Where, O death, is thy  sting?">
28775	46	15	56	 Now sin is the sting of death, and sin derives its power from the Law;
28776	46	15	57	 but God be thanked who gives us the victory through our Lord Jesus Christ!
28777	46	15	58	 Therefore, my dear brethren, be firm, unmovable, busily occupied at all times in the Lord's work, knowing that your toil is not fruitless  in the Lord.
28778	46	16	1	 As to the collection for God's people, what I have directed the Churches of Galatia to do, you must do also.
28779	46	16	2	 On the first day of every week let each of you put on one side and store up at his home  whatever gain has been granted to him; so that whenever I come, there may then be no collections going on.
28780	46	16	3	 And when I am with you, whatever brethren you accredit by letter I will send to carry your kind gift to Jerusalem.
28781	46	16	4	 And if it is worth while for me also to make the journey, they shall go as my companions.
28782	46	16	5	 I shall come to you after passing through Macedonia; for my plan will be to pass through Macedonia;
28783	46	16	6	 and I shall make some stay with you perhaps, or even spend the winter with you, in order that you may help me forward, whichever way I travel.
28784	46	16	7	 For I do not wish to see you on this occasion merely in passing; but if the Lord permits, I hope to remain some time with you.
28785	46	16	8	 I shall remain in Ephesus, however, until  the time of the Harvest Festival,
28786	46	16	9	 for a wide door stands open before me which demands great efforts, and we have many opponents.
28787	46	16	10	 If Timothy pays you a visit, see that he is free from fear in his relations with you; for he is engaged in the Master's work just as I am.
28788	46	16	11	 Therefore let no one slight him, but all of you should help him forward in peace to join me; for I am waiting for him and  others of the brethren.
28789	46	16	12	 As for our brother Apollos, I have repeatedly urged him to accompany the brethren who are  coming to you: but he is quite resolved not to do so at present. He will come, however, when he has a good opportunity.
28790	46	16	13	  Be on the alert; stand firm in the faith; acquit yourselves like men; be strong.
28791	46	16	14	 Let all that you do be done  from motives of love.
28792	46	16	15	 And I beseech you, brethren--you know the household of Stephanas, how they were the earliest Greek converts to Christ, and have devoted themselves to the service of God's people--
28793	46	16	16	 I beseech you, on your part, to show deference to such men, and to every one who participates in their work and toils hard.
28794	46	16	17	 It is a joy to me that Stephanas, Fortunatus and Achaicus have now arrived, because  what was wanting so far as you are concerned they have supplied.
28795	46	16	18	 They have refreshed my spirit,  and yours. Acknowledge such men as these.
28796	46	16	19	 The Churches in the province of Asia send you greetings; and Aquila and Prisca, in hearty Christian love, do the same, together with the Church which meets  at their house.
28797	46	16	20	 The brethren all send greetings to you. Greet one another  with a holy kiss.
28798	46	16	21	 The final greeting of me--Paul--with my own hand.
28799	46	16	22	 If any one is destitute of love to the Lord, let him be accursed.  OUR LORD IS COMING.
28800	46	16	23	 The grace of the Lord Jesus be with you.
28801	46	16	24	 My love in Christ Jesus be with you all.
28802	47	1	1	 Paul, an Apostle of Christ Jesus by the will of God--and our brother Timothy: To the Church of God in Corinth, with all God's people throughout  Greece.
28803	47	1	2	 May grace and peace be granted to you from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
28804	47	1	3	 Heartfelt thanks be to the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ--the  Father who is full of compassion and the God who gives all  comfort.
28805	47	1	4	 He comforts us in our every affliction so that we may be able to comfort those who are in any kind of affliction by means of the comfort with which we ourselves are comforted by God.
28806	47	1	5	 For just as we have more than our share of suffering for the Christ, so also through the Christ we have more than our share of comfort.
28807	47	1	6	 But if, on the one hand, we are enduring affliction, it is  for your comfort and salvation; and if, on the other hand, we are receiving comfort, it is for your comfort which is produced within you through your patient fortitude under the same sufferings as those which we also are enduring.
28808	47	1	7	 And our hope for you is stedfast; for we know that as you are partners with us in the sufferings, so you are also partners in the comfort.
28809	47	1	8	 For as for our troubles which came upon us in  the province of Asia, we would have you know, brethren, that we were exceedingly weighed down,  and felt overwhelmed, so that we renounced all hope even of life.
28810	47	1	9	 Nay, we had, as we still have, the  sentence of death within our own selves, in order that our confidence may repose, not on ourselves, but on God who raised the dead to life.
28811	47	1	10	 He it is who rescued us from so imminent a death, and will do so again; and we have a firm hope in Him that He will also rescue us in all the future,
28812	47	1	11	 while you on your part lend us your aid in entreaty for us, so that from many lips thanksgivings may rise on our behalf for the boon granted to us at the intercession of many.
28813	47	1	12	 For the reason for our boasting is this--the testimony of our own conscience that it was in holiness and with  pure motives before God, and in reliance not on worldly wisdom but on the gracious help of God, that we have conducted ourselves in the world, and above all in our relations with you.
28814	47	1	13	 For we are writing to you nothing different from what we have written before, or from what indeed you already recognize as truth and will, I trust, recognize as such to the very end;
28815	47	1	14	 just as some few of you have recognized us as your reason for boasting, even as you will be ours, on the day of Jesus our Lord.
28816	47	1	15	 It was because I entertained this confidence that I intended to visit you  before going elsewhere--so that you might receive a twofold  proof of God's favour--
28817	47	1	16	 and to pass by way of Corinth into Macedonia. Then my plan was to return from Macedonia to you, and be helped forward by you to Judaea.
28818	47	1	17	 Did I display any  vacillation or caprice in this? Or the purposes which I form--do I form them on worldly principles, now crying "Yes, yes," and now "No, no"?
28819	47	1	18	 As certainly as God is faithful, our language to you is not now "Yes" and now "No."
28820	47	1	19	 For Jesus Christ the Son of God--He who was proclaimed among you by us, that is by  Silas and Timothy and myself--did not show Himself a waverer between "Yes" and "No." But it  was and always is "Yes" with Him.
